6 • The Journey /поездка/ from Platform Nine and Three-Quarters /три четверти/

section.p: Mr and Mrs Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud /гордый/ to say that they were perfectly /в совершенстве/ normal /нормальный/, thank /спасибо/ you very much. They were the last people you’d expect to be involved /участвует/ in anything strange or mysterious /загадочный/, because they just didn /А не было/’t hold with such nonsense /бред какой то/.

Mr Dursley was the director /директор/ of a firm /фирма/ called Grunnings /grunnings/, which made drills /сверла/. He was a big, beefy /мускулистый/ man with hardly any neck, although he did have a very large moustache /усы/. Mrs Dursley was thin and blonde /блондинка/ and had nearly twice the usual amount /количество/ of neck, which came in very useful /полезным/ as she spent so much of her time craning /вытягивали/ over garden /сад/ fences /заборы/, spying /шпионаж/ on the neighbours /соседи/. The Dursleys had a small son /сын/ called Dudley and in their opinion /мнение/ there was no finer /мельче/ boy anywhere /в любом месте/.

The Dursleys had everything they wanted, but they also had a secret, and their greatest /величайший/ fear /страх/ was that somebody /кто-то/ would discover /обнаружить/ it. They didn /А не было/’t think they could bear /медведь/ it if anyone found out about the Potters. Mrs Potter was Mrs Dursley’s /Дурслей/ sister, but they hadn’t met for several years; in fact, Mrs Dursley pretended /притворился/ she didn /А не было/’t have a sister, because her sister and her good-for-nothing /никуда не годится/ husband /муж/ were as unDursleyish /undursleyish/ as it was possible to be. The Dursleys shuddered /содрогнулся/ to think what the neighbours /соседи/ would say if the Potters arrived in the street. The Dursleys knew that the Potters had a small son /сын/, too, but they had never even seen him. This boy was another good reason for keeping /хранение/ the Potters away; they didn /А не было/’t want Dudley mixing /смешивание/ with a child /ребенок/ like that.

When Mr and Mrs Dursley woke /просыпался/ up on the dull /скучный/, grey Tuesday /вторник/ our story starts /начинается/, there was nothing about the cloudy /облачный/ sky outside to suggest /предлагать/ that strange and mysterious /загадочный/ things would soon be hap /случаться/­pening /pening/ all over the country /страна/. Mr Dursley hummed /напевала/ as he picked out his most boring /скучный/ tie /галстук/ for work and Mrs Dursley gossiped /сплетничали/ away happily /счастливо/ as she wrestled /боролся/ a screaming /кричащий/ Dudley into his high chair /стул/.
None of them noticed a large tawny /рыжевато-коричневый/ owl flutter /флаттер/ past the window.

At half past eight /8/, Mr Dursley picked up his briefcase /портфель/, pecked /клевать/ Mrs Dursley on the cheek /щека/ and tried to kiss /поцелуй/ Dudley goodbye /Прощай/ but missed /пропущенный/, because Dudley was now having a tantrum /вспышка гнева/ and throwing /бросание/ his cereal /зерновой/ at the walls. ‘Little tyke /дворняжка/,’ chortled /хохотнул/ Mr Dursley as he left the house. He got into his car and backed /со спинкой/ out of number four’s /четверки/ drive.

It was on the corner of the street that he noticed the first sign of something peculiar /своеобразный/ – a cat reading /чтение/ a map /карта/. For a second, Mr Dursley didn /А не было/’t realise /понимать/ what he had seen – then he jerked /рывок/ his head around to look again. There was a tabby /полосатый/ cat standing on the corner of Privet Drive, but there wasn /WASN/’t a map /карта/ in sight. What could he have been thinking of? It must have been a trick /трюк/ of the light. Mr Dursley blinked /моргнула/ and stared at the cat. It stared back. As Mr Dursley drove /поехали/ around the corner and up the road /Дорога/, he watched the cat in his mirror. It was now reading /чтение/ the sign that said Privet Drive – no, looking at the sign; cats /коты/ couldn /не мог/’t read maps /карты/ or signs /знаки/. Mr Dursley gave himself a little shake /встряхивать/ and put the cat out of his mind. As he drove /поехали/ towards town /город/ he thought of nothing except a large order /заказ/ of drills /сверла/ he was hoping to get that day.

But on the edge of town /город/, drills /сверла/ were driven /управляемый/ out of his mind by something else. As he sat in the usual morning traffic /трафик/ jam /варенье/, he couldn /не мог/’t help noticing /замечающий/ that there seemed to be a lot of strangely /странно/ dressed /заправленный/ people about. People in cloaks /накидки/. Mr Dursley couldn /не мог/’t bear /медведь/ people who dressed /заправленный/ in funny clothes /одежда/ – the get-ups /получить бонусы/ you saw on young /молодой/ people! He supposed this was some stupid new fashion /мода/. He drummed /барабанил/ his fingers on the steering /рулевое управление/ wheel /колесо/ and his eyes fell on a huddle /жаться/ of these weirdos /чудаков/ standing quite close by. They were whis /whis/­pering /pering/ excitedly /азартно/ together. Mr Dursley was enraged /разъяренный/ to see that a couple /пара/ of them weren’t young /молодой/ at all; why, that man had to be older /старшая/ than he was, and wearing an emerald /изумруд/-green cloak! The nerve /нерв/ of him! But then it struck /пораженный/ Mr Dursley that this was probably some silly /глупый/ stunt /трюк/ – these people were obviously collecting /сбор/ for something ... yes, that would be it. The traffic /трафик/ moved on, and a few minutes later, Mr Dursley arrived in the Grunnings /grunnings/ car park /парк/, his mind back on drills /сверла/.

Mr Dursley always sat with his back to the window in his office /офис/ on the ninth /девятый/ floor. If he hadn’t, he might have found it harder /Сильнее/ to concentrate /концентрат/ on drills /сверла/ that morning. He didn /А не было/’t see the owls swooping /парящий/ past in broad /широкий/ daylight /дневной свет/, though people down in the street did; they pointed and gazed /смотрел/ open-mouthed /с открытым ртом/ /горлышко/ as owl after owl sped /ускоренный/ overhead /накладные расходы/. Most of them had never seen an owl even at night-time /ночь/. Mr Dursley, however, had a perfectly /в совершенстве/ normal /нормальный/, owl-free /Сова-бесплатно/ morn /утро/­ing. He yelled at five different people. He made several important telephone /телефон/ calls /звонки/ and shouted a bit more. He was in a very good mood /настроение/ until lunch /обед/-time, when he thought he’d stretch /протяжение/ his legs and walk across the road /Дорога/ to buy himself a bun /булочка/ from the baker’s /булочная/ opposite /напротив/.

He’d forgotten all about the people in cloaks /накидки/ until he passed a group /группа/ of them next to the baker’s /булочная/. He eyed /глаза/ them angrily /сердито/ as he passed. He didn /А не было/’t know why, but they made him uneasy /беспокойный/. This lot were whispering /шепот/ excitedly /азартно/, too, and he couldn /не мог/’t see a single /Один/ collecting /сбор/ tin /банка/. It was on his way back past them, clutching /вцепившись/ a large doughnut /пончик/ in a bag /мешок/, that he caught a few words of what they were saying.
‘The Potters, that’s right, that’s what I heard –’
‘– yes, their son /сын/, Harry –’
Mr Dursley stopped dead. Fear /страх/ flooded /затопленный/ him. He looked back at the whisperers /злоречивы/ as if he wanted to say something to them, but thought better of it.

He dashed /пунктирная/ back across the road /Дорога/, hurried up to his office /офис/, snapped at his secretary /секретарь/ not to disturb /беспокоить/ him, seized his telephone /телефон/ and had almost finished dialling /набор номера/ his home number when he changed his mind. He put the receiver /получатель/ back down and stroked /гладить/ his moustache /усы/, thinking ... no, he was being stupid. Potter wasn /WASN/’t such an unusual /необычный/ name. He was sure there were lots /много/ of people called Potter who had a son /сын/ called Harry. Come to think of it, he wasn /WASN/’t even sure his nephew /племянник/ was called Harry. He’d never even seen the boy. It might have been Harvey /Harvey/. Or Harold /Гарольд/. There was no point in worrying /беспокойство/ Mrs Dursley, she always got so upset /рассториться/ at any mention /упомянуть/ of her sister. He didn /А не было/’t blame /вина/ her – if he’d had a sister like that ... but all the same, those people in cloaks /накидки/ ...

He found it a lot harder /Сильнее/ to concentrate /концентрат/ on drills /сверла/ that afternoon, and when he left the building /здание/ at five o’clock /Часы/, he was still so worried that he walked straight into someone just outside the door.

‘Sorry,’ he grunted /хрюкнул/, as the tiny old man stumbled /споткнулся/ and almost fell. It was a few seconds before Mr Dursley realised that the man was wearing a violet /Фиолетовый/ cloak. He didn /А не было/’t seem at all upset /рассториться/ at being almost knocked to the ground. On the contrary /вопреки/, his face split /Трещина/ into a wide smile and he said in a squeaky /скрипучий/ voice that made passers-by /прохожие/ stare /глазеть/: ‘Don’t be sorry, my dear sir, for nothing could upset /рассториться/ me today! Rejoice /радоваться/, for You-Know /вы знаете/-Who has gone at last! Even Muggles like yourself should be celebrating /празднуя/, this happy happy day!’
And the old man hugged /обнимала/ Mr Dursley around the middle and walked off.

Mr Dursley stood rooted /укоренившийся/ to the spot /место/. He had been hugged /обнимала/ by a complete /полный/ stranger /незнакомец/. He also thought he had been called a Muggle, whatever /без разницы/ that was. He was rattled /гремели/. He hurried to his car and set off home, hoping he was imagining /воображающий/ things, which he had never hoped /надеялся/ before, because he didn /А не было/’t approve /одобрить/ of imagination /воображение/.

As he pulled into the driveway /дорога/ of number four, the first thing he saw – and it didn /А не было/’t improve /улучшать/ his mood /настроение/ – was the tabby /полосатый/ cat he’d spotted that morning. It was now sitting on his garden /сад/ wall. He was sure it was the same one; it had the same markings /маркировка/ around its eyes.
‘Shoo /кыш/!’ said Mr Dursley loudly.

The cat didn /А не было/’t move. It just gave him a stern /кормовой/ look. Was this nor /ни/­mal /ТЗА/ cat behaviour /поведение/, Mr Dursley wondered. Trying to pull himself together, he let himself into the house. He was still determined /определенный/ not to mention /упомянуть/ anything to his wife /жена/.

Mrs Dursley had had a nice, normal /нормальный/ day. She told him over din /шум/­ner /нер/ all about Mrs Next Door’s /дверь/ problems /проблемы/ with her daughter /дочь/ and how Dudley had learnt /научился/ a new word (‘Shan’t /не должен/!’). Mr Dursley tried to act /акт/ normally /как обычно/. When Dudley had been put to bed, he went into the living /живой/-room /гостиная/ in time to catch the last report /доклад/ on the evening news:

And finally, bird /птица/-watchers everywhere /везде/ have reported /сообщается/ that the nation /нация/’s owls have been behaving /вести/ very unusually /необычно/ today. Although owls normally /как обычно/ hunt /охота/ at night and are hardly ever seen in daylight /дневной свет/, there have been hundreds of sightings /визирования/ of these birds /птицы/ flying in every direction since sunrise /Восход/. Experts /эксперты/ are unable /не в состоянии/ to explain why the owls have suddenly changed their sleeping /спать/ pattern /шаблон/.’ The news reader /читатель/ allowed himself a grin /усмешка/. ‘Most mysterious /загадочный/. And now, over to Jim /Джим/ McGuffin /McGuffin/ with the weather /Погода/. Going to be any more showers /ливни/ of owls tonight, Jim /Джим/?’

‘Well, Ted /Тед/,’ said the weatherman /метеоролог/, ‘I don’t know about that, but it’s not only the owls that have been acting /действующий/ oddly /странно/ today. Viewers /зрителей/ as far apart as Kent /Кент/, Yorkshire /Йоркшир/ and Dundee /Dundee/ have been phoning /снятия трубки/ in to tell me that instead of the rain /дождь/ I promised /обещанный/ yesterday /вчера/, they’ve /они имеют/ had a downpour /ливень/ of shooting /стрельба/ stars /звезды/! Perhaps people have been celebrating /празднуя/ Bonfire /костер/ Night early /рано/ – it’s not until next week, folks /люди/! But I can promise /обещание/ a wet /влажный/ night tonight.’

Mr Dursley sat frozen /замороженный/ in his armchair /кресло/. Shooting /стрельба/ stars /звезды/ all over Britain /Британия/? Owls flying by daylight /дневной свет/? Mysterious /загадочный/ people in cloaks /накидки/ all over the place? And a whisper /шептать/, a whisper /шептать/ about the Potters ...

Mrs Dursley came into the living /живой/-room /гостиная/ carrying /проведение/ two cups /чашки/ of tea. It was no good. He’d have to say something to her. He cleared /очищается/ his throat /горло/ nervously. ‘Er – Petunia, dear – you haven’t heard from your sister lately /в последнее время/, have you?’
As he had expected, Mrs Dursley looked shocked /в шоке/ and angry. After all, they normally /как обычно/ pretended /притворился/ she didn /А не было/’t have a sister.
‘No,’ she said sharply /резко/. ‘Why?’

‘Funny stuff on the news,’ Mr Dursley mumbled /промямлил/. ‘Owls ... shooting /стрельба/ stars /звезды/ ... and there were a lot of funny-looking /забавно выглядящий/ people in town /город/ today ...’
‘So?’ snapped Mrs Dursley.
‘Well, I just thought ... maybe ... it was something to do with ... you know ... her lot.’

Mrs Dursley sipped /потягивал/ her tea through pursed /поджала/ lips /губы/. Mr Dursley wondered whether /будь то/ he dared /посмел/ tell her he’d heard the name ‘Potter’. He decided he didn /А не было/’t dare. Instead he said, as casually /вскользь/ as he could, ‘Their son /сын/ – he’d be about Dudley’s age /возраст/ now, wouldn /Wouldn/’t he?’
‘I suppose so,’ said Mrs Dursley stiffly /натянуто/.
‘What’s his name again? Howard /Хауард/, isn’t it?’
‘Harry. Nasty, common name, if you ask me.’
‘Oh, yes,’ said Mr Dursley, his heart sinking /тонущий/ horribly /ужасно/. ‘Yes, I quite agree /дать согласие/.’

He didn /А не было/’t say another word on the subject /предмет/ as they went upstairs to bed. While Mrs Dursley was in the bathroom /ванная/, Mr Dursley crept to the bedroom /Спальня/ window and peered /всматривался/ down into the front garden /сад/. The cat was still there. It was staring down Privet Drive as though it was waiting for something.

Was he imagining /воображающий/ things? Could all this have anything to do with the Potters? If it did ... if it got out that they were related /Связанный/ to a pair of – well, he didn /А не было/’t think he could bear /медведь/ it.

The Dursleys got into bed. Mrs Dursley fell asleep quickly but Mr Dursley lay awake /бодрствующий/, turning it all over in his mind. His last, comforting /утешительный/ thought before he fell asleep was that even if the Potters were involved /участвует/, there was no reason for them to come near him and Mrs Dursley. The Potters knew very well what he and Petunia thought about them and their kind /своего рода/ ... He couldn /не мог/’t see how he and Petunia could get mixed /смешанный/ up in anything that might be going on. He yawned /зевнула/ and turned over. It couldn /не мог/’t affect /аффект/ them ...
How very wrong he was.

Mr Dursley might have been drifting /дрейфующий/ into an uneasy /беспокойный/ sleep, but the cat on the wall outside was showing /показ/ no sign of sleepiness /сонливость/. It was sitting as still as a statue /статуя/, its eyes fixed /исправлено/ unblinkingly /мигая/ on the far corner of Privet Drive. It didn /А не было/’t so much as quiver /колчан/ when a car door slammed /захлопнула/ in the next street, nor /ни/ when two owls swooped /налетает/ overhead /накладные расходы/. In fact, it was nearly midnight before the cat moved at all.

A man appeared on the corner the cat had been watching, appeared so suddenly and silently /молча/ you’d have thought he’d just popped /совал/ out of the ground. The cat’s /кошки/ tail twitched /дернулись/ and its eyes narrowed /суженный/.

Nothing like this man had ever been seen in Privet Drive. He was tall, thin and very old, judging /судейство/ by the silver of his hair and beard, which were both long enough to tuck /складка/ into his belt /ремень/. He was wearing long robes, a purple cloak which swept /прокатилась/ the ground and high-heeled /на высоком каблуке/, buckled /закрепленный/ boots /ботинки/. His blue eyes were light, bright and sparkling /сверкающий/ behind half-moon /месяц/ /Луна/ spectacles /очки/ and his nose was very long and crooked /изогнутый/, as though it had been broken at least twice. This man’s /мужской/ name was Albus Dumbledore.

Albus Dumbledore didn /А не было/’t seem to realise /понимать/ that he had just arrived in a street where everything from his name to his boots /ботинки/ was unwelcome /нежеланный/. He was busy rummaging /рыться/ in his cloak, looking for something. But he did seem to realise /понимать/ he was being watched, because he looked up suddenly at the cat, which was still staring at him from the other end of the street. For some reason, the sight of the cat seemed to amuse /озадачивать/ him. He chuckled /хихикнул/ and muttered, ‘I should have known.’

He had found what he was looking for in his inside pocket. It seemed to be a silver cigarette /сигарета/ lighter /более легкий/. He flicked /щелкнул/ it open, held it up in the air and clicked /щелкнул/ it. The nearest /ближайший/ street lamp went out with a little pop /поп/. He clicked /щелкнул/ it again – the next lamp flickered /мерцал/ into darkness /темнота/. Twelve times he clicked /щелкнул/ the Put-Outer /пут-наружный/, until the only lights /огни/ left in the whole street were two tiny pinpricks /уколы/ in the dis /дис/­tance /стояние/, which were the eyes of the cat watching him. If anyone looked out of their window now, even beady /покрытый капельками/-eyed /глаза/ Mrs Dursley, they wouldn /Wouldn/’t be able to see anything that was happening /происходит/ down on the pavement /мостовая/. Dumbledore slipped /проскользнул/ the Put-Outer /пут-наружный/ back inside his cloak and set off down the street towards number four, where he sat down on the wall next to the cat. He didn /А не было/’t look at it, but after a moment he spoke to it.
‘Fancy /маскарадный/ seeing /видя/ you here, Professor McGonagall.’

He turned to smile at the tabby /полосатый/, but it had gone. Instead he was smiling at a rather severe-looking /тяжелой выглядящий/ woman who was wearing square /квадрат/ glasses exactly the shape /форма/ of the markings /маркировка/ the cat had had around its eyes. She, too, was wearing a cloak, an emerald /изумруд/ one. Her black hair was drawn /вничью/ into a tight /в обтяжку/ bun /булочка/. She looked distinctly /отчетливо/ ruffled /взъерошенные/.
‘How did you know it was me?’ she asked.
‘My dear Professor, I’ve never seen a cat sit /сидеть/ so stiffly /натянуто/.’
‘You’d be stiff /жесткий/ if you’d been sitting on a brick /кирпич/ wall all day,’ said Professor McGonagall.
‘All day? When you could have been celebrating /празднуя/? I must have passed a dozen /дюжина/ feasts /пиры/ and parties /стороны/ on my way here.’
Professor McGonagall sniffed /понюхал/ angrily /сердито/.

‘Oh yes, everyone’s /все это/ celebrating /празднуя/, all right,’ she said impatiently /с нетерпением/. ‘You’d think they’d be a bit more careful /осторожный/, but no – even the Muggles have noticed something’s /что-то/ going on. It was on their news.’ She jerked /рывок/ her head back at the Dursleys’ dark living /живой/-room /гостиная/ window. ‘I heard it. Flocks /отары/ of owls ... shooting /стрельба/ stars /звезды/ ... Well, they’re not completely /полностью/ stupid. They were bound /связанный/ to notice /уведомление/ something. Shooting /стрельба/ stars /звезды/ down in Kent /Кент/ – I’ll bet that was Dedalus /Дедал/ Diggle /Диггл/. He never had much sense /смысл/.’
‘You can’t blame /вина/ them,’ said Dumbledore gently /осторожно/. ‘We’ve had precious /драгоценный/ little to celebrate /праздновать/ for eleven years.’

‘I know that,’ said Professor McGonagall irritably /раздражение/. ‘But that’s no reason to lose our heads. People are being downright /совершенно/ careless /неосторожный/, out on the streets /улицы/ in broad /широкий/ daylight /дневной свет/, not even dressed /заправленный/ in Muggle clothes /одежда/, swapping /обменивать/ rumours /слухи/.’

She threw a sharp, sideways /вбок/ glance /взгляд/ at Dumbledore here, as though hoping he was going to tell her something, but he didn /А не было/’t, so she went on: ‘A fine /отлично/ thing it would be if, on the very day You-Know /вы знаете/-Who seems /кажется/ to have disappeared at last, the Muggles found out about us all. I suppose he really has gone, Dumbledore?’
‘It certainly /безусловно/ seems /кажется/ so,’ said Dumbledore. ‘We have much to be thankful /благодарный/ for. Would you care /забота/ for a sherbet /шербет/ lemon /лимон/?’
‘A what?’
‘A sherbet /шербет/ lemon /лимон/. They’re a kind /своего рода/ of Muggle sweet /милая/ I’m rather fond /любящий/ of.’

‘I demand /спрос/ that you leave at once, sir!’ he said. ‘You are breaking /ломка/ and entering /входящий/!’

‘Ah, shut up, Dursley, yeh great prune /чернослив/,’ said the giant. He reached over the back of the sofa /диван/, jerked /рывок/ the gun /пистолет/ out of Uncle Vernon’s hands, bent it into a knot /морской узел/ as easily /без труда/ as if it had been made of rubber /ластик/, and threw it into a corner of the room.
Uncle Vernon made another funny noise, like a mouse /мышь/ being trodden /проторенный/ on.

‘Anyway – Harry,’ said the giant, turning his back on the Dursleys, ‘a very happy birthday to yeh. Got summat /summat/ fer yeh here – I mighta /mighta/ sat on it at some point, but it’ll /это будет/ taste /вкус/ all right.’

From an inside pocket of his black overcoat /пальто/ he pulled a slightly /немного/ squashed /раздавленный/ box. Harry opened it with trembling /дрожь/ fingers. Inside was a large, sticky /липкий/ chocolate cake /кекс/ with Happy Birthday Harry written /написано/ on it in green icing /обледенение/.
Harry looked up at the giant. He meant /имел ввиду/ to say thank /спасибо/ you, but the words got lost on the way to his mouth, and what he said instead was, ‘Who are you?’
The giant chuckled /хихикнул/.
‘True, I haven’t introduced /введены/ meself /meself/. Rubeus /Rubeus/ Hagrid, Keeper of Keys and Grounds at Hogwarts.’
He held out an enormous /огромный/ hand and shook Harry’s whole arm.
‘What about that tea then, eh?’ he said, rubbing /натирание/ his hands together. ‘I’d not say no ter summat /summat/ stronger /сильнее/ if yeh’ve /yeh've/ got it, mind.’

His eyes fell on the empty grate /решетка/ with the shrivelled /скрюченный/ crisp /хрустящий/ pack /пак/­ets /етсь/ in it and he snorted /фыркнул/. He bent down over the fireplace /камин/; they couldn /не мог/’t see what he was doing but when he drew /Дрю/ back a second later, there was a roaring /запал/ fire there. It filled /заполненный/ the whole damp /сырость/ hut with flickering /мерцающий/ light and Harry felt the warmth /тепло/ wash /мыть/ over him as though he’d sunk /погруженный/ into a hot /горячий/ bath /ванна/.

The giant sat back down on the sofa /диван/, which sagged /провис/ under his weight /вес/, and began taking all sorts /виды/ of things out of the pockets /карманы/ of his coat /Пальто/: a copper /медь/ kettle /чайник/, a squashy /болотистый/ package of sausages /колбасные изделия/, a poker /покер/, a teapot /заварочный чайник/, several chipped /сколы/ mugs /кружки/ and a bottle of some amber /янтарный/ liquid /жидкость/ which he took a swig /глоток спиртного/ from before starting /начало/ to make tea. Soon the hut was full of the sound and smell of sizzling /испепеляющий/ sausage /колбаса/. Nobody said a thing while the giant was working /за работой/, but as he slid /скользили/ the first six fat, juicy /сочный/, slightly /немного/ burnt /сожжен/ sausages /колбасные изделия/ from the poker /покер/, Dudley fidgeted /ерзал/ a little. Uncle Vernon said sharply /резко/, ‘Don’t touch anything he gives /дает/ you, Dudley.’
The giant chuckled /хихикнул/ darkly /загадочно/.
‘Yer great puddin /puddin/’ of a son /сын/ don’ need fattenin /fattenin/’ any more, Dursley, don’ worry.’

He passed the sausages /колбасные изделия/ to Harry, who was so hungry /голодный/ he had never tasted /вкус/ anything so wonderful /замечательно/, but he still couldn /не мог/’t take his eyes off the giant. Finally, as nobody seemed about to explain any­thing, he said, ‘I’m sorry, but I still don’t really know who you are.’
The giant took a gulp /глоток/ of tea and wiped /стер/ his mouth with the back of his hand.
‘Call me Hagrid,’ he said, ‘everyone does. An’ like I told yeh, I’m Keeper of Keys at Hogwarts – yeh’ll /yeh'll/ know all about Hogwarts, o’ course.’
‘Er – no,’ said Harry.
Hagrid looked shocked /в шоке/.
‘Sorry,’ Harry said quickly.

‘Sorry?’ barked /рявкнул/ Hagrid, turning to stare /глазеть/ at the Dursleys, who shrank /сжался/ back into the shadows /тени/. ‘It’s them as should be sorry! I knew yeh weren’t gettin /собирающий/’ yer letters but I never thought yeh wouldn /Wouldn/’t even know abou /Abou/’ Hogwarts, fer cryin /Cryin/’ out loud! Did yeh never wonder where yer parents learnt /научился/ it all?’
‘All what?’ asked Harry.
‘ALL WHAT?’ Hagrid thundered /прогремело/. ‘Now wait jus /закон/’ one second!’
He had leapt to his feet. In his anger /гнев/ he seemed to fill /заполнить/ the whole hut. The Dursleys were cowering /съежившись/ against the wall.
‘Do you mean ter tell me,’ he growled /прорычал/ at the Dursleys, ‘that this boy – this boy! – knows nothin /Nothin/’ abou /Abou/’ – about ANYTHING?’
Harry thought this was going a bit far. He had been to school, after all, and his marks /Метки/ weren’t bad.
‘I know some things,’ he said. ‘I can, you know, do maths /математика/ and stuff.’
But Hagrid simply /просто/ waved /махал/ his hand and said, ‘About our world, I mean. Your world. My world. Yer parents’ world.’
‘What world?’
Hagrid looked as if he was about to explode /взрываться/.
‘DURSLEY!’ he boomed /прогудел/.
Uncle Vernon, who had gone very pale, whispered something that sounded /звучало/ like ‘Mimblewimble /mimblewimble/’. Hagrid stared wildly /дико/ at Harry.
‘But yeh must know about yer mum and dad,’ he said. ‘I mean, they’re famous. You’re famous.’
‘What? My – my mum and dad weren’t famous, were they?’
‘Yeh don’ know ... yeh don’ know ...’ Hagrid ran his fingers through his hair, fixing /фиксация/ Harry with a bewildered /озадаченный/ stare /глазеть/.
‘Yeh don’ know what yeh are?’ he said finally.
Uncle Vernon suddenly found his voice.
‘Stop!’ he commanded /скомандовал/. ‘Stop right there, sir! I forbid /запретить/ you to tell the boy anything!’

A braver /смелее/ man than Vernon Dursley would have quailed /робел/ under the furious /яростный/ look Hagrid now gave him; when Hagrid spoke, his every syllable /слог/ trembled /задрожала/ with rage /ярость/.
‘You never told him? Never told him what was in the letter Dumbledore left fer him? I was there! I saw Dumbledore leave it, Dursley! An’ you’ve kept it from him all these years?’
‘Kept what from me?’ said Harry eagerly /с нетерпением/.
‘STOP! I FORBID /запретить/ YOU!’ yelled Uncle Vernon in panic /паника/.
Aunt Petunia gave a gasp /удушье/ of horror /ужастик/.
‘Ah, go boil /кипятить/ yer heads, both of yeh,’ said Hagrid. ‘Harry – yer a wizard.’
There was silence inside the hut. Only the sea /море/ and the whistling /свистящий/ wind /ветер/ could be heard.
‘I’m a what?’ gasped Harry.

‘A wizard, o’ course,’ said Hagrid, sitting back down on the sofa /диван/, which groaned /простонал/ and sank /затонуло/ even lower /ниже/, ‘an’ a thumpin /Стук/’ good’un /good'un/, I’d say, once yeh’ve /yeh've/ been trained /обученный/ up a bit. With a mum an’ dad like yours /ваш/, what else would yeh be? An’ I reckon /рассчитывать/ it’s abou /Abou/’ time yeh read yer letter.’

Harry stretched /растянуты/ out his hand at last to take the yellowish /желтоватый/ envelope /конверт/, addressed /адресованный/ in emerald /изумруд/ green to Mr H. Potter, The Floor, Hut-on-the-Rock /Хат-на-рок/, The Sea /море/. He pulled out the letter and read:

p.emphasis: HOGWARTS SCHOOL OF WITCHCRAFT /колдовство/ AND WIZARDRY /колдовство/
(Order /заказ/ of Merlin /Мерлин/, First Class, Grand /большой/ Sorc /Sorc/., Chf /CHF/. Warlock /Чернокнижник/,
Supreme /высший/ Mugwump /шишка/, International /Международный/ Confed /confed/. of Wizards)
We are pleased to inform /поставить в известность/ you that you have a place at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft /колдовство/ and Wizardry /колдовство/. Please find
enclosed /закрытый/ a list /список/ of all necessary /необходимо/ books and equipment /оборудование/.
Term /срок/ begins /начинается/ on 1 September /сентябрь/. We await /Ждите/ your owl by no later than 31 July /июль/.

section.p: Questions exploded /взорванный/ inside Harry’s head like fireworks /фейерверк/ and he couldn /не мог/’t decide /принимать решение/ which to ask first. After a few minutes he stam /стам/­mered /Меред/, ‘What does it mean, they await /Ждите/ my owl?’

‘Gallopin /Галлопин/’ Gorgons /горгоны/, that reminds /напоминает/ me,’ said Hagrid, clapping /хлопающий/ a hand to his forehead with enough force /сила/ to knock /постучать/ over a cart /телега/ horse /лошадь/, and from yet another pocket inside his overcoat /пальто/ he pulled an owl – a real, live, rather ruffled /взъерошенные/-looking owl – a long quill /полый вал/ and a roll /рулон/ of parchment /пергамент/. With his tongue /язык/ between his teeth /зубы/ he scrib /Scrib/­bled /кровь/ a note which Harry could read upside-down /вверх ногами/:

p.emphasis: Given Harry his letter. Taking him to buy his things tomorrow /завтра/. Weather /Погода/’s horrible. Hope you’re well.

section.p: Hagrid rolled up the note, gave it to the owl, which clamped /зажимают/ it in its beak /клюв/, went to the door and threw the owl out into the storm /буря/. Then he came back and sat down as though this was as normal /нормальный/ as talking on the telephone /телефон/.
Harry realised his mouth was open and closed /закрыто/ it quickly.
‘Where was I?’ said Hagrid, but at that moment, Uncle Vernon, still ashen-faced /пепельным лицом/ but looking very angry, moved into the firelight /свет от костра/.
‘He’s not going,’ he said.
Hagrid grunted /хрюкнул/.
‘I’d like ter see a great Muggle like you stop him,’ he said.
‘A what?’ said Harry, interested /заинтересованный/.

‘A Muggle,’ said Hagrid. ‘It’s what we call non-magic /немагических/ folk /люди/ like them. An’ it’s your bad luck /везение/ you grew /вырос/ up in a family o’ the biggest /самый большой/ Muggles I ever laid /проложенный/ eyes on.’
‘We swore /клялись/ when we took him in we’d put a stop to that rubbish /мусор/,’ said Uncle Vernon, ‘swore /клялись/ we’d stamp /печать/ it out of him! Wizard, indeed /в самом деле/!’
‘You knew?’ said Harry. ‘You knew I’m a – a wizard?’

‘Knew!’ shrieked /взвизгнул/ Aunt Petunia suddenly. ‘Knew! Of course we knew! How could you not be, my dratted /прокл`ятый/ sister being what she was? Oh, she got a letter just like that and disappeared off to that – that school – and came home every holiday /день отдыха/ with her pockets /карманы/ full of frog /лягушка/-spawn, turning teacups /чашки/ into rats /крысы/. I was the only one who saw her for what she was – a freak /урод/! But for my mother and father, oh no, it was Lily /Лили/ this and Lily /Лили/ that, they were proud /гордый/ of having a witch in the family!’
She stopped to draw /привлечь/ a deep breath and then went ranting /разглагольствовать/ on. It seemed she had been wanting /желая/ to say all this for years.

‘Then she met that Potter at school and they left and got mar /март/­ried /Ried/ and had you, and of course I knew you’d be just the same, just as strange, just as – as – abnormal /ненормальный/ – and then, if you please, she went and got herself /сама/ blown /взорван/ up and we got landed with you!’
Harry had gone very white. As soon as he found his voice he said, ‘Blown /взорван/ up? You told me they died in a car crash /авария/!’

‘CAR CRASH /авария/!’ roared /взревел/ Hagrid, jumping /прыжки/ up so angrily /сердито/ that the Dursleys scuttled /затоплен/ back to their corner. ‘How could a car crash /авария/ kill Lily /Лили/ an’ James /Джеймс/ Potter? It’s an outrage /безобразие/! A scandal /скандал/! Harry Potter not knowin /узнав о том,/’ his own story when every kid /дитя/ in our world knows his name!’
‘But why? What happened?’ Harry asked urgently /срочно/.
The anger /гнев/ faded /утрачен/ from Hagrid’s face. He looked suddenly anxious /озабоченный/.

‘I never expected this,’ he said, in a low, worried voice. ‘I had no idea, when Dumbledore told me there might be trouble gettin /собирающий/’ hold of yeh, how much yeh didn /А не было/’t know. Ah, Harry, I don’ know if I’m the right person /человек/ ter tell yeh – but someone’s /чей-то/ gotta /должен/ – yeh can’t go off ter Hogwarts not knowin /узнав о том,/’.’
He threw a dirty /грязный/ look at the Dursleys.
‘Well, it’s best yeh know as much as I can tell yeh – mind, I can’t tell yeh everythin /everythin/’, it’s a great myst’ry /myst'ry/, parts /части/ of it ...’

He sat down, stared into the fire for a few seconds and then said, ‘It begins /начинается/, I suppose, with – with a person /человек/ called – but it’s incredible /неимоверный/ yeh don’t know his name, everyone in our world knows –’
‘Who?’
‘Well – I don’ like sayin /говорю/’ the name if I can help it. No one does.’
‘Why not?’

‘Gulpin /gulpin/’ gargoyles /горгульи/, Harry, people are still scared. Blimey /вот это да/, this is difficult. See, there was this wizard who went ... bad. As bad as you could go. Worse. Worse than worse. His name was ...’
Hagrid gulped /проглоченный/, but no words came out.
‘Could you write /записывать/ it down?’ Harry suggested /предложенный/.

‘Nah /Неа/ – can’t spell it. All right – Voldemort.’ Hagrid shuddered /содрогнулся/. ‘Don’ make me say it again. Anyway, this – this wizard, about twenty /20/ years ago now, started lookin /заглянуть/’ fer followers /последователи/. Got ’em, too –some were afraid /боюсь/, some just wanted a bit o’ his power, ’cause /причина/ he was gettin /собирающий/’ himself power, all right. Dark days, Harry. Didn /А не было/’t know who ter trust /доверять/, didn /А не было/’t dare get friendly /дружелюбный/ with strange wizards or witches /ведьмы/ ... Terrible things happened. He was takin /такин/’ over. ’Course, some stood up to him – an’ he killed ’em. Horribly /ужасно/. One o’ the only safe places /мест/ left was Hogwarts. Reckon /рассчитывать/ Dumbledore’s the only one You-Know /вы знаете/-Who was afraid /боюсь/ of. Didn /А не было/’t dare try takin /такин/’ the school, not jus /закон/’ then, anyway.

‘Now, yer mum an’ dad were as good a witch an’ wizard as I ever knew. Head Boy an’ Girl /девушка/ at Hogwarts in their day! Suppose the myst’ry /myst'ry/ is why You-Know /вы знаете/-Who never tried to get ’em on his side before ... probably knew they were too close ter Dumbledore ter want anythin’ ter do with the Dark Side.

‘Maybe he thought he could persuade /уговаривать/ ’em ... maybe he just wanted ’em outta /убираться/ the way. All anyone knows is, he turned up in the village /деревня/ where you was all living /живой/, on Hallowe’en ten years ago. You was just a year old. He came ter yer house an’ – an’ –’
Hagrid suddenly pulled out a very dirty /грязный/, spotted handkerchief /носовой платок/ and blew /дул/ his nose with a sound like a foghorn /туманный горн/.
‘Sorry,’ he said. ‘But it’s that sad /грустный/ – knew yer mum an’ dad, an’ nicer /лучше/ people yeh couldn /не мог/’t find – anyway –

‘You-Know /вы знаете/-Who killed ’em. An’ then – an’ this is the real myst’ry /myst'ry/ of the thing – he tried to kill you, too. Wanted ter make a clean /чистый/ job /работа/ of it, I suppose, or maybe he just liked killin /убиваешь/’ by then. But he couldn /не мог/’t do it. Never wondered how you got that mark /отметка/ on yer forehead? That was no ordinary /обычный/ cut /порез/. That’s what yeh get when a powerful /мощный/, evil /зло/ curse /проклятие/ touches /прикосновений/ yeh – took care /забота/ of yer mum an’ dad an’ yer house, even – but it didn /А не было/’t work on you, an’ that’s why yer famous, Harry. No one ever lived /жил/ after he decided ter kill ’em, no one except you, an’ he’d killed some o’ the best witches /ведьмы/ an’ wizards of the age /возраст/ – the McKinnons /mckinnons/, the Bones /скелет/, the Prewetts /prewetts/ – an’ you was only a baby /детка/, an’ you lived /жил/.’

Something very painful /болезненный/ was going on in Harry’s mind. As Hagrid’s story came to a close, he saw again the blinding /ослепление/ flash /вспышка/ of green light, more clearly than he had ever remembered /вспомнил/ it before –and he remembered /вспомнил/ something else, for the first time in his life – a high, cold, cruel /жестокий/ laugh /смех/.
Hagrid was watching him sadly /грустно/.
‘Took yeh from the ruined /разрушенный/ house myself /себя/, on Dumbledore’s orders /заказы/. Brought yeh ter this lot ...’

‘Load /нагрузка/ of old tosh /вздор/,’ said Uncle Vernon. Harry jumped, he had almost forgotten that the Dursleys were there. Uncle Vernon certainly /безусловно/ seemed to have got back his courage /мужество/. He was glaring /вопиющий/ at Hagrid and his fists /кулаки/ were clenched /сжались/.

‘Now, you listen here, boy,’ he snarled /прорычал/. ‘I accept /принимать/ there’s some­thing strange about you, probably nothing a good beating /битье/ wouldn /Wouldn/’t have cured /вылеченный/ – and as for all this about your parents, well, they were weirdos /чудаков/, no denying /отрицающий/ it, and the world’s /в мире/ better off with­out them in my opinion /мнение/ – asked for all they got, getting mixed /смешанный/ up with these wizarding /волшебников/ types /типы/ – just what I expected, always knew they’d come to a sticky /липкий/ end –’

But at that moment, Hagrid leapt from the sofa /диван/ and drew /Дрю/ a battered /разбитый/ pink umbrella /зонтик/ from inside his coat /Пальто/. Pointing this at Uncle Vernon like a sword /меч/, he said, ‘I’m warning /предупреждение/ you, Dursley – I’m warning /предупреждение/ you – one more word ...’

In danger /Опасность/ of being speared /пронзенный/ on the end of an umbrella /зонтик/ by a bearded /бородатый/ giant, Uncle Vernon’s courage /мужество/ failed /не смогли/ again; he flattened /сплюснутый/ himself against the wall and fell silent /бесшумный/.
‘That’s better,’ said Hagrid, breathing /дыхание/ heavily /сильно/ and sitting back down on the sofa /диван/, which this time sagged /провис/ right down to the floor.
Harry, meanwhile /между тем/, still had questions to ask, hundreds of them.
‘But what happened to Vol /об/— sorry – I mean, You-Know /вы знаете/-Who?’

‘Good question /вопрос/, Harry. Disappeared. Vanished /исчез/. Same night he tried ter kill you. Makes /марки/ yeh even more famous. That’s the biggest /самый большой/ myst’ry /myst'ry/, see ... he was gettin /собирающий/’ more an’ more powerful /мощный/ – why’d /Почему/ he go?

‘Some say he died. Codswallop /чепуха/, in my opinion /мнение/. Dunno /Не знаю/ if he had enough human /человек/ left in him to die. Some say he’s still out there, bidin /Бидин/’ his time, like, but I don’ believe it. People who was on his side came back ter ours /наш/. Some of ’em came outta /убираться/ kinda /вроде/ trances /трансы/. Don’ reckon /рассчитывать/ they could’ve /мог бы/ done if he was comin /пуща/’ back.

‘Most of us reckon /рассчитывать/ he’s still out there somewhere but lost his powers /полномочия/. Too weak /слабый/ to carry /нести/ on. ’Cause /причина/ somethin /Somethin/’ about you finished him, Harry. There was somethin /Somethin/’ goin /входить/’ on that night he hadn’t counted /подсчитаны/ on – I dunno /Не знаю/ what it was, no one does – but somethin /Somethin/’ about you stumped /озадачены/ him, all right.’

Hagrid looked at Harry with warmth /тепло/ and respect /уважение/ blazing /полыхающий/ in his eyes, but Harry, instead of feeling pleased and proud /гордый/, felt quite sure there had been a horrible mistake /ошибка/. A wizard? Him? How could he possibly /возможно/ be? He’d spent his life being clouted /clouted/ by Dudley and bullied /издеваются/ by Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon; if he was really a wizard, why hadn’t they been turned into warty /бородавчатый/ toads /жабы/ every time they’d tried to lock /замок/ him in his cupboard? If he’d once defeated /побежденный/ the greatest /величайший/ sorcerer /колдун/ in the world, how come Dudley had always been able to kick /удар/ him around like a football /футбол/?
‘Hagrid,’ he said quietly, ‘I think you must have made a mistake /ошибка/. I don’t think I can be a wizard.’
To his surprise /сюрприз/, Hagrid chuckled /хихикнул/.
‘Not a wizard, eh? Never made things happen /случаться/ when you was scared, or angry?’

Harry looked into the fire. Now he came to think about it ... every odd thing that had ever made his aunt and uncle furious /яростный/ with him had happened when he, Harry, had been upset /рассториться/ or angry ... chased /преследовали/ by Dudley’s gang /банда/, he had somehow found himself out of their reach /достичь/ ... dreading /ужасает/ going to school with that ridiculous /смешной/ hair­cut /порез/, he’d managed to make it grow /расти/ back ... and the very last time Dudley had hit him, hadn’t he got his revenge /жажда мести/, without even real­ising /я пою/ he was doing it? Hadn’t he set a boa /боа/ constrictor /констриктор/ on him?
Harry looked back at Hagrid, smiling, and saw that Hagrid was positively /положительно/ beaming /лучезарный/ at him.
‘See?’ said Hagrid. ‘Harry Potter, not a wizard – you wait, you’ll be right famous at Hogwarts.’
But Uncle Vernon wasn /WASN/’t going to give in without a fight /борьба/.

‘Haven’t I told you he’s not going?’ he hissed /прошипел/. ‘He’s going to Stonewall /каменная стена/ High and he’ll be grateful /благодарный/ for it. I’ve read those letters and he needs /потребности/ all sorts /виды/ of rubbish /мусор/ – spell books and wands and –’

‘If he wants /хочет/ ter go, a great Muggle like you won’t stop him,’ growled /прорычал/ Hagrid. ‘Stop Lily /Лили/ an’ James /Джеймс/ Potter’s /гончарное/ son /сын/ goin /входить/’ ter Hogwarts! Yer mad. His name’s /зовут/ been down ever since he was born /Родился/. He’s off ter the finest /лучшие/ school of witchcraft /колдовство/ and wizardry /колдовство/ in the world. Seven years there and he won’t know himself. He’ll be with youngsters /молодежь/ of his own sort, fer a change /изменение/, an’ he’ll be under the greatest /величайший/ Headmaster /старший мастер/ Hogwarts ever had, Albus Dumbled /dumbled/—’
‘I AM NOT PAYING /платеж/ FOR SOME CRACKPOT /ненормальный/ OLD FOOL /дурачить/ TO TEACH /учат/ HIM MAGIC TRICKS /трюки/!’ yelled Uncle Vernon.

But he had finally gone too far. Hagrid seized his umbrella /зонтик/ and whirled /кружился/ it over his head. ‘NEVER –’ he thundered /прогремело/, ‘– INSULT /оскорбление/ – ALBUS – DUMBLEDORE – IN – FRONT – OF – ME!’

He brought the umbrella /зонтик/ swishing /свистящий/ down through the air to point at Dudley – there was a flash /вспышка/ of violet /Фиолетовый/ light, a sound like a firecracker /фейерверк/, a sharp squeal /визг/ and next second, Dudley was dancing /танцы/ on the spot /место/ with his hands clasped /всплеснула/ over his fat bottom /дно/, howling /воющий/ in pain. When he turned his back on them, Harry saw a curly /кудрявый/ pig /свинья/’s tail poking /тыкать/ through a hole in his trousers /брюки/.
Uncle Vernon roared /взревел/. Pulling /тянущий/ Aunt Petunia and Dudley into the other room, he cast /бросать/ one last terrified /ужас/ look at Hagrid and slammed /захлопнула/ the door behind them.
Hagrid looked down at his umbrella /зонтик/ and stroked /гладить/ his beard.

‘Shouldn /не должен/’ta /shouldn /не должен/'ta/ lost me temper /характер/,’ he said ruefully /печально/, ‘but it didn /А не было/’t work anyway. Meant /имел ввиду/ ter turn him into a pig /свинья/, but I suppose he was so much like a pig /свинья/ anyway there wasn /WASN/’t much left ter do.’
He cast /бросать/ a sideways /вбок/ look at Harry under his bushy /лохматый/ eyebrows /брови/.

‘Be grateful /благодарный/ if yeh didn /А не было/’t mention /упомянуть/ that ter anyone at Hogwarts,’ he said. ‘I’m – er – not supposed ter do magic, strictly /строго/ speakin /Speakin/’. I was allowed ter do a bit ter follow yeh an’ get yer letters to yeh an’ stuff – one o’ the reasons /причины/ I was so keen /острый/ ter take on the job /работа/ –’
‘Why aren /Арен/’t you supposed to do magic?’ asked Harry.

‘Oh, well – I was at Hogwarts meself /meself/ but I – er – got expelled, ter tell yeh the truth /правда/. In me third year. They snapped me wand in half an’ everything. But Dumbledore let me stay on as gamekeeper /егерь/. Great man, Dumbledore.’
‘Why were you expelled?’
‘It’s gettin /собирающий/’ late and we’ve got lots /много/ ter do tomorrow /завтра/,’ said Hagrid loudly. ‘Gotta /должен/ get up ter town /город/, get all yer books an’ that.’
He took off his thick black coat /Пальто/ and threw it to Harry.
‘You can kip /койка/ under that,’ he said. ‘Don’ mind if it wriggles /извивается/ a bit, I think I still got a couple /пара/ o’ dormice /сони/ in one o’ the pockets /карманы/.’
Harry woke /просыпался/ early /рано/ the next morning. Although he could tell it was daylight /дневной свет/, he kept his eyes shut tight /в обтяжку/.

‘It was a dream /мечта/,’ he told himself firmly /твердо/. ‘I dreamed /снилось/ a giant called Hagrid came to tell me I was going to a school for wizards. When I open my eyes I’ll be at home in my cupboard.’
There was suddenly a loud tapping /нажав/ noise.
‘And there’s Aunt Petunia knocking /стук/ on the door,’ Harry thought, his heart sinking /тонущий/. But he still didn /А не было/’t open his eyes. It had been such a good dream /мечта/.
Tap /нажмите/. Tap /нажмите/. Tap /нажмите/.
‘All right,’ Harry mumbled /промямлил/, ‘I’m getting up.’

He sat up and Hagrid’s heavy coat /Пальто/ fell off him. The hut was full of sunlight /Солнечный лучик/, the storm /буря/ was over, Hagrid himself was asleep on the collapsed /развалился/ sofa /диван/ and there was an owl rapping /расколачивающий/ its claw /коготь/ on the window, a newspaper /газета/ held in its beak /клюв/.

Harry scrambled /вскарабкался/ to his feet, so happy he felt as though a large balloon /воздушный шар/ was swelling /припухлость/ inside him. He went straight to the window and jerked /рывок/ it open. The owl swooped /налетает/ in and dropped the news­paper on top of Hagrid, who didn /А не было/’t wake /будить/ up. The owl then fluttered /порхали/ on to the floor and began to attack /атака/ Hagrid’s coat /Пальто/.
‘Don’t do that.’
Harry tried to wave /волна/ the owl out of the way, but it snapped its beak /клюв/ fiercely /свирепо/ at him and carried /осуществляется/ on savaging /свирепствуют/ the coat /Пальто/.
‘Hagrid!’ said Harry loudly. ‘There’s an owl –’
‘Pay /платить/ him,’ Hagrid grunted /хрюкнул/ into the sofa /диван/.
‘What?’
‘He wants /хочет/ payin /платить/’ fer deliverin /deliverin/’ the paper. Look in the pockets /карманы/.’

Hagrid’s coat /Пальто/ seemed to be made of nothing but pockets /карманы/ – bunches /сгустки/ of keys, slug /слизень/ pellets /гранулы/, balls /мячи/ of string /строка/, mint /мята/ humbugs /Мятные/, tea-bags /чайные пакетики/ /мешки/ ... finally, Harry pulled out a handful /горсть/ of strange-looking /странный вид/ coins /монеты/.
‘Give him five Knuts /Knuts/,’ said Hagrid sleepily /сонно/.
‘Knuts /Knuts/?’
‘The little bronze /бронза/ ones.’

Harry counted /подсчитаны/ out five little bronze /бронза/ coins /монеты/ and the owl held out its leg so he could put the money into a small leather /кожа/ pouch /сумка/ tied /связанный/ to it. Then it flew off through the open window.
Hagrid yawned /зевнула/ loudly, sat up and stretched /растянуты/.
‘Best be off, Harry, lots /много/ ter do today, gotta /должен/ get up ter London an’ buy all yer stuff fer school.’

Harry was turning over the wizard coins /монеты/ and looking at them. He had just thought of something which made him feel as though the happy balloon /воздушный шар/ inside him had got a puncture /прокол/.
‘Um /гм/ – Hagrid?’
‘Mm /мм/?’ said Hagrid, who was pulling /тянущий/ on his huge boots /ботинки/.
‘I haven’t got any money – and you heard Uncle Vernon last night – he won’t pay /платить/ for me to go and learn magic.’
‘Don’t worry about that,’ said Hagrid, standing up and scratch /царапина/­ing his head. ‘D’yeh /d'Yeh/ think yer parents didn /А не было/’t leave yeh anything?’
‘But if their house was destroyed /разрушенный/ –’

‘They didn /А не было/’ keep their gold in the house, boy! Nah /Неа/, first stop fer us is Gringotts. Wizards’ bank /банка/. Have a sausage /колбаса/, they’re not bad cold – an’ I wouldn /Wouldn/’ say no teh /Teh/ a bit o’ yer birthday cake /кекс/, neither /ни/.’
‘Wizards have banks /банки/?’
‘Just the one. Gringotts. Run by goblins /гоблины/.’
Harry dropped the bit of sausage /колбаса/ he was holding.

‘Yeah – so yeh’d /yeh'd/ be mad ter try an’ rob /грабить/ it, I’ll tell yeh that. Never mess /беспорядок/ with goblins /гоблины/, Harry. Gringotts is the safest /безопасный/ place in the world fer anything yeh want ter keep safe – ’cept /СЕРТ/ maybe Hogwarts. As a matter o’ fact, I gotta /должен/ visit /посещение/ Gringotts anyway. Fer Dumbledore. Hogwarts business /бизнес/.’ Hagrid drew /Дрю/ himself up proudly /гордо/. ‘He usually gets /получает/ me ter do important stuff fer him. Fetchin /fetchin/’ you – gettin /собирающий/’ things from Gringotts – knows he can trust /доверять/ me, see.
‘Got everythin /everythin/’? Come on, then.’

Harry followed Hagrid out on to the rock. The sky was quite clear /Чисто/ now and the sea /море/ gleamed /светились/ in the sunlight /Солнечный лучик/. The boat Uncle Vernon had hired /наемный/ was still there, with a lot of water /воды/ in the bottom /дно/ after the storm /буря/.
‘How did you get here?’ Harry asked, looking around for another boat.
‘Flew,’ said Hagrid.
‘Yeah – but we’ll go back in this. Not s’posed /s'posed/ ter use magic now I’ve got yeh.’
They settled /решен/ down in the boat, Harry still staring at Hagrid, trying to imagine /представить/ him flying.

‘Seems /кажется/ a shame /позор/ ter row, though,’ said Hagrid, giving /дающий/ Harry another of his sideways /вбок/ looks /выглядит/. ‘If I was ter – er – speed /скорость/ things up a bit, would yeh mind not mentionin /mentionin/’ it at Hogwarts?’

‘Of course not,’ said Harry, eager /нетерпеливый/ to see more magic. Hagrid pulled out the pink umbrella /зонтик/ again, tapped /постучал/ it twice on the side of the boat and they sped /ускоренный/ off towards land /земельные участки/.
‘Why would you be mad to try and rob /грабить/ Gringotts?’ Harry asked.

‘Spells /заклинания/ – enchantments /чары/,’ said Hagrid, unfolding /разворачивание/ his newspaper /газета/ as he spoke. ‘They say there’s dragons guardin /Guardin/’ the high-security /высокая безопасность/ vaults /своды/. And then yeh gotta /должен/ find yer way – Gringotts is hundreds of miles /миль/ under London, see. Deep under the Underground /метро/. Yeh’d /yeh'd/ die of hunger /голод/ tryin /сделаешь/’ ter get out, even if yeh did manage /управлять/ ter get yer hands on summat /summat/.’

Harry sat and thought about this while Hagrid read his news­paper, the Daily /ежедневно/ Prophet /пророк/. Harry had learnt /научился/ from Uncle Vernon that people liked to be left alone while they did this, but it was very difficult, he’d never had so many questions in his life.
‘Ministry /министерство/ o’ Magic messin /Messin/’ things up as usual,’ Hagrid muttered, turning the page /страница/.
‘There’s a Ministry /министерство/ of Magic?’ Harry asked, before he could stop himself.

‘’Course,’ said Hagrid. ‘They wanted Dumbledore fer Minister /министр/, o’ course, but he’d never leave Hogwarts, so old Cornelius /Корнелий/ Fudge /помадка/ got the job /работа/. Bungler /растяпа/ if ever there was one. So he pelts /шкурки/ Dumbledore with owls every morning, askin /спрашиваешь/’ fer advice /совет/.’
‘But what does a Ministry /министерство/ of Magic do?’
‘Well, their main /главный/ job /работа/ is to keep it from the Muggles that there’s still witches /ведьмы/ an’ wizards up an’ down the country /страна/.’
‘Why?’
‘Why? Blimey /вот это да/, Harry, everyone’d /everyone'd/ be wantin /wantin/’ magic solutions /решения/ to their problems /проблемы/. Nah /Неа/, we’re best left alone.’

At this moment the boat bumped /врезались/ gently /осторожно/ into the harbour /гавань/ wall. Hagrid folded /сложенный/ up his newspaper /газета/ and they clambered /карабкались/ up the stone steps /меры/ on to the street.

Passers-by /прохожие/ stared a lot at Hagrid as they walked through the little town /город/ to the station /станция/. Harry couldn /не мог/’t blame /вина/ them. Not only was Hagrid twice as tall as anyone else, he kept pointing at per /в/­fectly /fectly/ ordinary /обычный/ things like parking /стоянка/ meters /метры/ and saying loudly, ‘See that, Harry? Things these Muggles dream /мечта/ up, eh?’
‘Hagrid,’ said Harry, panting /задыхающийся/ a bit as he ran to keep up, ‘did you say there are dragons at Gringotts?’
‘Well, so they say,’ said Hagrid. ‘Crikey /боже мой/, I’d like a dragon.’
‘You’d like one?’
‘Wanted one ever since I was a kid /дитя/ – here we go.’

They had reached the station /станция/. There was a train to London in five minutes’ time. Hagrid, who didn /А не было/’t understand ‘Muggle money’, as he called it, gave the notes /заметки/ to Harry so he could buy their tickets /Билеты/.
People stared more than ever on the train. Hagrid took up two seats /места/ and sat knitting /Вязание/ what looked like a canary-yellow /канареечно-желтый/ /желтый/ circus /цирк/ tent /палатка/.
‘Still got yer letter, Harry?’ he asked as he counted /подсчитаны/ stitches /швы/.
Harry took the parchment /пергамент/ envelope /конверт/ out of his pocket.
‘Good,’ said Hagrid. ‘There’s a list /список/ there of everything yeh need.’
Harry unfolded /развернутый/ a second piece /кусок/ of paper he hadn’t noticed the night before and read:
Uniform /единообразный/

p.emphasis: Three sets /наборы/ of plain /гладкий/ work robes (black)
One plain /гладкий/ pointed hat (black) for day wear /носить/
One pair of protective /защитный/ gloves /перчатки/ (dragon hide /скрывать/ or similar /аналогичный/)
One winter /зима/ cloak (black, silver fastenings /крепежные детали/)
Please note that all pupils /зрачки/’ clothes /одежда/ should carry /нести/ name tags /теги/

section.p: Set Books

p.emphasis: All students should have a copy /копия/ of each of the following /следующий/:

section.p: The Standard /стандарт/ Book of Spells /заклинания/ (Grade /класс/ 1) by Miranda /Миранда/ Goshawk /ястреб-тетеревятник/
A History /история/ of Magic by Bathilda /Батильда/ Bagshot /Багшот/
Magical Theory /теория/ by Adalbert /Адальберт/ Waffling /болтовня/
A Beginner’s /для начинающих/ Guide /руководство/ to Transfiguration /видоизменение/ by Emeric /Эмерик/ Switch /переключатель/
One Thousand Magical Herbs /травы/ and Fungi /грибы/ by Phyllida /Филлида/ Spore /спор/
Magical Drafts /Черновики/ and Potions by Arsenius /Арсениус/ Jigger /джиггер/
Fantastic /фантастика/ Beasts /скот/ and Where to Find Them by Newt /тритон/ Scamander /Скамандер/
The Dark Forces /сил/: A Guide /руководство/ to Self /сам/-Protection /защита/ by Quentin /Квентин/ Trimble /Тримбл/
Other Equipment /оборудование/

p.emphasis: Students may also bring /приносить/ an owl OR a cat OR a toad
PARENTS ARE REMINDED /напомнил/ THAT FIRST-YEARS ARE NOT ALLOWED THEIR OWN BROOMSTICKS /метлы/

section.p: ‘Can we buy all this in London?’ Harry wondered aloud /вслух/.
‘If yeh know where to go,’ said Hagrid.

Harry had never been to London before. Although Hagrid seemed to know where he was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary /обычный/ way. He got stuck /застрял/ in the ticket barrier /барьер/ on the Underground /метро/ and complained /жаловался/ loudly that the seats /места/ were too small and the trains /поезда/ too slow /медленный/.

‘I don’t know how the Muggles manage /управлять/ without magic,’ he said, as they climbed a broken-down /сломанный/ escalator /эскалатор/ which led /светодиод/ up to a bustling /суетливый/ road /Дорога/ lined /подкладке/ with shops /магазины/.

Hagrid was so huge that he parted /расставался/ the crowd easily /без труда/; all Harry had to do was keep close behind him. They passed book shops /магазины/ and music /Музыка/ stores /магазины/, hamburger /гамбургер/ bars /брусья/ and cinemas /кинотеатры/, but nowhere /нигде/ that looked as if it could sell /продавать/ you a magic wand. This was just an ordi /Ordi/­nary /ни капли/ street full of ordinary /обычный/ people. Could there really be piles /геморрой/ of wizard gold buried /похороненный/ miles /миль/ beneath /под/ them? Were there really shops /магазины/ that sold /продан/ spell books and broomsticks /метлы/? Might this not all be some huge joke /шутка/ that the Dursleys had cooked /приготовленный/ up? If Harry hadn’t known that the Dursleys had no sense /смысл/ of humour /юмор/, he might have thought so; yet somehow, even though everything Hagrid had told him so far was unbelievable /невероятно/, Harry couldn /не мог/’t help trusting /доверчивый/ him.
‘This is it,’ said Hagrid, coming to a halt /стой/, ‘the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron. It’s a famous place.’

It was a tiny, grubby /неряшливый/-looking pub /паб/. If Hagrid hadn’t pointed it out, Harry wouldn /Wouldn/’t have noticed it was there. The people hurry­ing by didn /А не было/’t glance /взгляд/ at it. Their eyes slid /скользили/ from the big book shop on one side to the record /запись/ shop on the other as if they couldn /не мог/’t see the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron at all. In fact, Harry had the most peculiar /своеобразный/ feeling that only he and Hagrid could see it. Before he could mention /упомянуть/ this, Hagrid had steered /управляемый/ him inside.

For a famous place, it was very dark and shabby /потертый/. A few old women /женщины/ were sitting in a corner, drinking /питьевой/ tiny glasses of sherry /шерри/. One of them was smoking /курение/ a long pipe /труба/. A little man in a top hat was talking to the old barman /бармен/, who was quite bald /плешивый/ and looked like a gummy /смолистый/ walnut /грецкий орех/. The low buzz /жужжание/ of chatter /болтовня/ stopped when they walked in. Everyone seemed to know Hagrid; they waved /махал/ and smiled at him, and the barman /бармен/ reached for a glass, saying, ‘The usual, Hagrid?’
‘Can’t, Tom /Том/, I’m on Hogwarts business /бизнес/,’ said Hagrid, clapping /хлопающий/ his great hand on Harry’s shoulder and making Harry’s knees buckle /пряжка/.
‘Good Lord /господин/,’ said the barman /бармен/, peering /всматриваясь/ at Harry, ‘is this – can this be –?’
The Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron had suddenly gone completely /полностью/ still and silent /бесшумный/.
‘Bless /благословить/ my soul /душа/,’ whispered the old barman /бармен/. ‘Harry Potter ... what an honour /честь/.’
He hurried out from behind the bar /бар/, rushed /помчался/ towards Harry and seized his hand, tears /слезы/ in his eyes.
‘Welcome /добро пожаловать/ back, Mr Potter, welcome /добро пожаловать/ back.’

Harry didn /А не было/’t know what to say. Everyone was looking at him. The old woman with the pipe /труба/ was puffing /пыхтящий/ on it without realising /понимая/ it had gone out. Hagrid was beaming /лучезарный/.
Then there was a great scraping /выскабливание/ of chairs /стулья/ and, next moment, Harry found himself shaking hands with everyone in the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron.
‘Doris /Дорис/ Crockford /Крокфорд/, Mr Potter, can’t believe I’m meeting /встреча/ you at last.’
‘So proud /гордый/, Mr Potter, I’m just so proud /гордый/.’
‘Always wanted to shake /встряхивать/ your hand – I’m all of a flutter /флаттер/.’
‘Delighted /Обрадованный/, Mr Potter, just can’t tell you. Diggle /Диггл/’s the name, Dedalus /Дедал/ Diggle /Диггл/.’
‘I’ve seen you before!’ said Harry, as Dedalus /Дедал/ Diggle /Диггл/’s top hat fell off in his excitement /волнение/. ‘You bowed /поклонилась/ to me once in a shop.’
‘He remembers /помнит/!’ cried Dedalus /Дедал/ Diggle /Диггл/, looking around at every­one. ‘Did you hear that? He remembers /помнит/ me!’
Harry shook hands again and again – Doris /Дорис/ Crockford /Крокфорд/ kept coming back for more.
A pale young /молодой/ man made his way forward, very nervously. One of his eyes was twitching /дергающийся/.
‘Professor Quirrell!’ said Hagrid. ‘Harry, Professor Quirrell will be one of your teachers at Hogwarts.’
‘P-P-Potter /р-р-Potter/,’ stammered /запинаясь/ Professor Quirrell, grasping /захватывая/ Harry’s hand, ‘c-can’t /с-мо/ t-tell /т-сказать/ you how p-pleased /р-рад/ I am to meet you.’
‘What sort of magic do you teach /учат/, Professor Quirrell?’

‘D-Defence /d-защита/ /защита/ Against the D-D-Dark /д-д-темно/ Arts /искусства/,’ muttered Professor Quirrell, as though he’d rather not think about it. ‘N-not /н-не/ that you n-need /н-нужно/ it, eh, P-P-Potter /р-р-Potter/?’ He laughed /рассмеялся/ nervously. ‘You’ll be g-getting /г-получение/ all your equipment /оборудование/, I suppose? I’ve g-got /г-у/ to p-pick /р-драфт/ /выбирать/ up a new b-book /б-книга/ on vampires /вампиры/, m-myself /м-я/ /себя/.’ He looked terrified /ужас/ at the very thought.

But the others wouldn /Wouldn/’t let Professor Quirrell keep Harry to himself. It took almost ten minutes to get away from them all. At last, Hagrid managed to make himself heard over the babble /лепет/.
‘Must get on – lots /много/ ter buy. Come on, Harry.’

Doris /Дорис/ Crockford /Крокфорд/ shook Harry’s hand one last time and Hagrid led /светодиод/ them through the bar /бар/ and out into a small, walled /обнесенный стеной/ courtyard /двор/, where there was nothing but a dustbin /мусорный ящик/ and a few weeds /сорняки/.
Hagrid grinned /ухмыльнулась/ at Harry.
‘Told yeh, didn /А не было/’t I? Told yeh you was famous. Even Professor Quirrell was tremblin /tremblin/’ ter meet yeh – mind you, he’s usually trem /Три/­blin /блин/’.’
‘Is he always that nervous?’

‘Oh, yeah. Poor /бедные/ bloke /парень/. Brilliant /блестящий/ mind. He was fine /отлично/ while he was studyin /учиться в/’ outta /убираться/ books but then he took a year off ter get some first­hand experience /опыт/ ... They say he met vampires /вампиры/ in the Black Forest and there was a nasty bit o’ trouble with a hag /карга/ – never been the same since. Scared of the students, scared of his own subject /предмет/ – now, where’s /где/ me umbrella /зонтик/?’
Vampires /вампиры/? Hags /ведьмы/? Harry’s head was swimming /плавание/. Hagrid, mean­while, was counting /подсчет/ bricks /кирпич/ in the wall above the dustbin /мусорный ящик/.
‘Three up ... two across ...’ he muttered. ‘Right, stand back, Harry.’
He tapped /постучал/ the wall three times with the point of his umbrella /зонтик/.

The brick /кирпич/ he had touched /прикоснулся/ quivered /задрожала/ – it wriggled /извивалась/ – in the middle, a small hole appeared – it grew /вырос/ wider /Шире/ and wider /Шире/ – a second later they were facing /облицовочный/ an archway /сводчатый проход/ large enough even for Hagrid, an arch /арка/­way on to a cobbled /мощеные/ street which twisted /скрученный/ and turned out of sight.
‘Welcome /добро пожаловать/,’ said Hagrid, ‘to Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/.’

He grinned /ухмыльнулась/ at Harry’s amazement /изумление/. They stepped through the archway /сводчатый проход/. Harry looked quickly over his shoulder and saw the archway /сводчатый проход/ shrink /сокращаться/ instantly /немедленно/ back into solid /твердый/ wall.

The sun /солнце/ shone /светило/ brightly /ярко/ on a stack /стек/ of cauldrons /казаны/ outside the nearest /ближайший/ shop. Cauldrons /казаны/ – All Sizes /размеры/ – Copper /медь/, Brass /латунь/, Pewter /оловянный/, Silver – Self /сам/-Stirring – Collapsible /разборный/ said a sign hanging over them.
‘Yeah, you’ll be needin /needin/’ one,’ said Hagrid, ‘but we gotta /должен/ get yer money first.’

Harry wished /пожелал/ he had about eight /8/ more eyes. He turned his head in every direction as they walked up the street, trying to look at everything at once: the shops /магазины/, the things outside them, the people doing their shopping /поход по магазинам/. A plump /полнеть/ woman outside an apothecary’s /аптекаря/ was shaking her head as they passed, saying, ‘Dragon liver /печень/, sixteen /шестнадцать/ Sickles /серпов/ an ounce /унция/, they’re mad ...’

A low, soft /мягкий/ hooting /улюлюканье/ came from a dark shop with a sign saying Eeylops /eeylops/ Owl Emporium /торговый центр/ – Tawny /рыжевато-коричневый/, Screech /визг/, Barn /сарай/, Brown /коричневый/ and Snowy /снежно/. Several boys of about Harry’s age /возраст/ had their noses /носы/ pressed /прессованный/ against a window with broomsticks /метлы/ in it. ‘Look,’ Harry heard one of them say, ‘the new Nimbus Two Thousand – fastest /быстрый/ ever –’ There were shops /магазины/ selling /продажа/ robes, shops /магазины/ selling /продажа/ telescopes /телескопы/ and strange silver instruments /инструменты/ Harry had never seen before, windows /окна/ stacked /сложены/ with barrels /баррели/ of bat /летучая мышь/ spleens /селезенки/ and eels /угри/’ eyes, tottering /шатающийся/ piles /геморрой/ of spell books, quills /перья/ and rolls /роллы/ of parchment /пергамент/, potion /зелье/ bottles /бутылки/, globes /глобусы/ of the moon /Луна/ ...
‘Gringotts,’ said Hagrid.

They had reached a snowy /снежно/-white building /здание/ which towered /возвышались/ over the other little shops /магазины/. Standing beside /рядом/ its burnished /отполированный/ bronze /бронза/ doors, wearing a uniform /единообразный/ of scarlet /алый/ and gold, was –

‘Yeah, that’s a goblin /гоблин/,’ said Hagrid quietly as they walked up the white stone steps /меры/ towards him. The goblin /гоблин/ was about a head shorter /короче/ than Harry. He had a swarthy /смуглый/, clever /умная/ face, a pointed beard and, Harry noticed, very long fingers and feet. He bowed /поклонилась/ as they walked inside. Now they were facing /облицовочный/ a second pair of doors, silver this time, with words engraved /выгравирован/ upon /на/ them:

p.emphasis: Of what awaits /Ждет/ the sin /грех/ of greed /жадность/,
For those who take, but do not earn /зарабатывать/,
Must pay /платить/ most dearly /дорого/ in their turn,
So if you seek /искать/ beneath /под/ our floors /этажей/
A treasure /сокровище/ that was never yours /ваш/,
Thief /вор/, you have been warned /предупреждала/, beware /остерегаться/
Of finding /обнаружение/ more than treasure /сокровище/ there.

section.p: ‘Like I said, yeh’d /yeh'd/ be mad ter try an’ rob /грабить/ it,’ said Hagrid.

A pair of goblins /гоблины/ bowed /поклонилась/ them through the silver doors and they were in a vast /огромный/ marble /мрамор/ hall. About a hundred more goblins /гоблины/ were sitting on high stools /испражнения/ behind a long counter /счетчик/, scribbling /строчить/ in large ledgers /гроссбухи/, weighing /взвешивание/ coins /монеты/ on brass /латунь/ scales /Весы/, examining /изучения/ precious /драгоценный/ stones /камни/ through eyeglasses /очки/. There were too many doors to count /подсчитывать/ leading /ведущий/ off the hall, and yet more goblins /гоблины/ were showing /показ/ people in and out of these. Hagrid and Harry made for the counter /счетчик/.
‘Morning,’ said Hagrid to a free goblin /гоблин/. ‘We’ve come ter take some money outta /убираться/ Mr Harry Potter’s /гончарное/ safe.’
‘You have his key, sir?’

‘Got it here somewhere,’ said Hagrid and he started emptying /опорожнение/ his pockets /карманы/ on to the counter /счетчик/, scattering /рассеяние/ a handful /горсть/ of mouldy /заплесневелый/ dog-biscuits /собачьи бисквиты/ over the goblin /гоблин/’s book of numbers /чисел/. The goblin /гоблин/ wrinkled /сморщенный/ his nose. Harry watched the goblin /гоблин/ on their right weighing /взвешивание/ a pile of rubies /рубины/ as big as glowing /пылающий/ coals /угли/.
‘Got it,’ said Hagrid at last, holding up a tiny golden /золотой/ key.
The goblin /гоблин/ looked at it closely /тесно/.
‘That seems /кажется/ to be in order /заказ/.’

‘An’ I’ve also got a letter here from Professor Dumbledore,’ said Hagrid importantly /важно/, throwing /бросание/ out his chest /грудь/. ‘It’s about the You-Know /вы знаете/-What /знаешь что/ in vault /свод/ seven hundred and thirteen /13/.’
The goblin /гоблин/ read the letter carefully.
‘Very well,’ he said, handing /вручая/ it back to Hagrid, ‘I will have someone take you down to both vaults /своды/. Griphook!’

Griphook was yet another goblin /гоблин/. Once Hagrid had crammed /забита/ all the dog-biscuits /собачьи бисквиты/ back inside his pockets /карманы/, he and Harry fol /Fol/­lowed /мычала/ Griphook towards one of the doors leading /ведущий/ off the hall.
‘What’s the You-Know /вы знаете/-What /знаешь что/ in vault /свод/ seven hundred and thir /thir/­teen /подросток/?’ Harry asked.

‘Can’t tell yeh that,’ said Hagrid mysteriously /таинственно/. ‘Very secret. Hogwarts business /бизнес/. Dumbledore’s trusted /доверенный/ me. More’n /more'n/ my job /работа/’s worth /стоимость/ ter tell yeh that.’

Griphook held the door open for them. Harry, who had expected more marble /мрамор/, was surprised /удивленный/. They were in a narrow /узкий/ stone passage /прохождение/­way lit /освещенный/ with flaming /пламенный/ torches /факелы/. It sloped /скошенный/ steeply /круто/ downwards /вниз/ and there were little railway /Железнодорожный/ tracks /треков/ on the floor. Griphook whistled /свистнул/ and a small cart /телега/ came hurtling /мчится/ up the tracks /треков/ towards them. They climbed in – Hagrid with some difficulty /трудность/ – and were off.

At first they just hurtled /понесся/ through a maze /лабиринт/ of twisting /скручивание/ passages /пассажи/. Harry tried to remember, left, right, right, left, middle fork /вилка/, right, left, but it was impossible /невозможно/. The rattling /грохочущий/ cart /телега/ seemed to know its own way, because Griphook wasn /WASN/’t steering /рулевое управление/.

Harry’s eyes stung /ужалила/ as the cold air rushed /помчался/ past them, but he kept them wide open. Once, he thought he saw a burst of fire at the end of a passage /прохождение/ and twisted /скрученный/ around to see if it was a dragon, but too late – they plunged /погрузилась/ even deeper /Глубже/, passing /прохождение/ an underground /метро/ lake /озеро/ where huge stalactites /сталактиты/ and stalagmites /сталагмиты/ grew /вырос/ from the ceiling and floor.
‘I never know,’ Harry called to Hagrid over the noise of the cart /телега/, ‘what’s the difference /разница/ between a stalagmite /сталагмит/ and a stalactite /сталактит/?’
‘Stalagmite /сталагмит/’s /сталагмитов-х/ got an “m” in it,’ said Hagrid. ‘An’ don’ ask me questions just now, I think I’m gonna /собирается/ be sick /больной/.’

He did look very green and when the cart /телега/ stopped at last beside /рядом/ a small door in the passage /прохождение/ wall, Hagrid got out and had to lean /опираться/ against the wall to stop his knees trembling /дрожь/.

Griphook unlocked /разблокирована/ the door. A lot of green smoke /дым/ came bil /миллиарду/­lowing /мычание/ out, and as it cleared /очищается/, Harry gasped. Inside were mounds /курганы/ of gold coins /монеты/. Columns /столбцы/ of silver. Heaps /отвалы/ of little bronze /бронза/ Knuts /Knuts/.
‘All yours /ваш/,’ smiled Hagrid.

All Harry’s – it was incredible /неимоверный/. The Dursleys couldn /не мог/’t have known about this or they’d have had it from him faster /Быстрее/ than blinking /моргание/. How often /довольно часто/ had they complained /жаловался/ how much Harry cost /Стоимость/ them to keep? And all the time there had been a small fortune /состояние/ belonging /принадлежащий/ to him, buried /похороненный/ deep under London.
Hagrid helped /помог/ Harry pile some of it into a bag /мешок/.

‘The gold ones are Galleons /галеонов/,’ he explained /объяснил/. ‘Seventeen /семнадцать/ silver Sickles /серпов/ to a Galleon /галеон/ and twenty /20/-nine Knuts /Knuts/ to a Sickle /серп/, it’s easy enough. Right, that should be enough fer a couple /пара/ o’ terms /сроки/, we’ll keep the rest safe for yeh.’ He turned to Griphook. ‘Vault /свод/ seven hundred and thirteen /13/ now, please, and can we go more slowly?’
‘One speed /скорость/ only,’ said Griphook.

They were going even deeper /Глубже/ now and gathering /сбор/ speed /скорость/. The air became colder /холоднее/ and colder /холоднее/ as they hurtled /понесся/ round tight /в обтяжку/ corners /углы/. They went rattling /грохочущий/ over an underground /метро/ ravine /овраг/ and Harry leant over the side to try and see what was down at the dark bottom /дно/ but Hagrid groaned /простонал/ and pulled him back by the scruff /загривок/ of his neck.
Vault /свод/ seven hundred and thirteen /13/ had no keyhole /замочная скважина/.
‘Stand back,’ said Griphook importantly /важно/. He stroked /гладить/ the door gently /осторожно/ with one of his long fingers and it simply /просто/ melted /плавленый/ away.
‘If anyone but a Gringotts goblin /гоблин/ tried that, they’d be sucked /высосанный/ through the door and trapped /ловушке/ in there,’ said Griphook.
‘How often /довольно часто/ do you check /проверить/ to see if anyone’s /кто это/ inside?’ Harry asked.
‘About once every ten years,’ said Griphook, with a rather nasty grin /усмешка/.

Something really extraordinary /необычайный/ had to be inside this top-security /топ-безопасности/ vault /свод/, Harry was sure, and he leant forward eagerly /с нетерпением/, expecting /ожидая/ to see fabulous /невероятный/ jewels /ювелирные изделия/ at the very least – but at first he thought it was empty. Then he noticed a grubby /неряшливый/ little package wrapped /завернутый/ up in brown /коричневый/ paper lying on the floor. Hagrid picked it up and tucked /заправленные/ it deep inside his coat /Пальто/. Harry longed /жаждал/ to know what it was, but knew better than to ask.
‘Come on, back in this infernal /адский/ cart /телега/, and don’t talk to me on the way back, it’s best if I keep me mouth shut,’ said Hagrid.

One wild cart /телега/-ride /поездка/ later they stood blinking /моргание/ in the sunlight /Солнечный лучик/ out­side Gringotts. Harry didn /А не было/’t know where to run first now that he had a bag /мешок/ full of money. He didn /А не было/’t have to know how many Galleons /галеонов/ there were to a pound /фунт/ to know that he was holding more money than he’d had in his whole life – more money than even Dudley had ever had.

‘Might as well get yer uniform /единообразный/,’ said Hagrid, nodding /кивание/ towards Madam Malkin /Малкина/’s /Малкин/ Robes for All Occasions /случаи/. ‘Listen, Harry would yeh mind if I slipped /проскользнул/ off fer a pick /выбирать/-me-up in the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron? I hate /ненавидеть/ them Gringotts carts /тележки/.’ He did still look a bit sick /больной/, so Harry entered /вошел/ Madam Malkin /Малкина/’s /Малкин/ shop alone, feeling nervous.
Madam Malkin /Малкина/ was a squat /приземистый/, smiling witch dressed /заправленный/ all in mauve /розовато-лиловый/.
‘Hogwarts, dear?’ she said, when Harry started to speak. ‘Got the lot here – another young /молодой/ man being fitted /установлены/ up just now, in fact.’

In the back of the shop, a boy with a pale, pointed face was standing on a footstool /скамеечка для ног/ while a second witch pinned /приколол/ up his long black robes. Madam Malkin /Малкина/ stood Harry on a stool /стул/ next to him, slipped /проскользнул/ a long robe /халат/ over his head and began to pin /штырь/ it to the right length /длина/.
‘Hullo /алло/,’ said the boy, ‘Hogwarts too?’
‘Yes,’ said Harry.

‘My father’s /отец/ next door buying /покупка/ my books and mother’s /мамин/ up the street looking at wands,’ said the boy. He had a bored /скучающий/, drawling /протяжные/ voice. ‘Then I’m going to drag /бремя/ them off to look at racing brooms. I don’t see why first-years can’t have their own. I think I’ll bully /задира/ father into getting me one and I’ll smuggle /провозить/ it in somehow.’
Harry was strongly /сильно/ reminded /напомнил/ of Dudley.
‘Have you got your own broom?’ the boy went on.
‘No,’ said Harry.
‘Play Quidditch at all?’
‘No,’ Harry said again, wondering /интересно/ what on earth /Земля/ Quidditch could be.
‘I do – Father says it’s a crime /преступление/ if I’m not picked to play for my house, and I must say, I agree /дать согласие/. Know what house you’ll be in yet?’
‘No,’ said Harry, feeling more stupid by the minute.

‘Well, no one really knows until they get there, do they, but I know I’ll be in Slytherin, all our family have been – imagine /представить/ being in Hufflepuff, I think I’d leave, wouldn /Wouldn/’t you?’
‘Mmm /ммм/,’ said Harry, wishing /желающих/ he could say something a bit more interesting /интересно/.

‘I say, look at that man!’ said the boy suddenly, nodding /кивание/ towards the front window. Hagrid was standing there, grinning /ухмыляющийся/ at Harry and pointing at two large ice /лед/-creams to show he couldn /не мог/’t come in.
‘That’s Hagrid,’ said Harry, pleased to know something the boy didn /А не было/’t. ‘He works /работает/ at Hogwarts.’
‘Oh,’ said the boy, ‘I’ve heard of him. He’s a sort of servant /служащий/, isn’t he?’
‘He’s the gamekeeper /егерь/,’ said Harry. He was liking /симпатия/ the boy less /Меньше/ and less /Меньше/ every second.

‘Yes, exactly. I heard he’s a sort of savage /дикарь/ – lives /жизни/ in a hut in the school grounds and every now and then he gets /получает/ drunk /пьяный/, tries /пытается/ to do magic and ends /концы/ up setting /установка/ fire to his bed.’
‘I think he’s brilliant /блестящий/,’ said Harry coldly /холодно/.
‘Do you?’ said the boy, with a slight /незначительный/ sneer /насмешка/. ‘Why is he with you? Where are your parents?’
‘They’re dead,’ said Harry shortly /вскоре/. He didn /А не было/’t feel much like going into the matter with this boy.
‘Oh, sorry,’ said the other, not sounding /звучащий/ sorry at all. ‘But they were our kind /своего рода/, weren’t they?’
‘They were a witch and wizard, if that’s what you mean.’

‘I really don’t think they should let the other sort in, do you? They’re just not the same, they’ve /они имеют/ never been brought up to know our ways /пути/. Some of them have never even heard of Hogwarts until they get the letter, imagine /представить/. I think they should keep it in the old wizarding /волшебников/ families. What’s your surname /фамилия/, anyway?’

But before Harry could answer, Madam Malkin /Малкина/ said, ‘That’s you done, my dear,’ and Harry, not sorry for an excuse /оправдание/ to stop talking to the boy, hopped /прыгал/ down from the footstool /скамеечка для ног/.
‘Well, I’ll see you at Hogwarts, I suppose,’ said the drawling /протяжные/ boy.
Harry was rather quiet as he ate /ел/ the ice /лед/-cream Hagrid had bought /купил/ him (chocolate and raspberry /малина/ with chopped /рубленый/ nuts /орешки/).
‘What’s up?’ said Hagrid.
