‘Nothing,’ Harry lied /солгал/. They stopped to buy parchment /пергамент/ and quills /перья/. Harry cheered /повеселел/ up a bit when he found a bottle of ink /чернила/ that changed colour /цвет/ as you wrote /писал/. When they had left the shop, he said, ‘Hagrid, what’s Quidditch?’
‘Blimey /вот это да/, Harry, I keep forgettin /forgettin/’ how little yeh know – not knowin /узнав о том,/’ about Quidditch!’
‘Don’t make me feel worse,’ said Harry. He told Hagrid about the pale boy in Madam Malkin /Малкина/’s /Малкин/.
‘– and he said people from Muggle families shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ even be allowed in –’

‘Yer not from a Muggle family. If he’d known who yeh were – he’s grown /взрослый/ up knowin /узнав о том,/’ yer name if his parents are wizardin /wizardin/’ folk /люди/ – you saw ’em in the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron. Anyway, what does he know about it, some o’ the best I ever saw were the only ones with magic in ’em in a long line o’ Muggles – look at yer mum! Look what she had fer a sister!’
‘So what is Quidditch?’

‘It’s our sport /спорт/. Wizard sport /спорт/. It’s like – like football /футбол/ in the Muggle world – everyone follows /следует/ Quidditch – played /играл/ up in the air on broomsticks /метлы/ and there’s four balls /мячи/ – sorta /Сорта/ hard ter explain the rules /правила/.’
‘And what are Slytherin and Hufflepuff?’
‘School houses /дома/. There’s four. Everyone says Hufflepuff are a lot o’ duffers /duffers/, but –’
‘I bet I’m in Hufflepuff,’ said Harry gloomily /угрюмо/.
‘Better Hufflepuff than Slytherin,’ said Hagrid darkly /загадочно/. ‘There’s not a single /Один/ witch or wizard who went bad who wasn /WASN/’t in Slytherin. You-Know /вы знаете/-Who was one.’
‘Vol /об/— sorry – You-Know /вы знаете/-Who was at Hogwarts?’
‘Years an’ years ago,’ said Hagrid.

They bought /купил/ Harry’s school books in a shop called Flourish /процветать/ and Blotts /Блоттс/ where the shelves /полки/ were stacked /сложены/ to the ceiling with books as large as paving /мощение/ stones /камни/ bound /связанный/ in leather /кожа/; books the size /размер/ of postage /почтовые расходы/ stamps /Марки/ in covers /крышки/ of silk /шелк/; books full of peculiar /своеобразный/ symbols /символы/ and a few books with nothing in them at all. Even Dudley, who never read anything, would have been wild to get his hands on some of these. Hagrid almost had to drag /бремя/ Harry away from Curses /проклятий/ and Counter /счетчик/-Curses /проклятий/ (Bewitch /восхищать/ your Friends and Befuddle /одурманивать/ your Enemies /враги/ with the Latest /последний/ Revenges /мстит/: Hair Loss /потеря/, Jelly /желе/-Legs /желе-ноги/, Tongue /язык/-Tying and much, much more) by Professor Vindictus /Vindictus/ Viridian /Виридийский/.
‘I was trying to find out how to curse /проклятие/ Dudley.’

‘I’m not sayin /говорю/’ that’s not a good idea, but yer not ter use magic in the Muggle world except in very special /особый/ circumstances /обстоятельства/,’ said Hagrid. ‘An’ anyway, yeh couldn /не мог/’ work any of them curses /проклятий/ yet, yeh’ll /yeh'll/ need a lot more study /изучение/ before yeh get ter that level /уровень/.’

Hagrid wouldn /Wouldn/’t let Harry buy a solid /твердый/ gold cauldron, either (‘It says pewter /оловянный/ on yer list /список/’), but they got a nice set of scales /Весы/ for weighing /взвешивание/ potion /зелье/ ingredients /ингредиенты/ and a collapsible /разборный/ brass /латунь/ telescope /телескоп/. Then they visited /посетил/ the apothecary’s /аптекаря/, which was fascinating /очаровательный/ enough to make up for its horrible smell, a mixture /смесь/ of bad eggs /яйца/ and rotted /сгнили/ cabbages /капуста/. Barrels /баррели/ of slimy /слизистый/ stuff stood on the floor, jars /банки/ of herbs /травы/, dried /высушенный/ roots /корнеплоды/ and bright powders /порошки/ lined /подкладке/ the walls, bundles /пучки/ of feath /feath/­ers /ERS/, strings /строки/ of fangs /клыки/ and snarled /прорычал/ claws /когти/ hung from the ceiling. While Hagrid asked the man behind the counter /счетчик/ for a supply /поставка/ of some basic /основной/ potion /зелье/ ingredients /ингредиенты/ for Harry, Harry himself examined /рассмотрел/ silver unicorn horns /рога/ at twenty /20/-one Galleons /галеонов/ each and minuscule /минускул/, glittery /блестящем/ black beetle /жук/ eyes (five Knuts /Knuts/ a scoop /совок/).
Outside the apothecary’s /аптекаря/, Hagrid checked /проверено/ Harry’s list /список/ again.
‘Just yer wand left – oh yeah, an’ I still haven’t got yeh a birth /рождение/­day present /настоящее время/.’
Harry felt himself go red.
‘You don’t have to –’

‘I know I don’t have to. Tell yeh what, I’ll get yer animal /животное/. Not a toad, toads /жабы/ went outta /убираться/ fashion /мода/ years ago, yeh’d /yeh'd/ be laughed /рассмеялся/ at – an’ I don’ like cats /коты/, they make me sneeze /чихать/. I’ll get yer an owl. All the kids /Дети/ want owls, they’re dead useful /полезным/, carry /нести/ yer post an’ everythin /everythin/’.’

Twenty /20/ minutes later, they left Eeylops /eeylops/ Owl Emporium /торговый центр/, which had been dark and full of rustling /шуршащий/ and flickering /мерцающий/, jewel-bright /драгоценный камень яркий/ eyes. Harry now carried /осуществляется/ a large cage /клетка/ which held a beautiful /красивая/ snowy /снежно/ owl, fast asleep with her head under her wing /крыло/. He couldn /не мог/’t stop stammering /заикание/ his thanks, sounding /звучащий/ just like Professor Quirrell.

‘Don’ mention /упомянуть/ it,’ said Hagrid gruffly /хрипло/. ‘Don’ expect you’ve had a lotta /Лотта/ presents /подарки/ from them Dursleys. Just Ollivanders /ollivanders/ left now – only place fer wands, Ollivanders /ollivanders/, and yeh gotta /должен/ have the best wand.’
A magic wand ... this was what Harry had been really looking forward to.

The last shop was narrow /узкий/ and shabby /потертый/. Peeling /шелушение/ gold letters over the door read Ollivanders /ollivanders/: Makers /производители/ of Fine /отлично/ Wands since 382 bc /До нашей эры/. A single /Один/ wand lay on a faded /утрачен/ purple cushion /диванная подушка/ in the dusty /пыльный/ window.

A tinkling /звенящий/ bell /колокол/ rang /звенел/ somewhere in the depths /глубины/ of the shop as they stepped inside. It was a tiny place, empty except for a single /Один/ spindly /веретенообразный/ chair /стул/ which Hagrid sat on to wait. Harry felt strangely /странно/ as though he had entered /вошел/ a very strict /строгий/ library; he swallowed /проглатывании/ a lot of new questions which had just occurred /произошло/ to him and looked instead at the thousands /тысячи/ of narrow /узкий/ boxes /ящики/ piled /сложено/ neatly /аккуратно/ right up to the ceiling. For some reason, the back of his neck prickled /защипало/. The very dust /пыли/ and silence in here seemed to tingle /покалывание/ with some secret magic.

‘Good afternoon,’ said a soft /мягкий/ voice. Harry jumped. Hagrid must have jumped, too, because there was a loud crunching /хруст/ noise and he got quickly off the spindly /веретенообразный/ chair /стул/.
An old man was standing before them, his wide, pale eyes shining /блестящий/ like moons /спутники/ through the gloom /мрачность/ of the shop.
‘Hello /Здравствуйте/,’ said Harry awkwardly /нескладно/.

‘Ah yes,’ said the man. ‘Yes, yes. I thought I’d be seeing /видя/ you soon. Harry Potter.’ It wasn /WASN/’t a question /вопрос/. ‘You have your mother’s /мамин/ eyes. It seems /кажется/ only yesterday /вчера/ she was in here herself /сама/, buying /покупка/ her first wand. Ten and a quarter /четверть/ inches long, swishy /swishy/, made of willow /ива/. Nice wand for charm /очарование/ work.’
Mr Ollivander moved closer to Harry. Harry wished /пожелал/ he would blink /мерцать/. Those silvery /серебристый/ eyes were a bit creepy /жутко/.

‘Your father, on the other hand, favoured /благоприятствования/ a mahogany /красное дерево/ wand. Eleven inches. Pliable /гибкий/. A little more power and excellent /отлично/ for trans /транс/­figuration /орнаментация/. Well, I say your father favoured /благоприятствования/ it – it’s really the wand that chooses /выбирает/ the wizard, of course.’
Mr Ollivander had come so close that he and Harry were almost nose to nose. Harry could see himself reflected /отраженный/ in those misty /туманный/ eyes.
‘And that’s where ...’
Mr Ollivander touched /прикоснулся/ the lightning /молния/ scar on Harry’s forehead with a long, white finger /Палец/.

‘I’m sorry to say I sold /продан/ the wand that did it,’ he said softly /мягко/. ‘Thirteen /13/ and a half inches. Yew /тис/. Powerful /мощный/ wand, very powerful /мощный/, and in the wrong hands ... Well, if I’d known what that wand was going out into the world to do ...’
He shook his head and then, to Harry’s relief /облегчение/, spotted Hagrid.
‘Rubeus /Rubeus/! Rubeus /Rubeus/ Hagrid! How nice to see you again ... Oak /дуб/, sixteen /шестнадцать/ inches, rather bendy /Бенди/, wasn /WASN/’t it?’
‘It was, sir, yes,’ said Hagrid.
‘Good wand, that one. But I suppose they snapped it in half when you got expelled?’ said Mr Ollivander, suddenly stern /кормовой/.
‘Er – yes, they did, yes,’ said Hagrid, shuffling /шарканье/ his feet. ‘I’ve still got the pieces /куски/, though,’ he added brightly /ярко/.
‘But you don’t use them?’ said Mr Ollivander sharply /резко/.
‘Oh, no, sir,’ said Hagrid quickly. Harry noticed he gripped /захватывается/ his pink umbrella /зонтик/ very tightly /плотно/ as he spoke.

‘Hmmm /хммм/,’ said Mr Ollivander, giving /дающий/ Hagrid a piercing /пронзительный/ look. ‘Well, now – Mr Potter. Let me see.’ He pulled a long tape /лента/ measure /измерение/ with silver markings /маркировка/ out of his pocket. ‘Which is your wand arm?’
‘Er – well, I’m right-handed /правосторонний/ /руками/,’ said Harry.

‘Hold out your arm. That’s it.’ He measured /измеренный/ Harry from shoul /Shoul/­der /дер/ to finger /Палец/, then wrist /запястье/ to elbow /локоть/, shoulder to floor, knee /колено/ to armpit /подмышка/ and round his head. As he measured /измеренный/, he said, ‘Every Ollivander wand has a core /ядро/ of a powerful /мощный/ magical substance /вещество/, Mr Potter. We use unicorn hairs /волосы/, phoenix /Феникс/ tail feathers /перья/ and the heartstrings /глубочайшие чувства/ of dragons. No two Ollivander wands are the same, just as no two unicorns /единороги/, dragons or phoenixes /фениксов/ are quite the same. And of course, you will never get such good results /Результаты/ with another wizard’s /мастера/ wand.’

Harry suddenly realised that the tape /лента/ measure /измерение/, which was meas /тез/­uring /тор/ between his nostrils /ноздри/, was doing this on its own. Mr Ollivander was flitting /порхают/ around the shelves /полки/, taking down boxes /ящики/.

‘That will do,’ he said, and the tape /лента/ measure /измерение/ crumpled /мятый/ into a heap /куча/ on the floor. ‘Right then, Mr Potter. Try this one. Beechwood /букового/ and dragon heartstring /Струны души/. Nine inches. Nice and flexible /гибкий/. Just take it and give it a wave /волна/.’
Harry took the wand and (feeling foolish /глупый/) waved /махал/ it around a bit, but Mr Ollivander snatched /выхватила/ it out of his hand almost at once.
‘Maple /кленовый/ and phoenix /Феникс/ feather /перо/. Seven inches. Quite whippy /гибкий/. Try –’
Harry tried – but he had hardly raised the wand when it, too, was snatched /выхватила/ back by Mr Ollivander.
‘No, no – here, ebony /черное дерево/ and unicorn hair, eight /8/ and a half inches, springy /упругий/. Go on, go on, try it out.’

Harry tried. And tried. He had no idea what Mr Ollivander was waiting for. The pile of tried wands was mounting /монтаж/ higher /выше/ and higher /выше/ on the spindly /веретенообразный/ chair /стул/, but the more wands Mr Ollivander pulled from the shelves /полки/, the happier /счастливее/ he seemed to become /стали/.

‘Tricky /запутанный/ customer /клиент/, eh? Not to worry, we’ll find the perfect /идеально/ match here somewhere – I wonder, now – yes, why not – unusual /необычный/ combi /комби/­nation /нация/ – holly /падуб/ and phoenix /Феникс/ feather /перо/, eleven inches, nice and supple /податливый/.’

Harry took the wand. He felt a sudden warmth /тепло/ in his fingers. He raised the wand above his head, brought it swishing /свистящий/ down through the dusty /пыльный/ air and a stream /поток/ of red and gold sparks /искры/ shot from the end like a firework /салют/, throwing /бросание/ dancing /танцы/ spots /пятна/ of light on to the walls. Hagrid whooped /гикнул/ and clapped and Mr Ollivander cried, ‘Oh, bravo /Браво/! Yes, indeed /в самом деле/, oh, very good. Well, well, well ... how curious /любопытный/ ... how very curious /любопытный/ ...’
He put Harry’s wand back into its box and wrapped /завернутый/ it in brown /коричневый/ paper, still muttering /бормотание/, ‘Curious /любопытный/ ... curious /любопытный/ ...’
‘Sorry,’ said Harry, ‘but what’s curious /любопытный/?’
Mr Ollivander fixed /исправлено/ Harry with his pale stare /глазеть/.

‘I remember every wand I’ve ever sold /продан/, Mr Potter. Every single /Один/ wand. It so happens /происходит/ that the phoenix /Феникс/ whose /чья/ tail feather /перо/ is in your wand, gave another feather /перо/ – just one other. It is very curious /любопытный/ indeed /в самом деле/ that you should be destined /предназначенный/ for this wand when its brother /брат/ – why, its brother /брат/ gave you that scar.’
Harry swallowed /проглатывании/.

‘Yes, thirteen /13/ and a half inches. Yew /тис/. Curious /любопытный/ indeed /в самом деле/ how these things happen /случаться/. The wand chooses /выбирает/ the wizard, remember ... I think we must expect great things from you, Mr Potter ... After all, He Who Must Not Be Named /названный/ did great things – terrible, yes, but great.’

Harry shivered /задрожала/. He wasn /WASN/’t sure he liked Mr Ollivander too much. He paid /оплаченный/ seven gold Galleons /галеонов/ for his wand and Mr Ollivander bowed /поклонилась/ them from his shop.

The late-afternoon /Поздний вечер/ sun /солнце/ hung low in the sky as Harry and Hagrid made their way back down Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/, back through the wall, back through the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron, now empty. Harry didn /А не было/’t speak at all as they walked down the road /Дорога/; he didn /А не было/’t even notice /уведомление/ how much people were gawping /gawping/ at them on the Underground /метро/, laden /нагруженный/ as they were with all their funny-shaped /смешно-образный/ /фасонный/ packages /пакеты/, with the sleeping /спать/ snowy /снежно/ owl on Harry’s lap /круг/. Up another escalator /эскалатор/, out into Paddington /Паддингтон/ station /станция/; Harry only realised where they were when Hagrid tapped /постучал/ him on the shoulder.
‘Got time fer a bite /укусить/ to eat /есть/ before yer train leaves,’ he said.
He bought /купил/ Harry a hamburger /гамбургер/ and they sat down on plastic /пластик/ seats /места/ to eat /есть/ them. Harry kept looking around. Everything looked so strange, somehow.
‘You all right, Harry? Yer very quiet,’ said Hagrid.
Harry wasn /WASN/’t sure he could explain. He’d just had the best birthday of his life – and yet – he chewed /пожевал/ his hamburger /гамбургер/, trying to find the words.

‘Everyone thinks /думает/ I’m special /особый/,’ he said at last. ‘All those people in the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron, Professor Quirrell, Mr Ollivander ... but I don’t know anything about magic at all. How can they expect great things? I’m famous and I can’t even remember what I’m famous for. I don’t know what happened when Vol /об/— sorry – I mean, the night my parents died.’
Hagrid leant across the table. Behind the wild beard and eye­brows /брови/ he wore /носил/ a very kind /своего рода/ smile.

‘Don’ you worry, Harry. You’ll learn fast enough. Everyone starts /начинается/ at the beginning /начало/ at Hogwarts, you’ll be just fine /отлично/. Just be yerself /yerself/. I know it’s hard. Yeh’ve /yeh've/ been singled /выделены/ out, an’ that’s always hard. But yeh’ll /yeh'll/ have a great time at Hogwarts – I did – still do, ’smatter /быть дилетантом/ of fact.’
Hagrid helped /помог/ Harry on to the train that would take him back to the Dursleys, then handed /руками/ him an envelope /конверт/.

‘Yer ticket fer Hogwarts,’ he said. ‘First o’ September /сентябрь/ – King /король/’s /королевский/ Cross /пересекать/ – it’s all on yer ticket. Any problems /проблемы/ with the Dursleys, send me a letter with yer owl, she’ll /оболочка/ know where to find me ... See yeh soon, Harry.’

The train pulled out of the station /станция/. Harry wanted to watch Hagrid until he was out of sight; he rose in his seat and pressed /прессованный/ his nose against the window, but he blinked /моргнула/ and Hagrid had gone.

p.emphasis: The Journey /поездка/ from Platform Nine and Three-Quarters /три четверти/

section.p: Harry’s last month /месяц/ with the Dursleys wasn /WASN/’t fun /весело/. True, Dudley was now so scared of Harry he wouldn /Wouldn/’t stay in the same room, while Aunt Petunia and Uncle Vernon didn /А не было/’t shut Harry in his cupboard, force /сила/ him to do anything or shout /окрик/ at him – in fact, they didn /А не было/’t speak to him at all. Half-terrified /наполовину напуган/ /ужас/, half-furious /наполовину в ярости/ /яростный/, they acted /действовал/ as though any chair /стул/ with Harry in it was empty. Although this was an improvement /улучшение/ in many ways /пути/, it did become /стали/ a bit depressing /унылый/ after a while.

Harry kept to his room, with his new owl for company /Компания/. He had decided to call her Hedwig, a name he had found in A History /история/ of Magic. His school books were very interesting /интересно/. He lay on his bed reading /чтение/ late into the night, Hedwig swooping /парящий/ in and out of the open window as she pleased. It was lucky that Aunt Petunia didn /А не было/’t come in to hoover /пылесос/ any more, because Hedwig kept bringing /приведение/ back dead mice /мышей/. Every night before he went to sleep, Harry ticked /тикали/ off another day on the piece /кусок/ of paper he had pinned /приколол/ to the wall, counting /подсчет/ down to September /сентябрь/ the first.

On the last day of August /августейший/ he thought he’d better speak to his aunt and uncle about getting to King /король/’s /королевский/ Cross /пересекать/ station /станция/ next day, so he went down to the living /живой/-room /гостиная/, where they were watching a quiz /викторина/ show on television /телевидение/. He cleared /очищается/ his throat /горло/ to let them know he was there, and Dudley screamed and ran from the room.
‘Er – Uncle Vernon?’
Uncle Vernon grunted /хрюкнул/ to show he was listening.
‘Er – I need to be at King /король/’s /королевский/ Cross /пересекать/ tomorrow /завтра/ to – to go to Hogwarts.’
Uncle Vernon grunted /хрюкнул/ again.
‘Would it be all right if you gave me a lift /лифт/?’
Grunt /хрюкать/. Harry supposed that meant /имел ввиду/ yes.
‘Thank /спасибо/ you.’
He was about to go back upstairs when Uncle Vernon actually /на самом деле/ spoke.
‘Funny way to get to a wizards’ school, the train. Magic carpets /ковры/ all got punctures /проколы/, have they?’
Harry didn /А не было/’t say anything.
‘Where is this school, anyway?’
‘I don’t know,’ said Harry, realising /понимая/ this for the first time. He pulled the ticket Hagrid had given him out of his pocket.
‘I just take the train from platform nine and three-quarters /три четверти/ at eleven o’clock /Часы/,’ he read.
His aunt and uncle stared.
‘Platform what?’
‘Nine and three-quarters /три четверти/.’
‘Don’t talk rubbish /мусор/,’ said Uncle Vernon, ‘there is no platform nine and three-quarters /три четверти/.’
‘It’s on my ticket.’

‘Barking /лай/,’ said Uncle Vernon, ‘howling /воющий/ mad, the lot of them. You’ll see. You just wait. All right, we’ll take you to King /король/’s /королевский/ Cross /пересекать/. We’re going up to London tomorrow /завтра/ anyway, or I wouldn /Wouldn/’t bother /беспокоить/.’
‘Why are you going to London?’ Harry asked, trying to keep things friendly /дружелюбный/.
‘Taking Dudley to hospital /больница/,’ growled /прорычал/ Uncle Vernon. ‘Got to have that ruddy /румяный/ tail removed /удален/ before he goes to Smeltings.’

Harry woke /просыпался/ at five o’clock /Часы/ the next morning and was too excited /в восторге/ and nervous to go back to sleep. He got up and pulled on his jeans /джинсы/ because he didn /А не было/’t want to walk into the station /станция/ in his wiz /волшебник/­ard /Ард/’s /Ард-х/ robes – he’d change /изменение/ on the train. He checked /проверено/ his Hogwarts list /список/ yet again to make sure he had everything he needed /необходимый/, saw that Hedwig was shut safely /безопасно/ in her cage /клетка/ and then paced /шагают/ the room, waiting for the Dursleys to get up. Two hours /часов/ later, Harry’s huge, heavy trunk /хобот/ had been loaded /нагруженный/ into the Dursleys’ car, Aunt Petunia had talked /говорили/ Dudley into sitting next to Harry and they had set off.

They reached King /король/’s /королевский/ Cross /пересекать/ at half past ten. Uncle Vernon dumped /сбрасывали/ Harry’s trunk /хобот/ on to a trolley /тележка/ and wheeled /колесный/ it into the sta /станция/­tion /Тион/ for him. Harry thought this was strangely /странно/ kind /своего рода/ until Uncle Vernon stopped dead, facing /облицовочный/ the platforms /платформы/ with a nasty grin /усмешка/ on his face.
‘Well, there you are, boy. Platform nine – platform ten. Your platform should be somewhere in the middle, but they don’t seem to have built /построен/ it yet, do they?’
He was quite right, of course. There was a big plastic /пластик/ number nine over one platform and a big plastic /пластик/ number ten over the one next to it, and in the middle, nothing at all.

‘Have a good term /срок/,’ said Uncle Vernon with an even nastier /противней/ smile. He left without another word. Harry turned and saw the Dursleys drive away. All three of them were laughing /смеющийся/. Harry’s mouth went rather dry /сухой/. What on earth /Земля/ was he going to do? He was starting /начало/ to attract /привлекать/ a lot of funny looks /выглядит/, because of Hedwig. He’d have to ask someone.

He stopped a passing /прохождение/ guard /охрана/, but didn /А не было/’t dare mention /упомянуть/ platform nine and three-quarters /три четверти/. The guard /охрана/ had never heard of Hogwarts and when Harry couldn /не мог/’t even tell him what part /часть/ of the country /страна/ it was in, he started to get annoyed /раздраженный/, as though Harry was being stu /сту/­pid /ПИД-регулятор/ on purpose /цель/. Getting desperate /отчаянный/, Harry asked for the train that left at eleven o’clock /Часы/, but the guard /охрана/ said there wasn /WASN/’t one. In the end the guard /охрана/ strode /зашагал/ away, muttering /бормотание/ about time-wasters /время-испорченные/. Harry was now trying hard not to panic /паника/. According /в соответствии/ to the large clock /Часы/ over the arrivals /Прибытие/ board /доска/, he had ten minutes left to get on the train to Hogwarts and he had no idea how to do it; he was stranded /скрученный/ in the middle of a station /станция/ with a trunk /хобот/ he could hardly lift /лифт/, a pocket full of wizard money and a large owl.

Hagrid must have forgotten to tell him something you had to do, like tapping /нажав/ the third brick /кирпич/ on the left to get into Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/. He wondered if he should get out his wand and start tapping /нажав/ the ticket box between platforms /платформы/ nine and ten.
At that moment a group /группа/ of people passed just behind him and he caught a few words of what they were saying.
‘– packed /уплотненный/ with Muggles, of course –’

Harry swung round. The speaker /оратор/ was a plump /полнеть/ woman who was talking to four boys, all with flaming /пламенный/ red hair. Each of them was pushing /толкая/ a trunk /хобот/ like Harry’s in front of him – and they had an owl.
Heart hammering /чеканка/, Harry pushed his trolley /тележка/ after them. They stopped and so did he, just near enough to hear what they were saying.
‘Now, what’s the platform number?’ said the boys’ mother.
‘Nine and three-quarters /три четверти/!’ piped /конвейеру/ a small girl /девушка/, also red-headed /рыжеволосый/ /двуглавый/, who was holding her hand. ‘Mum, can’t I go ...’
‘You’re not old enough, Ginny /Ginny/, now be quiet. All right, Percy, you go first.’

What looked like the oldest /самый старший/ boy marched /маршировали/ towards platforms /платформы/ nine and ten. Harry watched, careful /осторожный/ not to blink /мерцать/ in case he missed /пропущенный/ it – but just as the boy reached the divide /делить/ between the two platforms /платформы/, a large crowd of tourists /туристы/ came swarming /рост бактерий на твердой среде/ in front of him, and by the time the last rucksack /рюкзак/ had cleared /очищается/ away, the boy had vanished /исчез/.
‘Fred, you next,’ the plump /полнеть/ woman said.
‘I’m not Fred, I’m George,’ said the boy. ‘Honestly /честно говоря/, woman, call yourself our mother? Can’t you tell I’m George?’
‘Sorry, George, dear.’
‘Only joking /шучу/, I am Fred,’ said the boy, and off he went. His twin /близнец/ called after him to hurry up, and he must have done, because a second later, he had gone – but how had he done it?
Now the third brother /брат/ was walking briskly /оживленно/ towards the ticket barrier /барьер/ – he was almost there – and then, quite suddenly, he wasn /WASN/’t anywhere /в любом месте/.
There was nothing else for it.
‘Excuse /оправдание/ me,’ Harry said to the plump /полнеть/ woman.
‘Hullo /алло/, dear,’ she said. ‘First time at Hogwarts? Ron’s new, too.’
She pointed at the last and youngest /младший/ of her sons /сыновья/. He was tall, thin and gangling /долговязый/, with freckles /веснушки/, big hands and feet and a long nose.
‘Yes,’ said Harry. ‘The thing is – the thing is, I don’t know how to –’
‘How to get on to the platform?’ she said kindly /любезно/, and Harry nodded /кивал/.

‘Not to worry,’ she said. ‘All you have to do is walk straight at the barrier /барьер/ between platforms /платформы/ nine and ten. Don’t stop and don’t be scared you’ll crash /авария/ into it, that’s very important. Best do it at a bit of a run if you’re nervous. Go on, go now before Ron.’
‘Er – OK /ОК/,’ said Harry.
He pushed his trolley /тележка/ round and stared at the barrier /барьер/. It looked very solid /твердый/.

He started to walk towards it. People jostled /затолкали/ him on their way to platforms /платформы/ nine and ten. Harry walked more quickly. He was going to smash /громить/ right into that ticket box and then he’d be in trouble – leaning /склонность/ forward on his trolley /тележка/ he broke into a heavy run – the barrier /барьер/ was coming nearer and nearer – he wouldn /Wouldn/’t be able to stop – the trolley /тележка/ was out of control /контроль/ – he was a foot away – he closed /закрыто/ his eyes ready for the crash /авария/ –
It didn /А не было/’t come ... he kept on running ... he opened his eyes.

A scarlet /алый/ steam /Стим/ engine /двигатель/ was waiting next to a platform packed /уплотненный/ with people. A sign overhead /накладные расходы/ said Hogwarts Express /экспресс/, 11 o’clock /Часы/. Harry looked behind him and saw a wrought-iron /железо/ /кованое железо/ archway /сводчатый проход/ where the ticket box had been, with the words Platform Nine and Three-Quarters /три четверти/ on it. He had done it.

Smoke /дым/ from the engine /двигатель/ drifted /дрейфовали/ over the heads of the chattering /болтовня/ crowd, while cats /коты/ of every colour /цвет/ wound /рана/ here and there between their legs. Owls hooted /загудели/ to each other in a disgruntled /раздраженный/ sort of way over the babble /лепет/ and the scraping /выскабливание/ of heavy trunks /стволы/.

The first few carriages /вагоны/ were already packed /уплотненный/ with students, some hanging out of the window to talk to their families, some fighting /борьба/ over seats /места/. Harry pushed his trolley /тележка/ off down the platform in search /поиск/ of an empty seat. He passed a round-faced /круглолицый/ boy who was saying, ‘Gran /бабуля/, I’ve lost my toad again.’
‘Oh, Neville,’ he heard the old woman sigh /вздох/.
A boy with dreadlocks /дреды/ was surrounded /окруженный/ by a small crowd.
‘Give us a look, Lee /подветренный/, go on.’
The boy lifted /поднятый/ the lid /крышка/ of a box in his arms and the people around him shrieked /взвизгнул/ and yelled as something inside poked /тыкали/ out a long, hairy /волосатый/ leg.

Harry pressed /прессованный/ on through the crowd until he found an empty compartment /отсек/ near the end of the train. He put Hedwig inside first and then started to shove /совать/ and heave /вспучивание/ his trunk /хобот/ towards the train door. He tried to lift /лифт/ it up the steps /меры/ but could hardly raise /повышение/ one end and twice he dropped it painfully /болезненно/ on his foot.
‘Want a hand?’ It was one of the red-haired /рыжеволосый/ twins he’d followed through the ticket box.
‘Yes, please,’ Harry panted /пыхтел/.
‘Oy /ой/, Fred! C’mere /всего лишь/ /C'mere /всего лишь// and help!’
With the twins’ help, Harry’s trunk /хобот/ was at last tucked /заправленные/ away in a corner of the compartment /отсек/.
‘Thanks,’ said Harry, pushing /толкая/ his sweaty /потный/ hair out of his eyes.
‘What’s that?’ said one of the twins suddenly, pointing at Harry’s lightning /молния/ scar.
‘Blimey /вот это да/,’ said the other twin /близнец/. ‘Are you –?’
‘He is,’ said the first twin /близнец/. ‘Aren /Арен/’t you?’ he added to Harry.
‘What?’ said Harry.
‘Harry Potter,’ chorused /хором/ the twins.
‘Oh, him,’ said Harry. ‘I mean, yes, I am.’
The two boys gawped /gawped/ at him and Harry felt himself going red. Then, to his relief /облегчение/, a voice came floating /плавающий/ in through the train’s /поезд/ open door.
‘Fred? George? Are you there?’
‘Coming, Mum.’
With a last look at Harry, the twins hopped /прыгал/ off the train.

Harry sat down next to the window where, half-hidden /полускрытую/ /скрытый/, he could watch the red-haired /рыжеволосый/ family on the platform and hear what they were saying. Their mother had just taken out her handker /handker/­chief /главный/.
‘Ron, you’ve got something on your nose.’
The youngest /младший/ boy tried to jerk /придурок/ out of the way, but she grabbed him and began rubbing /натирание/ the end of his nose.
‘Mum – geroff /geroff/.’ He wriggled /извивалась/ free.
‘Aaah /ааа/, has ickle /ickle/ Ronnie /Ronnie/ got somefink /somefink/ on his nosie /nosie/?’ said one of the twins.
‘Shut up,’ said Ron.
‘Where’s /где/ Percy?’ said their mother.
‘He’s coming now.’

The oldest /самый старший/ boy came striding /шагающий/ into sight. He had already changed into his billowing /вздымающиеся/ black Hogwarts robes and Harry noticed a shiny /блестящий/ red and gold badge /значок/ on his chest /грудь/ with the letter P on it.
‘Can’t stay long, Mother,’ he said. ‘I’m up front, the Prefects /префектов/ have got two compartments /отсеки/ to themselves –’
‘Oh, are you a Prefect /префект/, Percy?’ said one of the twins, with an air of great surprise /сюрприз/. ‘You should have said something, we had no idea.’
‘Hang /вешать/ on, I think I remember him saying something about it,’ said the other twin /близнец/. ‘Once –’
‘Or twice –’
‘A minute –’
‘All summer /лето/ –’
‘Oh, shut up,’ said Percy the Prefect /префект/.
‘How come Percy gets /получает/ new robes, anyway?’ said one of the twins.
‘Because he’s a Prefect /префект/,’ said their mother fondly /любовно/. ‘All right, dear, well, have a good term /срок/ – send me an owl when you get there.’
She kissed /целовал/ Percy on the cheek /щека/ and he left. Then she turned to the twins.
‘Now, you two – this year, you behave /вести себя/ yourselves /себя/. If I get one more owl telling me you’ve – you’ve blown /взорван/ up a toilet /туалет/ or –’
‘Blown /взорван/ up a toilet /туалет/? We’ve never blown /взорван/ up a toilet /туалет/.’
‘Great idea though, thanks, Mum.’
‘It’s not funny. And look after Ron.’
‘Don’t worry, ickle /ickle/ Ronniekins /ronniekins/ is safe with us.’
‘Shut up,’ said Ron again. He was almost as tall as the twins already and his nose was still pink where his mother had rubbed /втирать/ it.
‘Hey /Привет/, Mum, guess /Угадай/ what? Guess /Угадай/ who we just met on the train?’
Harry leant back quickly so they couldn /не мог/’t see him looking.
‘You know that black-haired /черноволосый/ boy who was near us in the station /станция/? Know who he is?’
‘Who?’
Harry heard the little girl /девушка/’s voice.
‘Oh, Mum, can I go on the train and see him, Mum, oh please ...’
‘You’ve already seen him, Ginny /Ginny/, and the poor /бедные/ boy isn’t some­thing you goggle /таращиться/ at in a zoo /зоопарк/. Is he really, Fred? How do you know?’
‘Asked him. Saw his scar. It’s really there – like lightning /молния/.’
‘Poor /бедные/ dear – no wonder he was alone. I wondered. He was ever so polite /вежливый/ when he asked how to get on to the platform.’
‘Never mind that, do you think he remembers /помнит/ what You-Know /вы знаете/-Who looks /выглядит/ like?’
Their mother suddenly became very stern /кормовой/.
‘I forbid /запретить/ you to ask him, Fred. No, don’t you dare. As though he needs /потребности/ reminding /напоминая/ of that on his first day at school.’
‘All right, keep your hair on.’
A whistle /свисток/ sounded /звучало/.

‘Hurry up!’ their mother said, and the three boys clambered /карабкались/ on to the train. They leant out of the window for her to kiss /поцелуй/ them goodbye /Прощай/ and their younger /моложе/ sister began to cry /плакать/.
‘Don’t, Ginny /Ginny/, we’ll send you loads /грузы/ of owls.’
‘We’ll send you a Hogwarts toilet /туалет/ seat.’
‘Only joking /шучу/, Mum.’

The train began to move. Harry saw the boys’ mother waving /размахивающий/ and their sister, half laughing /смеющийся/, half crying /плач/, running to keep up with the train until it gathered /собранный/ too much speed /скорость/; then she fell back and waved /махал/.

Harry watched the girl /девушка/ and her mother disappear /исчезать/ as the train rounded /закругленный/ the corner. Houses /дома/ flashed /сверкнул/ past the window. Harry felt a great leap /прыжок/ of excitement /волнение/. He didn /А не было/’t know what he was going to – but it had to be better than what he was leaving behind.
The door of the compartment /отсек/ slid /скользили/ open and the youngest /младший/ red-headed /рыжеволосый/ /двуглавый/ boy came in.
‘Anyone sitting there?’ he asked, pointing at the seat opposite /напротив/ Harry. ‘Everywhere /везде/ else is full.’

Harry shook his head and the boy sat down. He glanced /посмотрел/ at Harry and then looked quickly out of the window, pretending /претендующий/ he hadn’t looked. Harry saw he still had a black mark /отметка/ on his nose.
‘Hey /Привет/ Ron.’
The twins were back.
‘Listen, we’re going down the middle of the train – Lee /подветренный/ Jordan /Иордания/’s got a giant tarantula /тарантул/ down there.’
‘Right,’ mumbled /промямлил/ Ron.
‘Harry,’ said the other twin /близнец/, ‘did we introduce /вводить/ ourselves /сами/? Fred and George Weasley. And this is Ron, our brother /брат/. See you later, then.’
‘Bye /пока/,’ said Harry and Ron. The twins slid /скользили/ the compartment /отсек/ door shut behind them.
‘Are you really Harry Potter?’ Ron blurted /выпалила/ out.
Harry nodded /кивал/.
‘Oh – well, I thought it might be one of Fred and George’s /Юрьева/ jokes /шутки/,’ said Ron. And have you really got – you know ...’
He pointed at Harry’s forehead.
Harry pulled back his fringe /бахрома/ to show the lightning /молния/ scar. Ron stared.
‘So that’s where You-Know /вы знаете/-Who –?’
‘Yes,’ said Harry, ‘but I can’t remember it.’
‘Nothing?’ said Ron eagerly /с нетерпением/.
‘Well – I remember a lot of green light, but nothing else.’
‘Wow /Вау/,’ said Ron. He sat and stared at Harry for a few moments /моменты/, then, as though he had suddenly realised what he was doing, he looked quickly out of the window again.
‘Are all your family wizards?’ asked Harry, who found Ron just as interesting /интересно/ as Ron found him.
‘Er – yes, I think so,’ said Ron. ‘I think Mum’s /мамин/ got a second cousin /двоюродная сестра/ who’s /кто/ an accountant /бухгалтер/, but we never talk about him.’
‘So you must know loads /грузы/ of magic already.’
The Weasleys were clearly one of those old wizarding /волшебников/ families the pale boy in Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/ had talked /говорили/ about.
‘I heard you went to live with Muggles,’ said Ron. ‘What are they like?’
‘Horrible – well, not all of them. My aunt and uncle and cousin /двоюродная сестра/ are, though. Wish /желание/ I’d had three wizard brothers.’

‘Five,’ said Ron. For some reason, he was looking gloomy /мрачный/. ‘I’m the sixth /шестой/ in our family to go to Hogwarts. You could say I’ve got a lot to live up to. Bill /законопроект/ and Charlie have already left – Bill /законопроект/ was Head Boy and Charlie was captain /капитан/ of Quidditch. Now Percy’s /Перси/ a Prefect /префект/. Fred and George mess /беспорядок/ around a lot, but they still get really good marks /Метки/ and everyone thinks /думает/ they’re really funny. Everyone expects /надеется/ me to do as well as the others, but if I do, it’s no big deal /по рукам/, because they did it first. You never get anything new, either, with five brothers. I’ve got Bill /законопроект/’s old robes, Charlie’s /Чарли/ old wand and Percy’s /Перси/ old rat /крыса/.’
Ron reached inside his jacket /куртка/ and pulled out a fat grey rat /крыса/, which was asleep.

‘His name’s /зовут/ Scabbers and he’s useless /бесполезный/, he hardly ever wakes /будит/ up. Percy got an owl from my dad for being made a Prefect /префект/, but they couldn /не мог/’t aff /утвердительный/— I mean, I got Scabbers instead.’
Ron’s ears went pink. He seemed to think he’d said too much, because he went back to staring out of the window.

Harry didn /А не было/’t think there was anything wrong with not being able to afford /позволить себе/ an owl. After all, he’d never had any money in his life until a month /месяц/ ago, and he told Ron so, all about having to wear /носить/ Dudley’s old clothes /одежда/ and never getting proper /правильный/ birthday presents /подарки/. This seemed to cheer Ron up.
‘... and until Hagrid told me, I didn /А не было/’t know anything about being a wizard or about my parents or Voldemort –’
Ron gasped.
‘What?’ said Harry.
‘You said You-Know /вы знаете/-Who’s /Вы знаете кто это/ /кто/ name!’ said Ron, sounding /звучащий/ both shocked /в шоке/ and impressed /впечатленный/. ‘I’d have thought you, of all people –’

‘I’m not trying to be brave /Храбрый/ or anything, saying the name,’ said Harry. ‘I just never knew you shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/. See what I mean? I’ve got loads /грузы/ to learn ... I bet,’ he added, voicing /выражающий/ for the first time something that had been worrying /беспокойство/ him a lot lately /в последнее время/, ‘I bet I’m the worst /наихудший/ in the class.’
‘You won’t be. There’s loads /грузы/ of people who come from Muggle families and they learn quick /быстро/ enough.’

While they had been talking, the train had carried /осуществляется/ them out of London. Now they were speeding /превышение скорости/ past fields /поля/ full of cows /коровы/ and sheep /овца/. They were quiet for a time, watching the fields /поля/ and lanes /полосы/ flick /фильм/ past.

Around half past twelve there was a great clattering /стук/ outside in the corridor and a smiling, dimpled /покрытый впадинами/ woman slid /скользили/ back their door and said, ‘Anything off the trolley /тележка/, dears /родимые/?’
Harry, who hadn’t had any breakfast, leapt to his feet, but Ron’s ears went pink again and he muttered that he’d brought sand /песок/­wiches /wiches/. Harry went out into the corridor.

He had never had any money for sweets /сладости/ with the Dursleys and now that he had pockets /карманы/ rattling /грохочущий/ with gold and silver he was ready to buy as many Mars /Марс/ Bars /брусья/ as he could carry /нести/ – but the woman didn /А не было/’t have Mars /Марс/ Bars /брусья/. What she did have were Bertie /Берти/ Bott’s /Ботта/ Every-Flavour /аромат/ /каждый аромат/ Beans /фасоль/, Drooble’s /drooble-х/ Best Blowing /дующий/ Gum /жвачка/, Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/, Pumpkin /тыква/ Pasties /чебуреки/, Cauldron Cakes /торты/, Liquorice /лакрица/ Wands and a number of other strange things Harry had never seen in his life. Not wanting /желая/ to miss anything, he got some of everything and paid /оплаченный/ the woman eleven silver Sickles /серпов/ and seven bronze /бронза/ Knuts /Knuts/.
Ron stared as Harry brought it all back into the compartment /отсек/ and tipped /наваренный/ it on to an empty seat.
‘Hungry /голодный/, are you?’
‘Starving /голодающий/,’ said Harry, taking a large bite /укусить/ out of a pumpkin /тыква/ pasty /пастообразный/.

Ron had taken out a lumpy /комковатый/ package and unwrapped /развернутый/ it. There were four sandwiches /бутерброды/ in there. He pulled one of them apart and said, ‘She always forgets /забывает/ I don’t like corned /соленый/ beef /говядина/.’
‘Swap /замена/ you for one of these,’ said Harry, holding up a pasty /пастообразный/. ‘Go on –’
‘You don’t want this, it’s all dry /сухой/,’ said Ron. ‘She hasn’t /не имеет/ got much time,’ he added quickly, ‘you know, with five of us.’

‘Go on, have a pasty /пастообразный/,’ said Harry, who had never had anything to share /доля/ before or, indeed /в самом деле/, anyone to share /доля/ it with. It was a nice feeling, sitting there with Ron, eating /принимать пищу/ their way through all Harry’s pasties /чебуреки/ and cakes /торты/ (the sandwiches /бутерброды/ lay forgotten).

‘What are these?’ Harry asked Ron, holding up a pack /пак/ of Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/. ‘They’re not really frogs /лягушки/, are they?’ He was start­ing to feel that nothing would surprise /сюрприз/ him.
‘No,’ said Ron. ‘But see what the card is, I’m missing /отсутствует/ Agrippa /Агриппа/.’
‘What?’

‘Oh, of course, you wouldn /Wouldn/’t know – Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/ have cards /карты/ inside them, you know, to collect /собирать/ – Famous Witches /ведьмы/ and Wizards. I’ve got about five hundred, but I haven’t got Agrippa /Агриппа/ or Ptolemy /Птолемей/.’

Harry unwrapped /развернутый/ his Chocolate Frog /лягушка/ and picked up the card. It showed a man’s /мужской/ face. He wore /носил/ half-moon /месяц/ /Луна/ glasses, had a long crooked /изогнутый/ nose and flowing /текущий/ silver hair, beard and moustache /усы/. Underneath /под/ the picture /картина/ was the name Albus Dumbledore.
‘So this is Dumbledore!’ said Harry.
‘Don’t tell me you’d never heard of Dumbledore!’ said Ron. ‘Can I have a frog /лягушка/? I might get Agrippa /Агриппа/ – thanks –’
Harry turned over his card and read:

p.emphasis: Albus Dumbledore, currently /В данный момент/ Headmaster /старший мастер/ of Hogwarts.
Considered /считается/ by many the greatest /величайший/ wizard of modern /современное/ times, Professor Dumbledore

is particularly /в частности/ famous for his defeat /поражение/ of the dark wizard Grindelwald /Гриндельвальд/ in 1945, for the discovery /открытие/ of the twelve uses /использования/ of dragon’s /дракона/ blood and his work on alchemy /алхимия/ with his partner /партнер/, Nicolas Flamel. Professor Dumbledore enjoys /пользуется/ chamber music /Музыка/ and tenpin /Tenpin/ bowling /боулинг/.

section.p: Harry turned the card back over and saw, to his astonishment /удивление/, that Dumbledore’s face had disappeared.
‘He’s gone!’

‘Well, you can’t expect him to hang /вешать/ around all day.’ said Ron. ‘He’ll be back. No, I’ve got Morgana /моргана/ again and I’ve got about six of her ... do you want it? You can start collecting /сбор/.’
Ron’s eyes strayed /заблудившийся/ to the pile of Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/ waiting to be unwrapped /развернутый/.
‘Help yourself,’ said Harry. ‘But in, you know, the Muggle world, people just stay put in photos /фото/.’
‘Do they? What, they don’t move at all?’ Ron sounded /звучало/ amazed /пораженный/. ‘Weird /странный/!’

Harry stared as Dumbledore sidled /бочком/ back into the picture /картина/ on his card and gave him a small smile. Ron was more interested /заинтересованный/ in eating /принимать пищу/ the frogs /лягушки/ than looking at the Famous Witches /ведьмы/ and Wizards cards /карты/, but Harry couldn /не мог/’t keep his eyes off them. Soon he had not only Dumbledore and Morgana /моргана/, but Hengist /Хенгист/ of Woodcraft /умение мастерить из дерева/, Alberic /Альберик/ Grunnion /grunnion/, Circe /Цирцея/, Paracelsus /Парацельс/ and Merlin /Мерлин/. He finally tore /оторвал/ his eyes away from the druidess /druidess/ Cliodna /cliodna/, who was scratching /чесать/ her nose, to open a bag /мешок/ of Bertie /Берти/ Bott’s /Ботта/ Every-Flavour /аромат/ /каждый аромат/ Beans /фасоль/.

‘You want to be careful /осторожный/ with those,’ Ron warned /предупреждала/ Harry. ‘When they say every flavour /аромат/, they mean every flavour /аромат/ – you know, you get all the ordinary /обычный/ ones like chocolate and peppermint /мята/ and mar /март/­malade /Malade/, but then you can get spinach /шпинат/ and liver /печень/ and tripe /рубец/. George reckons /считает/ he had a bogey-flavoured /жупел вкус/ one once.’
Ron picked up a green bean /боб/, looked at it carefully and bit into a corner.
‘Bleaaargh /bleaaargh/ – see? Sprouts /ростки/.’

They had a good time eating /принимать пищу/ the Every-Flavour /аромат/ /каждый аромат/ Beans /фасоль/. Harry got toast /тост/, coconut /кокос/, baked /запеченный/ bean /боб/, strawberry /клубника/, curry /карри/, grass /трава/, coffee /кофе/, sardine /сардина/ and was even brave /Храбрый/ enough to nibble /клев/ the end off a funny grey one Ron wouldn /Wouldn/’t touch, which turned out to be pepper /перец/.

The countryside /сельская местность/ now flying past the window was becoming /становление/ wilder /дикое/. The neat /аккуратный/ fields /поля/ had gone. Now there were woods /леса/, twisting /скручивание/ rivers /реки/ and dark green hills /холмы/.

There was a knock /постучать/ on the door of their compartment /отсек/ and the round-faced /круглолицый/ boy Harry had passed on platform nine and three-quarters /три четверти/ came in. He looked tearful /плачущий/.
‘Sorry,’ he said, ‘but have you seen a toad at all?’
When they shook their heads, he wailed /причитала/, ‘I’ve lost him! He keeps /держит/ getting away from me!’
‘He’ll turn up,’ said Harry.
‘Yes,’ said the boy miserably /несчастно/. ‘Well, if you see him ...’
He left.
‘Don’t know why he’s so bothered /беспокоили/,’ said Ron. ‘If I’d brought a toad I’d lose it as quick /быстро/ as I could. Mind you, I brought Scabbers, so I can’t talk.’
The rat /крыса/ was still snoozing /Повтор/ on Ron’s lap /круг/.

‘He might have died and you wouldn /Wouldn/’t know the difference /разница/,’ said Ron in disgust /отвращение/. ‘I tried to turn him yellow /желтый/ yesterday /вчера/ to make him more interesting /интересно/, but the spell didn /А не было/’t work. I’ll show you, look ...’

He rummaged /порылась/ around in his trunk /хобот/ and pulled out a very battered /разбитый/-looking wand. It was chipped /сколы/ in places /мест/ and something white was glinting /сверкают/ at the end.
‘Unicorn hair’s /HAIR'S/ nearly poking /тыкать/ out. Anyway –’

He had just raised his wand when the compartment /отсек/ door slid /скользили/ open again. The toadless /toadless/ boy was back, but this time he had a girl /девушка/ with him. She was already wearing her new Hogwarts robes.
‘Has anyone seen a toad? Neville’s lost one,’ she said. She had a bossy /властная/ sort of voice, lots /много/ of bushy /лохматый/ brown /коричневый/ hair and rather large front teeth /зубы/.
‘We’ve already told him we haven’t seen it,’ said Ron, but the girl /девушка/ wasn /WASN/’t listening, she was looking at the wand in his hand.
‘Oh, are you doing magic? Let’s /Давайте/ see it, then.’
She sat down. Ron looked taken aback /сзади/.
‘Er – all right.’
He cleared /очищается/ his throat /горло/.
‘Sunshine /Солнечный свет/, daisies /маргаритки/, butter /масло/ mellow /сочный/,
Turn this stupid, fat rat /крыса/ yellow /желтый/.’
He waved /махал/ his wand, but nothing happened. Scabbers stayed /остались/ grey and fast asleep.

‘Are you sure that’s a real spell?’ said the girl /девушка/. ‘Well, it’s not very good, is it? I’ve tried a few simple /просто/ spells /заклинания/ just for practice /практика/ and it’s all worked /работал/ for me. Nobody in my family’s /семьи/ magic at all, it was ever such a surprise /сюрприз/ when I got my letter, but I was ever so pleased, of course, I mean, it’s the very best school of witchcraft /колдовство/ there is, I’ve heard – I’ve learnt /научился/ all our set books off by heart, of course, I just hope it will be enough – I’m Hermione Granger, by the way, who are you?’
She said all this very fast.
Harry looked at Ron and was relieved /облегчение/ to see by his stunned /ошеломлен/ face that he hadn’t learnt /научился/ all the set books off by heart either.
‘I’m Ron Weasley,’ Ron muttered.
‘Harry Potter,’ said Harry.

‘Are you really?’ said Hermione. ‘I know all about you, of course – I got a few extra /дополнительный/ books for background /задний план/ reading /чтение/, and you’re in Modern /современное/ Magical History /история/ and The Rise /подъем/ and Fall of the Dark Arts /искусства/ and Great Wizarding /волшебников/ Events /Мероприятия/ of the Twentieth /двадцатый/ Century /века/.
‘Am I?’ said Harry, feeling dazed /изумленный/.

‘Goodness /доброта/, didn /А не было/’t you know, I’d have found out everything I could if it was me,’ said Hermione. ‘Do either of you know what house you’ll be in? I’ve been asking /просить/ around and I hope I’m in Gryffindor, it sounds /звуки/ by far the best, I hear Dumbledore himself was one, but I suppose Ravenclaw /Равенкло/ wouldn /Wouldn/’t be too bad ... Anyway, we’d better go and look for Neville’s toad. You two had better change /изменение/, you know, I expect we’ll be there soon.’
And she left, taking the toadless /toadless/ boy with her.
‘Whatever /без разницы/ house I’m in, I hope she’s /она/ not in it,’ said Ron. He threw his wand back into his trunk /хобот/. ‘Stupid spell – George gave it to me, bet he knew it was a dud /рвань/.’
‘What house are your brothers in?’ asked Harry.

‘Gryffindor,’ said Ron. Gloom /мрачность/ seemed to be settling /оседание/ on him again. ‘Mum and Dad were in it, too. I don’t know what they’ll /они будут/ say if I’m not. I don’t suppose Ravenclaw /Равенкло/ would be too bad, but imagine /представить/ if they put me in Slytherin.’
‘That’s the house Vol /об/— I mean, You-Know /вы знаете/-Who was in?’
‘Yeah,’ said Ron. He flopped /шлепнулся/ back into his seat, looking depressed /подавленный/.

‘You know, I think the ends /концы/ of Scabbers’s /Scabbers-х/ whiskers /бакенбарды/ are a bit lighter /более легкий/,’ said Harry, trying to take Ron’s mind off houses /дома/. ‘So what do your oldest /самый старший/ brothers do now they’ve /они имеют/ left, anyway?’
Harry was wondering /интересно/ what a wizard did once he’d finished school.

‘Charlie’s /Чарли/ in Romania /Румыния/ studying /изучение/ dragons and Bill /законопроект/’s in Africa /Африка/ doing something for Gringotts,’ said Ron. ‘Did you hear about Gringotts? It’s been all over the Daily /ежедневно/ Prophet /пророк/, but I don’t suppose you get that with the Muggles – someone tried to rob /грабить/ a high-security /высокая безопасность/ vault /свод/.’
Harry stared.
‘Really? What happened to them?’

‘Nothing, that’s why it’s such big news. They haven’t been caught. My dad says it must’ve /Должно быть/ been a powerful /мощный/ Dark wizard to get round Gringotts, but they don’t think they took anything, that’s what’s odd. ’Course, everyone gets /получает/ scared when something like this happens /происходит/ in case You-Know /вы знаете/-Who’s /Вы знаете кто это/ /кто/ behind it.’

Harry turned this news over in his mind. He was starting /начало/ to get a prickle /колючка/ of fear /страх/ every time You-Know /вы знаете/-Who was mentioned /упомянутый/. He supposed this was all part /часть/ of entering /входящий/ the magical world, but it had been a lot more comfortable /удобный/ saying ‘Voldemort’ without worrying /беспокойство/.
‘What’s your Quidditch team?’ Ron asked.
‘Er – I don’t know any,’ Harry confessed /признался/.

‘What!’ Ron looked dumbfounded /ошарашенный/. ‘Oh, you wait, it’s the best game in the world –’ And he was off, explaining /объясняя/ all about the four balls /мячи/ and the positions /позиции/ of the seven players /игроки/, describing /описывающее/ famous games /игры/ he’d been to with his brothers and the broomstick he’d like to get if he had the money. He was just taking Harry through the finer /мельче/ points of the game when the compartment /отсек/ door slid /скользили/ open yet again, but it wasn /WASN/’t Neville the toadless /toadless/ boy or Hermione Granger this time.

Three boys entered /вошел/ and Harry recognised /признанное/ the middle one at once: it was the pale boy from Madam Malkin /Малкина/’s /Малкин/ robe /халат/ shop. He was looking at Harry with a lot more interest /интерес/ than he’d shown /показанный/ back in Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/.
‘Is it true?’ he said. ‘They’re saying all down the train that Harry Potter’s /гончарное/ in this compartment /отсек/. So it’s you, is it?’

‘Yes,’ said Harry. He was looking at the other boys. Both of them were thickset /коренастый/ and looked extremely /очень/ mean. Standing either side of the pale boy they looked like bodyguards /телохранители/.
‘Oh, this is Crabbe and this is Goyle,’ said the pale boy carelessly /беспечно/, noticing /замечающий/ where Harry was looking. ‘And my name’s /зовут/ Malfoy, Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy.’
Ron gave a slight /незначительный/ cough /кашель/, which might have been hiding /прячется/ a snigger /хихиканье/. Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy looked at him.

‘Think my name’s /зовут/ funny, do you? No need to ask who you are. My father told me all the Weasleys have red hair, freckles /веснушки/ and more children /дети/ than they can afford /позволить себе/.’
He turned back to Harry.
‘You’ll soon find out some wizarding /волшебников/ families are much better than others, Potter. You don’t want to go making friends with the wrong sort. I can help you there.’
He held out his hand to shake /встряхивать/ Harry’s, but Harry didn /А не было/’t take it.
‘I think I can tell who the wrong sort are for myself /себя/, thanks,’ he said coolly /спокойно/.
Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy didn /А не было/’t go red, but a pink tinge /оттенок/ appeared in his pale cheeks /щеки/.

‘I’d be careful /осторожный/ if I were you, Potter,’ he said slowly. ‘Unless /если/ you’re a bit politer /politer/ you’ll go the same way as your parents. They didn /А не было/’t know what was good for them, either. You hang /вешать/ around with riff-raff /шушера/ like the Weasleys and that Hagrid and it’ll /это будет/ rub /натирать/ off on you.’
Both Harry and Ron stood up. Ron’s face was as red as his hair.
‘Say that again,’ he said.
‘Oh, you’re going to fight /борьба/ us, are you?’ Malfoy sneered /глумился/.
‘Unless /если/ you get out now,’ said Harry, more bravely /отважно/ than he felt, because Crabbe and Goyle were a lot bigger /больше/ than him or Ron.
‘But we don’t feel like leaving, do we, boys? We’ve eaten /съеденный/ all our food /питание/ and you still seem to have some.’
Goyle reached towards the Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/ next to Ron – Ron leapt forward, but before he’d so much as touched /прикоснулся/ Goyle, Goyle let out a horrible yell /вопить/.

Scabbers the rat /крыса/ was hanging off his finger /Палец/, sharp little teeth /зубы/ sunk /погруженный/ deep into Goyle’s /Гойл-х/ knuckle /ножка/ – Crabbe and Malfoy backed /со спинкой/ away as Goyle swung Scabbers round and round, howling /воющий/, and when Scabbers finally flew off and hit the window, all three of them disappeared at once. Perhaps they thought there were more rats /крысы/ lurking /скрываясь/ among /среди/ the sweets /сладости/, or perhaps they’d heard footsteps /шаги/, because a second later, Hermione Granger had come in.
‘What has been going on?’ she said, looking at the sweets /сладости/ all over the floor and Ron picking /собирание/ up Scabbers by his tail.
‘I think he’s been knocked out,’ Ron said to Harry. He looked closer at Scabbers. ‘No – I don’t believe it – he’s gone back to sleep.’
And so he had.
‘You’ve met Malfoy before?’
Harry explained /объяснил/ about their meeting /встреча/ in Diagon /Косой/ Alley /аллея/.

‘I’ve heard of his family,’ said Ron darkly /загадочно/. ‘They were some of the first to come back to our side after You-Know /вы знаете/-Who disap /disap/­peared /peared/. Said they’d been bewitched /заколдованный/. My dad doesn’t /не/ believe it. He says Malfoy’s father didn /А не было/’t need an excuse /оправдание/ to go over to the Dark Side.’ He turned to Hermione. ‘Can we help you with something?’

‘You’d better hurry up and put your robes on, I’ve just been up the front to ask the driver /Водитель/ and he says we’re nearly there. You haven’t been fighting /борьба/, have you? You’ll be in trouble before we even get there!’
‘Scabbers has been fighting /борьба/, not us,’ said Ron, scowling /сердитый/ at her. ‘Would you mind leaving while we change /изменение/?’

‘All right – I only came in here because people outside are behaving /вести/ very childishly /ребячески/, racing up and down the corridors /коридоры/,’ said Hermione in a sniffy /презрительный/ voice. ‘And you’ve got dirt /грязь/ on your nose, by the way, did you know?’

Ron glared /впился/ at her as she left. Harry peered /всматривался/ out of the window. It was getting dark. He could see mountains /горы/ and forests /леса/ under a deep-purple /темно-фиолетовый/ sky. The train did seem to be slowing /замедление/ down.
He and Ron took off their jackets /жакеты/ and pulled on their long black robes. Ron’s were a bit short /короткая/ for him, you could see his trainers /кросовки/ underneath /под/ them.

A voice echoed /вторил/ through the train: ‘We will be reaching /достижения/ Hogwarts in five minutes’ time. Please leave your luggage /багаж/ on the train, it will be taken to the school separately /в отдельности/.’

Harry’s stomach /желудок/ lurched /покачнулся/ with nerves /нервы/ and Ron, he saw, looked pale under his freckles /веснушки/. They crammed /забита/ their pockets /карманы/ with the last of the sweets /сладости/ and joined /присоединился/ the crowd thronging /толпятся/ the corridor.

The train slowed /замедлилась/ right down and finally stopped. People pushed their way towards the door and out on to a tiny, dark platform. Harry shivered /задрожала/ in the cold night air. Then a lamp came bobbing /флюктуация интенсивности светового пятна на экране радиолокатора/ over the heads of the students and Harry heard a familiar /знакомые/ voice: ‘Firs /ели/’-years /firs /ели/' лет/! Firs /ели/’-years /firs /ели/' лет/ over here! All right there, Harry?’
Hagrid’s big hairy /волосатый/ face beamed /балочные/ over the sea /море/ of heads.
‘C’mon /Да ладно/, follow me – any more firs /ели/’-years /firs /ели/' лет/? Mind yer step /шаг/, now! Firs /ели/’-years /firs /ели/' лет/ follow me!’

Slipping /скольжение/ and stumbling /спотыкаясь/, they followed Hagrid down what seemed to be a steep /крутой/, narrow /узкий/ path. It was so dark either side of them that Harry thought there must be thick trees there. Nobody spoke much. Neville, the boy who kept losing /проигрыш/ his toad, sniffed /понюхал/ once or twice.
‘Yeh’ll /yeh'll/ get yer firs /ели/’ sight o’ Hogwarts in a sec /сек/,’ Hagrid called over his shoulder, ‘jus /закон/’ round this bend /изгиб/ here.’
There was a loud ‘Oooooh /Oooooh/!’.

The narrow /узкий/ path had opened suddenly on to the edge of a great black lake /озеро/. Perched /взгромоздился/ atop /сверху/ a high mountain /гора/ on the other side, its windows /окна/ sparkling /сверкающий/ in the starry /звездный/ sky, was a vast /огромный/ castle with many turrets /башенки/ and towers /башни/.

‘No more’n /more'n/ four to a boat!’ Hagrid called, pointing to a fleet /флот/ of little boats /лодки/ sitting in the water /воды/ by the shore /берег/. Harry and Ron were followed into their boat by Neville and Hermione.
‘Everyone in?’ shouted Hagrid, who had a boat to himself, ‘Right then – FORWARD!’

And the fleet /флот/ of little boats /лодки/ moved off all at once, gliding /скольжение/ across the lake /озеро/, which was as smooth /гладкий; плавный/ as glass. Everyone was silent /бесшумный/, staring up at the great castle overhead /накладные расходы/. It towered /возвышались/ over them as they sailed /плавал/ nearer and nearer to the cliff /утес/ on which it stood.

‘Heads down!’ yelled Hagrid as the first boats /лодки/ reached the cliff /утес/; they all bent their heads and the little boats /лодки/ carried /осуществляется/ them through a curtain /занавес/ of ivy /плющ/ which hid /спрятался/ a wide opening /открытие/ in the cliff /утес/ face. They were carried /осуществляется/ along a dark tunnel /тоннель/, which seemed to be taking them right underneath /под/ the castle, until they reached a kind /своего рода/ of under­ground harbour /гавань/, where they clambered /карабкались/ out on to rocks /горные породы/ and pebbles /крупная галька/.
‘Oy /ой/, you there! Is this your toad?’ said Hagrid, who was check /проверить/­ing the boats /лодки/ as people climbed out of them.

‘Trevor /Тревор/!’ cried Neville blissfully /блаженно/, holding out his hands. Then they clambered /карабкались/ up a passageway /перепускной канал/ in the rock after Hagrid’s lamp, coming out at last on to smooth /гладкий; плавный/, damp /сырость/ grass /трава/ right in the shadow /тень/ of the castle.
They walked up a flight /рейс/ of stone steps /меры/ and crowded /переполненный/ around the huge, oak /дуб/ front door.
‘Everyone here? You there, still got yer toad?’
Hagrid raised a gigantic /гигантский/ fist /кулак/ and knocked three times on the castle door.

The door swung open at once. A tall, black-haired /черноволосый/ witch in emerald /изумруд/-green robes stood there. She had a very stern /кормовой/ face and Harry’s first thought was that this was not someone to cross /пересекать/.
‘The firs /ели/’-years /firs /ели/' лет/, Professor McGonagall,’ said Hagrid.
‘Thank /спасибо/ you, Hagrid. I will take them from here.’

She pulled the door wide. The Entrance /вход/ Hall was so big you could have fitted /установлены/ the whole of the Dursleys’ house in it. The stone walls were lit /освещенный/ with flaming /пламенный/ torches /факелы/ like the ones at Gringotts, the ceiling was too high to make out, and a magnificent /великолепный/ marble /мрамор/ stair /ступенька/­case facing /облицовочный/ them led /светодиод/ to the upper /верхний/ floors /этажей/.

They followed Professor McGonagall across the flagged /Помеченные/ stone floor. Harry could hear the drone /трутень/ of hundreds of voices /голоса/ from a doorway /дверной проем/ to the right – the rest of the school must already be here – but Professor McGonagall showed the first-years into a small empty chamber off the hall. They crowded /переполненный/ in, standing rather closer together than they would usually have done, peering /всматриваясь/ about nervously.

‘Welcome /добро пожаловать/ to Hogwarts,’ said Professor McGonagall. ‘The start-of-term /старт-оф-термина/ /срок/ banquet /банкет/ will begin /начать/ shortly /вскоре/, but before you take your seats /места/ in the Great Hall, you will be sorted /отсортированный/ into your houses /дома/. The Sorting /сортировка/ is a very important ceremony /церемония/ because, while you are here, your house will be something like your family within /в/ Hogwarts. You will have classes /классы/ with the rest of your house, sleep in your house dormitory /общежитие/ and spend /проводить/ free time in your house common room.

‘The four houses /дома/ are called Gryffindor, Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw /Равенкло/ and Slytherin. Each house has its own noble /благородный/ history /история/ and each has produced /произведенный/ outstanding /выдающийся/ witches /ведьмы/ and wizards. While you are at Hogwarts, your triumphs /триумфы/ will earn /зарабатывать/ your house points, while any rule /правило/-breaking /ломка/ will lose house points. At the end of the year, the house with the most points is awarded /награжден/ the House Cup, a great honour /честь/. I hope each of you will be a credit /кредит/ to whichever /какой бы ни/ house becomes /становится/ yours /ваш/.

‘The Sorting /сортировка/ Ceremony /церемония/ will take place in a few minutes in front of the rest of the school. I suggest /предлагать/ you all smarten /прихорашиваться/ yourselves /себя/ up as much as you can while you are waiting.’

Her eyes lingered /задержались/ for a moment on Neville’s cloak, which was fastened /закреплены/ under his left ear /ухо/, and on Ron’s smudged /нечеткое/ nose. Harry nervously tried to flatten /расплющить/ his hair.
‘I shall /должен/ return /вернуть/ when we are ready for you,’ said Professor McGonagall. ‘Please wait quietly.’
She left the chamber. Harry swallowed /проглатывании/.
‘How exactly do they sort us into houses /дома/?’ he asked Ron.
‘Some sort of test /контрольная работа/, I think. Fred said it hurts /болит/ a lot, but I think he was joking /шучу/.’

Harry’s heart gave a horrible jolt /трясти/. A test /контрольная работа/? In front of the whole school? But he didn /А не было/’t know any magic yet – what on earth /Земля/ would he have to do? He hadn’t expected something like this the moment they arrived. He looked around anxiously /с тревогой/ and saw that everyone else looked terrified /ужас/ too. No one was talking much except Hermione Granger, who was whispering /шепот/ very fast about all the spells /заклинания/ she’d learnt /научился/ and wondering /интересно/ which one she’d need. Harry tried hard not to listen to her. He’d never been more nervous, never, not even when he’d had to take a school report /доклад/ home to the Dursleys saying that he’d somehow turned his teacher /учитель/’s wig /парик/ blue. He kept his eyes fixed /исправлено/ on the door. Any second now, Professor McGonagall would come back and lead /вести/ him to his doom /гибель/.
Then something happened which made him jump /Прыгать/ about a foot in the air – several people behind him screamed.
‘What the –?’

He gasped. So did the people around him. About twenty /20/ ghosts /призраки/ had just streamed /потоковый/ through the back wall. Pearly /жемчужный/-white /жемчужно-белый/ and slightly /немного/ transparent /прозрачный/, they glided /скользили/ across the room talking to each other and hardly glancing /поглядывая/ at the first-years. They seemed to be arguing /спорить/. What looked like a fat little monk /монах/ was saying, ‘Forgive /прощать/ and forget, I say, we ought /должен/ to give him a second chance –’

‘My dear Friar /монах/, haven’t we given Peeves all the chances /шансы/ he deserves /заслуживает/? He gives /дает/ us all a bad name and you know, he’s not really even a ghost – I say, what are you all doing here?’
A ghost wearing a ruff /ерш/ and tights /колготки/ had suddenly noticed the first-years.
Nobody answered /ответил/.
‘New students!’ said the Fat Friar /монах/, smiling around at them. ‘About to be sorted /отсортированный/, I suppose?’
A few people nodded /кивал/ mutely /безмолвно/.
‘Hope to see you in Hufflepuff!’ said the Friar /монах/. ‘My old house, you know.’
‘Move along now,’ said a sharp voice. ‘The Sorting /сортировка/ Ceremony /церемония/’s about to start.’
Professor McGonagall had returned /возвращенный/. One by one, the ghosts /призраки/ floated /плавали/ away through the opposite /напротив/ wall.
‘Now, form /форма/ a line,’ Professor McGonagall told the first-years, ‘and follow me.’

Feeling oddly /странно/ as though his legs had turned to lead /вести/, Harry got into line behind a boy with sandy /Сэнди/ hair, with Ron behind him, and they walked out of the chamber, back across the hall and through a pair of double /двойной/ doors into the Great Hall.

Harry had never even imagined /вообразил/ such a strange and splendid /великолепный/ place. It was lit /освещенный/ by thousands /тысячи/ and thousands /тысячи/ of candles /свечи/ which were floating /плавающий/ in mid-air /в воздухе/ over four long tables /таблицы/, where the rest of the students were sitting. These tables /таблицы/ were laid /проложенный/ with glittering /сверкающий/ golden /золотой/ plates /тарелки/ and goblets /бокалы/. At the top of the Hall was another long table where the teachers were sitting. Professor McGonagall led /светодиод/ the first-years up here, so that they came to a halt /стой/ in a line facing /облицовочный/ the other students, with the teachers behind them. The hundreds of faces staring at them looked like pale lanterns /фонари/ in the flickering /мерцающий/ candlelight /искусственное освещение/. Dotted /пунктирный/ here and there among /среди/ the students, the ghosts /призраки/ shone /светило/ misty /туманный/ silver. Mainly /в основном/ to avoid /избежать/ all the staring eyes, Harry looked upwards /вверх/ and saw a velvety /бархатистый/ black ceiling dotted /пунктирный/ with stars /звезды/. He heard Hermione whisper /шептать/, ‘It’s bewitched /заколдованный/ to look like the sky outside, I read about it in Hogwarts: A History /история/.’
It was hard to believe there was a ceiling there at all, and that the Great Hall didn /А не было/’t simply /просто/ open on to the heavens /небо/.

Harry quickly looked down again as Professor McGonagall silently /молча/ placed /помещенный/ a four-legged /на четырех ногах/ stool /стул/ in front of the first-years. On top of the stool /стул/ she put a pointed wizard’s /мастера/ hat. This hat was patched /заплата/ and frayed /изношен/ and extremely /очень/ dirty /грязный/. Aunt Petunia wouldn /Wouldn/’t have let it in the house.

Maybe they had to try and get a rabbit /кролик/ out of it, Harry thought wildly /дико/, that seemed the sort of thing – noticing /замечающий/ that everyone in the Hall was now staring at the hat, he stared at it too. For a few seconds, there was complete /полный/ silence. Then the hat twitched /дернулись/. A rip /Покойся с миром/ near the brim /край/ opened wide like a mouth – and the hat began to sing /петь/:

p.emphasis: ‘Oh, you may not think I’m pretty /Симпатичная/,
But don’t judge /судья/ on what you see,
I’ll eat /есть/ myself /себя/ if you can find
You can keep your bowlers /котелки/ black,
Your top hats /головные уборы/ sleek /гладкий/ and tall,
For I’m the Hogwarts Sorting /сортировка/ Hat
And I can cap /кепка/ them all.
There’s nothing hidden /скрытый/ in your head
So try me on and I will tell you
Where dwell /обитать/ the brave /Храбрый/ at heart,
Where they are just and loyal /верный/,
Or yet in wise /мудрый/ old Ravenclaw /Равенкло/,
Where those of wit /остроумие/ and learning /обучение/,
Will always find their kind /своего рода/;
Those cunning /хитрость/ folk /люди/ use any means /означает/
So put me on! Don’t be afraid /боюсь/!
And don’t get in a flap /створка/!
You’re in safe hands (though I have none)

section.p: The whole Hall burst into applause /аплодисменты/ as the hat finished its song /песня/. It bowed /поклонилась/ to each of the four tables /таблицы/ and then became quite still again.
‘So we’ve just got to try on the hat!’ Ron whispered to Harry. ‘I’ll kill Fred, he was going on about wrestling /борьба/ a troll.’

Harry smiled weakly /слабо/. Yes, trying on the hat was a lot better than having to do a spell, but he did wish /желание/ they could have tried it on without everyone watching. The hat seemed to be asking /просить/ rather a lot; Harry didn /А не было/’t feel brave /Храбрый/ or quick /быстро/-witted or any of it at the moment. If only the hat had mentioned /упомянутый/ a house for people who felt a bit queasy /разборчивый/, that would have been the one for him.
Professor McGonagall now stepped forward holding a long roll /рулон/ of parchment /пергамент/.
‘When I call your name, you will put on the hat and sit /сидеть/ on the stool /стул/ to be sorted /отсортированный/,’ she said. ‘Abbott /Abbott/, Hannah /Анна/!’

A pink-faced /розовое лицо/ girl /девушка/ with blonde /блондинка/ pigtails /косички/ stumbled /споткнулся/ out of line, put on the hat, which fell right down over her eyes, and sat down. A moment’s /минутное/ pause /Пауза/ –
‘HUFFLEPUFF!’ shouted the hat.

The table on the right cheered /повеселел/ and clapped as Hannah /Анна/ went to sit /сидеть/ down at the Hufflepuff table. Harry saw the ghost of the Fat Friar /монах/ waving /размахивающий/ merrily /весело/ at her.
‘Bones /скелет/, Susan /Сьюзен/!’
‘HUFFLEPUFF!’ shouted the hat again, and Susan /Сьюзен/ scuttled /затоплен/ off to sit /сидеть/ next to Hannah /Анна/.
‘Boot /ботинок/, Terry /Терри/!’
‘RAVENCLAW /Равенкло/!’
The table second from the left clapped this time; several Ravenclaws /рейвенкловцы/ stood up to shake /встряхивать/ hands with Terry /Терри/ as he joined /присоединился/ them.

‘Brocklehurst /Броклехерст/, Mandy /Мэнди/’ went to Ravenclaw /Равенкло/ too, but ‘Brown /коричневый/, Lavender /лаванда/’ became the first new Gryffindor and the table on the far left exploded /взорванный/ with cheers /ура/; Harry could see Ron’s twin /близнец/ brothers catcalling /catcalling/.

‘Bulstrode /Булстроуд/, Millicent /Миллисент/’ then became a Slytherin. Perhaps it was Harry’s imagination /воображение/, after all he’d heard about Slytherin, but he thought they looked an unpleasant /неприятный/ lot.

He was starting /начало/ to feel definitely /определенно/ sick /больной/ now. He remembered /вспомнил/ being picked for teams /команды/ during /в течение/ sports /виды спорта/ lessons at his old school. He had always been last to be chosen /выбранный/, not because he was no good, but because no one wanted Dudley to think they liked him.
‘Finch-Fletchley /Финч-Флетчли/, Justin /джастин/!’
‘HUFFLEPUFF!’

Sometimes /иногда/, Harry noticed, the hat shouted out the house at once, but at others it took a little while to decide /принимать решение/. ‘Finnigan /Финниган/, Seamus’, the sandy /Сэнди/-haired /светловолосый/ boy next to Harry in the line, sat on the stool /стул/ for almost a whole minute before the hat declared /объявленный/ him a Gryffindor.
‘Granger, Hermione!’
Hermione almost ran to the stool /стул/ and jammed /зажатый/ the hat eagerly /с нетерпением/ on her head.
‘GRYFFINDOR!’ shouted the hat. Ron groaned /простонал/.

A horrible thought struck /пораженный/ Harry, as horrible thoughts /мысли/ always do when you’re very nervous. What if he wasn /WASN/’t chosen /выбранный/ at all? What if he just sat there with the hat over his eyes for ages, until Professor McGonagall jerked /рывок/ it off his head and said there had obviously been a mistake /ошибка/ and he’d better get back on the train?

When Neville Longbottom /Лонгботт/, the boy who kept losing /проигрыш/ his toad, was called, he fell over on his way to the stool /стул/. The hat took a long time to decide /принимать решение/ with Neville. When it finally shouted ‘GRYFFINDOR’, Neville ran off still wearing it, and had to jog /бегать трусцой/ back amid /среди/ gales /штормы/ of laughter /смех/ to give it to ‘MacDougal /Макдугал/, Morag /Мораг/’.
Malfoy swaggered /вразвалочку/ forward when his name was called and got his wish /желание/ at once: the hat had barely /едва/ touched /прикоснулся/ his head when it screamed, ‘SLYTHERIN!’
Malfoy went to join /присоединиться/ his friends Crabbe and Goyle, looking pleased with himself.
There weren’t many people left now.

‘Moon /Луна/’ ... ‘Nott /Нотт/’ ... ‘Parkinson /паркинсон/’ ... then a pair of twin /близнец/ girls /девочки/, ‘Patil /Патил/’ and ‘Patil /Патил/’ ... then ‘Perks /надбавки/, Sally-Anne /анна/ /вылазка-анна/’ ... and then, at last –
‘Potter, Harry!’
As Harry stepped forward, whispers /шепоты/ suddenly broke out like little hissing /шипение/ fires /пожары/ all over the hall.
‘Potter, did she say?’
‘The Harry Potter?’

The last thing Harry saw before the hat dropped over his eyes was the Hall full of people craning /вытягивали/ to get a good look at him. Next second he was looking at the black inside of the hat. He waited /подождал/.

‘Hmm /хмм/,’ said a small voice in his ear /ухо/. ‘Difficult. Very difficult. Plenty /много/ of courage /мужество/, I see. Not a bad mind, either. There’s talent /талант/, oh my goodness /доброта/, yes – and a nice thirst /жажда/ to prove /доказывать/ yourself, now that’s interesting /интересно/ ... So where shall /должен/ I put you?’
Harry gripped /захватывается/ the edges /края/ of the stool /стул/ and thought, ‘Not Slytherin, not Slytherin.’

‘Not Slytherin, eh?’ said the small voice. ‘Are you sure? You could be great, you know, it’s all here in your head, and Slytherin will help you on the way to greatness /величие/, no doubt /сомнение/ about that – no? Well, if you’re sure – better be GRYFFINDOR!’

Harry heard the hat shout /окрик/ the last word to the whole Hall. He took off the hat and walked shakily /шатко/ towards the Gryffindor table. He was so relieved /облегчение/ to have been chosen /выбранный/ and not put in Slytherin, he hardly noticed that he was getting the loudest /громче всех/ cheer yet. Percy the Prefect /префект/ got up and shook his hand vigorously /энергично/, while the Weasley twins yelled, ‘We got Potter! We got Potter!’ Harry sat down opposite /напротив/ the ghost in the ruff /ерш/ he’d seen earlier /ранее/. The ghost patted /потрепал/ his arm, giving /дающий/ Harry the sudden, horrible feeling he’d just plunged /погрузилась/ it into a bucket /ведро/ of ice /лед/-cold water /воды/.

He could see the High Table properly /должным образом/ now. At the end nearest /ближайший/ him sat Hagrid, who caught his eye and gave him the thumbs-up /пальцы вверх/. Harry grinned /ухмыльнулась/ back. And there, in the centre /центр/ of the High Table, in a large gold chair /стул/, sat Albus Dumbledore. Harry recognised /признанное/ him at once from the card he’d got out of the Chocolate Frog /лягушка/ on the train. Dumbledore’s silver hair was the only thing in the whole Hall that shone /светило/ as brightly /ярко/ as the ghosts /призраки/. Harry spotted Professor Quirrell, too, the nervous young /молодой/ man from the Leaky /неплотный/ Cauldron. He was looking very peculiar /своеобразный/ in a large purple turban.

And now there were only three people left to be sorted /отсортированный/. ‘Turpin /Терпин/, Lisa /Лайза/’ became a Ravenclaw /Равенкло/ and then it was Ron’s turn. He was pale green by now. Harry crossed /пересекла/ his fingers under the table and a second later the hat had shouted, ‘GRYFFINDOR!’
Harry clapped loudly with the rest as Ron collapsed /развалился/ into the chair /стул/ next to him.

‘Well done, Ron, excellent /отлично/,’ said Percy Weasley pompously /высокопарно/ across Harry as ‘Zabini /Забини/, Blaise /Блез/’ was made a Slytherin. Professor McGonagall rolled up her scroll /свиток/ and took the Sorting /сортировка/ Hat away.
Harry looked down at his empty gold plate /пластина/. He had only just realised how hungry /голодный/ he was. The pumpkin /тыква/ pasties /чебуреки/ seemed ages ago.
Albus Dumbledore had got to his feet. He was beaming /лучезарный/ at the students, his arms opened wide, as if nothing could have pleased him more than to see them all there.
