‘Welcome /добро пожаловать/!’ he said. ‘Welcome /добро пожаловать/ to a new year at Hogwarts! Before we begin /начать/ our banquet /банкет/, I would like to say a few words. And here they are: Nitwit /простофиля/! Blubber /выпячивающийся/! Oddment /oddment/! Tweak /щипать/!
‘Thank /спасибо/ you!’
He sat back down. Everybody /все/ clapped and cheered /повеселел/. Harry didn /А не было/’t know whether /будь то/ to laugh /смех/ or not.
‘Is he – a bit mad?’ he asked Percy uncertainly /нерешительно/.
‘Mad?’ said Percy airily /легкомысленно/. ‘He’s a genius /гениальность/! Best wizard in the world! But he is a bit mad, yes. Potatoes /картофель/, Harry?’

Harry’s mouth fell open. The dishes /блюда/ in front of him were now piled /сложено/ with food /питание/. He had never seen so many things he liked to eat /есть/ on one table: roast /обжиг/ beef /говядина/, roast /обжиг/ chicken /курица/, pork /свинина/ chops /челюсти/ and lamb /ягненок/ chops /челюсти/, sausages /колбасные изделия/, bacon /бекон/ and steak /стейк/, boiled /вареный/ potatoes /картофель/, roast /обжиг/ potatoes /картофель/, chips /чипсы/, Yorkshire /Йоркшир/ pudding /пудинг/, peas /горох/, carrots /морковь/, gravy /подливка/, ketchup /кетчуп/ and, for some strange reason, mint /мята/ humbugs /Мятные/.

The Dursleys had never exactly starved /изморенный голод/ Harry, but he’d never been allowed to eat /есть/ as much as he liked. Dudley had always taken anything that Harry really wanted, even if it made him sick /больной/. Harry piled /сложено/ his plate /пластина/ with a bit of everything except the humbugs /Мятные/ and began to eat /есть/. It was all delicious /вкусно/.
‘That does look good,’ said the ghost in the ruff /ерш/ sadly /грустно/, watching Harry cut /порез/ up his steak /стейк/.
‘Can’t you –?’

‘I haven’t eaten /съеденный/ for nearly five hundred years,’ said the ghost. ‘I don’t need to, of course, but one does miss it. I don’t think I’ve introduced /введены/ myself /себя/? Sir Nicholas /Николай/ de /де/ Mimsy /mimsy/-Porpington /mimsy /mimsy/-porpington/ at your service /оказание услуг/. Resident /резидент/ ghost of Gryffindor Tower.’
‘I know who you are!’ said Ron suddenly. ‘My brothers told me about you – you’re Nearly Headless /Обезглавленный/ Nick /Ник/!’

‘I would prefer /предпочитать/ you to call me Sir Nicholas /Николай/ de /де/ Mimsy /mimsy/ –’ the ghost began stiffly /натянуто/, but sandy /Сэнди/-haired /светловолосый/ Seamus Finnigan /Финниган/ interrupted /прерванный/.
‘Nearly Headless /Обезглавленный/? How can you be nearly headless /Обезглавленный/?’
Sir Nicholas /Николай/ looked extremely /очень/ miffed /раздражались/, as if their little chat /чат/ wasn /WASN/’t going at all the way he wanted.

‘Like this,’ he said irritably /раздражение/. He seized his left ear /ухо/ and pulled. His whole head swung off his neck and fell on to his shoulder as if it was on a hinge /петля/. Someone had obviously tried to behead /обезглавить/ him, but not done it properly /должным образом/. Looking pleased at the stunned /ошеломлен/ looks /выглядит/ on their faces, Nearly Headless /Обезглавленный/ Nick /Ник/ flipped /перевернутый/ his head back on to his neck, coughed /кашлянул/ and said, ‘So – new Gryffindors! I hope you’re going to help us win /выиграть/ the House Championship /чемпионат/ this year? Gryffindor have never gone so long without winning /выигрыш/. Slytherin have got the cup six years in a row! The Bloody /кровавый/ Baron /барон/’s becoming /становление/ almost unbearable /невыносимый/ – he’s the Slytherin ghost.’

Harry looked over at the Slytherin table and saw a horrible ghost sitting there, with blank /пустой/ staring eyes, a gaunt /тощий/ face and robes stained /запятнанный/ with silver blood. He was right next to Malfoy who, Harry was pleased to see, didn /А не было/’t look too pleased with the seating /посадка/ arrangements /договоренности/.
‘How did he get covered /покрытый/ in blood?’ asked Seamus with great interest /интерес/.
‘I’ve never asked,’ said Nearly Headless /Обезглавленный/ Nick /Ник/ delicately /деликатно/.

When everyone had eaten /съеденный/ as much as they could, the remains /остатки/ of the food /питание/ faded /утрачен/ from the plates /тарелки/, leaving them sparkling /сверкающий/ clean /чистый/ as before. A moment later the puddings /пудинги/ appeared. Blocks /блоки/ of ice /лед/-cream in every flavour /аромат/ you could think of, apple /яблоко/ pies /пирогов/, treacle /патока/ tarts /пирогов/, chocolate éclairs /clairs/ and jam /варенье/ doughnuts /пончики/, trifle /мелочь/, strawberries /клубника/, jelly /желе/, rice /рис/ pudding /пудинг/ ...
As Harry helped /помог/ himself to a treacle /патока/ tart /терпкий/, the talk turned to their families.
‘I’m half and half,’ said Seamus. ‘Me dad’s /папа/ a Muggle. Mam /мама/ didn /А не было/’t tell him she was a witch ’til /сезам/ after they were married /в браке/. Bit of a nasty shock for him.’
The others laughed /рассмеялся/.
‘What about you, Neville?’ said Ron.

‘Well, my gran /бабуля/ brought me up and she’s /она/ a witch,’ said Neville, ‘but the family thought I was all Muggle for ages. My great-uncle /двоюродный дедушка/ Algie /Элджи/ kept trying to catch me off my guard /охрана/ and force /сила/ some magic out of me – he pushed me off the end of Blackpool /Blackpool/ pier /пирс/ once, I nearly drowned /утонули/ – but nothing happened until I was eight /8/. Great-uncle /двоюродный дедушка/ Algie /Элджи/ came round for tea and he was hanging me out of an upstairs window by the ankles /щиколотки/ when my great-auntie /тетушка/ /двоюродная тетушка/ Enid /Энид/ offered /предложенный/ him a meringue /меренга/ and he accidentally /случайно/ let go. But I bounced /отскочила/ – all the way down the garden /сад/ and into the road /Дорога/. They were all really pleased. Gran /бабуля/ was crying /плач/, she was so happy. And you should have seen their faces when I got in here – they thought I might not be magic enough to come, you see. Great-uncle /двоюродный дедушка/ Algie /Элджи/ was so pleased he bought /купил/ me my toad.’

On Harry’s other side, Percy Weasley and Hermione were talk­ing about lessons (‘I do hope they start straight away, there’s so much to learn, I’m particularly /в частности/ interested /заинтересованный/ in Transfiguration /видоизменение/, you know, turning something into something else, of course, it’s supposed to be very difficult –’; ‘You’ll be starting /начало/ small, just matches /Матчи/ into needles /иглы/ and that sort of thing –’).

Harry, who was starting /начало/ to feel warm /тепло/ and sleepy /сонный/, looked up at the High Table again. Hagrid was drinking /питьевой/ deeply /глубоко/ from his goblet /кубок/. Professor McGonagall was talking to Professor Dumbledore. Professor Quirrell, in his absurd /абсурд/ turban, was talking to a teacher /учитель/ with greasy /сальный/ black hair, a hooked /зацепили/ nose and sallow /желтоватый/ skin /кожа/.

It happened very suddenly. The hook-nosed /с крючковатым носом/ teacher /учитель/ looked past Quirrell’s turban straight into Harry’s eyes – and a sharp, hot /горячий/ pain shot across the scar on Harry’s forehead.
‘Ouch /ой/!’ Harry clapped a hand to his head.
‘What is it?’ asked Percy.
‘N-nothing /Н-ничего/.’

The pain had gone as quickly as it had come. Harder /Сильнее/ to shake /встряхивать/ off was the feeling Harry had got from the teacher /учитель/’s look – a feel­ing that he didn /А не было/’t like Harry at all.
‘Who’s /кто/ that teacher /учитель/ talking to Professor Quirrell?’ he asked Percy.

‘Oh, you know Quirrell already, do you? No wonder he’s look­ing so nervous, that’s Professor Snape. He teaches /учит/ Potions, but he doesn’t /не/ want to – everyone knows he’s after Quirrell’s job /работа/. Knows an awful /ужасный/ lot about the Dark Arts /искусства/, Snape.’
Harry watched Snape for a while but Snape didn /А не было/’t look at him again.
At last, the puddings /пудинги/ too disappeared and Professor Dumbledore got to his feet again. The Hall fell silent /бесшумный/.
‘Ahem /гм/ – just a few more words now we are all fed /кормили/ and watered /поливают/. I have a few start-of-term /старт-оф-термина/ /срок/ notices /уведомления/ to give you.
‘First-years should note that the forest in the grounds is forbid /запретить/­den /логово/ to all pupils /зрачки/. And a few of our older /старшая/ students would do well to remember that as well.’
Dumbledore’s twinkling /мерцающий/ eyes flashed /сверкнул/ in the direction of the Weasley twins.
‘I have also been asked by Mr Filch, the caretaker /смотритель/, to remind /напоминать/ you all that no magic should be used between classes /классы/ in the corri /Corri/­dors /DORS/.
‘Quidditch trials /испытания/ will be held in the second week of term /срок/. Anyone interested /заинтересованный/ in playing for their house teams /команды/ should contact /контакт/ Madam Hooch.

‘And finally, I must tell you that this year, the third-floor /третий этаж/ corridor on the right-hand /правая рука/ side is out of bounds /оценки/ to everyone who does not wish /желание/ to die a very painful /болезненный/ death /смерть/.’
Harry laughed /рассмеялся/, but he was one of the few who did.
‘He’s not serious /серьезный/?’ he muttered to Percy.

‘Must be,’ said Percy, frowning /угрожающий/ at Dumbledore. ‘It’s odd, because he usually gives /дает/ us a reason why we’re not allowed to go some­where – the forest’s /леса/ full of dangerous /опасно/ beasts /скот/, everyone knows that. I do think he might have told us Prefects /префектов/, at least.’
‘And now, before we go to bed, let us sing /петь/ the school song /песня/!’ cried Dumbledore. Harry noticed that the other teachers’ smiles /улыбки/ had become /стали/ rather fixed /исправлено/.

Dumbledore gave his wand a little flick /фильм/ as if he was trying to get a fly /летать/ off the end and a long golden /золотой/ ribbon /лента/ flew out of it, which rose high above the tables /таблицы/ and twisted /скрученный/ itself /сам/ snake-like /змеиный/ into words.
‘Everyone pick /выбирать/ their favourite /любимый/ tune /мелодия/,’ said Dumbledore, ‘and off we go!’
And the school bellowed /проревел/:

p.emphasis: Whether /будь то/ we be old and bald /плешивый/
Our heads could do with filling /заполнение/
For now they’re bare /голый/ and full of air,
Dead flies /летит/ and bits /биты/ of fluff /пушок/,
So teach /учат/ us things worth /стоимость/ knowing /знание/,
Just do your best, we’ll do the rest,
And learn until our brains /мозги/ all rot /гниль/.’

section.p: Everybody /все/ finished the song /песня/ at different times. At last, only the Weasley twins were left singing /пение/ along to a very slow /медленный/ funeral /похороны/ march /Март/. Dumbledore conducted /проведены/ their last few lines /линии/ with his wand, and when they had finished, he was one of those who clapped loudest /громче всех/.
‘Ah, music /Музыка/,’ he said, wiping /вытирание/ his eyes. ‘A magic beyond /за/ all we do here! And now, bedtime /время отхода ко сну/. Off you trot /рысь/!’

The Gryffindor first-years followed Percy through the chatter /болтовня/­ing crowds /толпы/, out of the Great Hall and up the marble /мрамор/ staircase. Harry’s legs were like lead /вести/ again, but only because he was so tired /устала/ and full of food /питание/. He was too sleepy /сонный/ even to be surprised /удивленный/ that the people in the portraits /портреты/ along the corridors /коридоры/ whispered and pointed as they passed, or that twice Percy led /светодиод/ them through doorways /дверные проемы/ hidden /скрытый/ behind sliding /скольжение/ panels /панели/ and hanging tapestries /гобелены/. They climbed more staircases /лестничные/, yawning /зевающий/ and dragging /перетаскивание/ their feet, and Harry was just wondering /интересно/ how much further /в дальнейшем/ they had to go when they came to a sudden halt /стой/.

A bundle /сверток/ of walking sticks /палочки/ was floating /плавающий/ in mid-air /в воздухе/ ahead of them and as Percy took a step /шаг/ towards them they started throwing /бросание/ themselves at him.
‘Peeves,’ Percy whispered to the first-years. ‘A poltergeist /полтергейст/.’ He raised his voice, ‘Peeves – show yourself.’
A loud, rude /грубый/ sound, like the air being let out of a balloon /воздушный шар/, answered /ответил/.
‘Do you want me to go to the Bloody /кровавый/ Baron /барон/?’

There was a pop /поп/ and a little man with wicked /злой/ dark eyes and a wide mouth appeared, floating /плавающий/ cross /пересекать/-legged in the air, clutching /вцепившись/ the walking sticks /палочки/.
‘Oooooooh /oooooooh/!’ he said, with an evil /зло/ cackle /кудахтать/. ‘Ickle /ickle/ firsties /firsties/! What fun /весело/!’
He swooped /налетает/ suddenly at them. They all ducked /пригнулся/.
‘Go away, Peeves, or the Baron /барон/’ll hear about this, I mean it!’ barked /рявкнул/ Percy.

Peeves stuck /застрял/ out his tongue /язык/ and vanished /исчез/, dropping /сбрасывание/ the walk­ing sticks /палочки/ on Neville’s head. They heard him zooming /масштабирование/ away, rattling /грохочущий/ coats /пальто/ of armour /броня/ as he passed.

‘You want to watch out for Peeves,’ said Percy, as they set off again. ‘The Bloody /кровавый/ Baron /барон/’s the only one who can control /контроль/ him, he won’t even listen to us Prefects /префектов/. Here we are.’
At the very end of the corridor hung a portrait of a very fat woman in a pink silk /шелк/ dress /платье/.
‘Password /пароль/?’ she said.

‘Caput /капут/ Draconis /Draconis/,’ said Percy, and the portrait swung forward to reveal /выявить/ a round hole in the wall. They all scrambled /вскарабкался/ through it – Neville needed /необходимый/ a leg up – and found themselves in the Gryffindor common room, a cosy /уютный/, round room full of squashy /болотистый/ armchairs /кресла/.

Percy directed /направленный/ the girls /девочки/ through one door to their dormitory /общежитие/ and the boys through another. At the top of a spiral /спираль/ staircase – they were obviously in one of the towers /башни/ – they found their beds /кровати/ at last: five four-posters /четыре плакаты/ hung with deep-red /глубокий красный цвет/ velvet /бархат/ curtains /шторы/. Their trunks /стволы/ had already been brought up. Too tired /устала/ to talk much, they pulled on their pyjamas /пижама/ and fell into bed.
‘Great food /питание/, isn’t it?’ Ron muttered to Harry through the hang /вешать/­ings /ь/. ‘Get off, Scabbers! He’s chewing /жевание/ my sheets /простыни/.’
Harry was going to ask Ron if he’d had any of the treacle /патока/ tart /терпкий/, but he fell asleep almost at once.

Perhaps Harry had eaten /съеденный/ a bit too much, because he had a very strange dream /мечта/. He was wearing Professor Quirrell’s turban, which kept talking to him, telling him he must transfer /перевод/ to Slytherin at once, because it was his destiny /судьба/. Harry told the turban he didn /А не было/’t want to be in Slytherin; it got heavier /тяжелее/ and heavier /тяжелее/; he tried to pull it off but it tightened /ужесточены/ painfully /болезненно/ – and there was Malfoy, laughing /смеющийся/ at him as he struggled /изо всех сил/ with it – then Malfoy turned into the hook-nosed /с крючковатым носом/ teacher /учитель/, Snape, whose /чья/ laugh /смех/ became high and cold – there was a burst of green light and Harry woke /просыпался/, sweating /потение/ and shaking.
He rolled over and fell asleep again, and when he woke /просыпался/ next day, he didn /А не было/’t remember the dream /мечта/ at all.
‘There, look.’
‘Where?’
‘Next to the tall kid /дитя/ with the red hair.’
‘Wearing the glasses?’
‘Did you see his face?’
‘Did you see his scar?’

Whispers /шепоты/ followed Harry from the moment he left his dormi /Dormi/­tory /тори/ next day People queuing /очередями/ outside classrooms /классы/ stood on tiptoe /цыпочки/ to get a look at him, or doubled /двойной/ back to pass /проходить/ him in the corridors /коридоры/ again, staring. Harry wished /пожелал/ they wouldn /Wouldn/’t, because he was trying to concentrate /концентрат/ on finding /обнаружение/ his way to classes /классы/.

There were a hundred and forty /сорок/-two /сорок два/ staircases /лестничные/ at Hogwarts: wide, sweeping /подметание/ ones; narrow /узкий/, rickety /покосившийся/ ones; some that led /светодиод/ some­where different on a Friday /пятница/; some with a vanishing /исчезающий/ step /шаг/ halfway /наполовину/ up that you had to remember to jump /Прыгать/. Then there were doors that wouldn /Wouldn/’t open unless /если/ you asked politely /вежливо/, or tickled /щекотали/ them in exactly the right place, and doors that weren’t really doors at all, but solid /твердый/ walls just pretending /претендующий/. It was also very hard to remember where anything was, because it all seemed to move around a lot. The people in the portraits /портреты/ kept going to visit /посещение/ each other and Harry was sure the coats /пальто/ of armour /броня/ could walk.

The ghosts /призраки/ didn /А не было/’t help, either. It was always a nasty shock when one of them glided /скользили/ suddenly through a door you were trying to open. Nearly Headless /Обезглавленный/ Nick /Ник/ was always happy to point new Gryffindors in the right direction, but Peeves the poltergeist /полтергейст/ was worth /стоимость/ two locked doors and a trick /трюк/ staircase if you met him when you were late for class. He would drop /падение/ waste /отходы/-paper /макулатура/ baskets /корзины/ on your head, pull rugs /коврики/ from under your feet, pelt /шкура/ you with bits /биты/ of chalk /мел/ or sneak /ябеда/ up behind you, invisible /невидимый/, grab /грейфер/ your nose and screech /визг/, ‘GOT YOUR CONK /носище/!’

Even worse than Peeves, if that was possible, was the caretaker /смотритель/, Argus /Аргус/ Filch. Harry and Ron managed to get on the wrong side of him on their very first morning. Filch found them trying to force /сила/ their way through a door which unluckily /к несчастью/ turned out to be the entrance /вход/ to the out-of-bounds /оценки/ /за границами/ corridor on the third floor. He wouldn /Wouldn/’t believe they were lost, was sure they were trying to break into it on purpose /цель/ and was threatening /угрожающий/ to lock /замок/ them in the dungeons /подземелья/ when they were rescued /спасенный/ by Professor Quirrell, who was passing /прохождение/.

Filch owned /находящийся в собственности/ a cat called Mrs Norris, a scrawny /тощий/, dust /пыли/-coloured creature /существо/ with bulging /выпячивание/, lamp-like /Лампа-подобный/ eyes just like Filch’s /Филча/. She patrolled /патрулировали/ the corridors /коридоры/ alone. Break a rule /правило/ in front of her, put just one toe /палец/ out of line, and she’d whisk /метелка/ off for Filch, who’d /кто бы/ appear /появиться/, wheezing /хрипящий/, two seconds later. Filch knew the secret passageways /проходы/ of the school better than anyone (except perhaps the Weasley twins) and could pop /поп/ up as suddenly as any of the ghosts /призраки/. The students all hated /ненавистный/ him and it was the dearest /самый дорогой/ ambition /амбиция/ of many to give Mrs Norris a good kick /удар/.

And then, once you had managed to find them, there were the lessons themselves. There was a lot more to magic, as Harry quickly found out, than waving /размахивающий/ your wand and saying a few funny words.

They had to study /изучение/ the night skies /небо/ through their telescopes /телескопы/ every Wednesday /среда/ at midnight and learn the names /имена/ of different stars /звезды/ and the movements /движения/ of the planets /планеты/. Three times a week they went out to the greenhouses /теплицы/ behind the castle to study /изучение/ Herbology /гербологии/, with a dumpy /коренастый/ little witch called Professor Sprout /росток/, where they learnt /научился/ how to take care /забота/ of all the strange plants /растения/ and fungi /грибы/ and found out what they were used for.

Easily /без труда/ the most boring /скучный/ lesson /урок/ was History /история/ of Magic, which was the only class taught /учил/ by a ghost. Professor Binns /Биннз/ had been very old indeed /в самом деле/ when he had fallen /падший/ asleep in front of the staff /сотрудники/-room fire and got up next morning to teach /учат/, leaving his body behind him. Binns /Биннз/ droned /прогудел/ on and on while they scribbled /нацарапанный/ down names /имена/ and dates /даты/ and got Emeric /Эмерик/ the Evil /зло/ and Uric /мочевой/ the Oddball /чудак/ mixed /смешанный/ up.

Professor Flitwick, the Charms /Чары/ teacher /учитель/, was a tiny little wizard who had to stand on a pile of books to see over his desk /стол письменный/. At the start of their first lesson /урок/ he took the register /регистр/, and when he reached Harry’s name he gave an excited /в восторге/ squeak /писк/ and toppled /свергли/ out of sight.

Professor McGonagall was again different. Harry had been quite right to think she wasn /WASN/’t a teacher /учитель/ to cross /пересекать/. Strict /строгий/ and clever /умная/, she gave them a talking-to /Разговариваю с/ the moment they had sat down in her first class.

‘Transfiguration /видоизменение/ is some of the most complex /сложный/ and dangerous /опасно/ magic you will learn at Hogwarts,’ she said. ‘Anyone messing /Мессинг/ around in my class will leave and not come back. You have been warned /предупреждала/.’

Then she changed her desk /стол письменный/ into a pig /свинья/ and back again. They were all very impressed /впечатленный/ and couldn /не мог/’t wait to get started, but soon realised they weren’t going to be changing /изменения/ the furniture /мебель/ into ani /ани/­mals /Mals/ for a long time. After making a lot of complicated /сложно/ notes /заметки/, they were each given a match and started trying to turn it into a needle /игла/. By the end of the lesson /урок/, only Hermione Granger had made any difference /разница/ to her match; Professor McGonagall showed the class how it had gone all silver and pointy /заостренный/ and gave Hermione a rare /редкий/ smile.

The class everyone had really been looking forward to was Defence /защита/ Against the Dark Arts /искусства/, but Quirrell’s lessons turned out to be a bit of a joke /шутка/. His classroom smelled /пахло/ strongly /сильно/ of garlic /чеснок/, which everyone said was to ward /подопечный/ off a vampire /вампир/ he’d met in Romania /Румыния/ and was afraid /боюсь/ would be coming back to get him one of these days. His turban, he told them, had been given to him by an African /африканец/ prince /принц/ as a thank /спасибо/-you for getting rid /избавиться/ of a troublesome /хлопотный/ zombie /живой мертвец/, but they weren’t sure they believed /Считается,/ this story. For one thing, when Seamus Finnigan /Финниган/ asked eagerly /с нетерпением/ to hear how Quirrell had fought /дрался/ off the zombie /живой мертвец/, Quirrell went pink and started talking about the weather /Погода/; for another, they had noticed that a funny smell hung around the turban, and the Weasley twins insisted /настояла/ that it was stuffed /фаршированный/ full of garlic /чеснок/ as well, so that Quirrell was protected /защищенный/ wher /порога/­ever he went.

Harry was very relieved /облегчение/ to find out that he wasn /WASN/’t miles /миль/ behind everyone else. Lots /много/ of people had come from Muggle families and, like him, hadn’t had any idea that they were witches /ведьмы/ and wizards. There was so much to learn that even people like Ron didn /А не было/’t have much of a head start.
Friday /пятница/ was an important day for Harry and Ron. They finally managed to find their way down to the Great Hall for breakfast without getting lost once.
‘What have we got today?’ Harry asked Ron as he poured /выливали/ sugar /сахар/ on his porridge /овсяная каша/.
‘Double /двойной/ Potions with the Slytherins /слизеринцы/,’ said Ron. ‘Snape’s Head of Slytherin house. They say he always favours /благосклонности/ them – we’ll be able to see if it’s true.’

‘Wish /желание/ McGonagall favoured /благоприятствования/ us,’ said Harry. Professor McGonagall was Head of Gryffindor house, but it hadn’t stopped her giving /дающий/ them a huge pile of homework /домашнее задание/ the day before.

Just then, the post arrived. Harry had got used to this by now, but it had given him a bit of a shock on the first morning, when about a hundred owls had suddenly streamed /потоковый/ into the Great Hall during /в течение/ breakfast, circling /кружить/ the tables /таблицы/ until they saw their owners /владельцы/ and dropping /сбрасывание/ letters and packages /пакеты/ on to their laps /коленей/.

Hedwig hadn’t brought Harry anything so far. She sometimes /иногда/ flew in to nibble /клев/ his ear /ухо/ and have a bit of toast /тост/ before going off to sleep in the owlery /совятню/ with the other school owls. This morning, however, she fluttered /порхали/ down between the marmalade /джем/ and the sugar /сахар/ bowl /миска/ and dropped a note on to Harry’s plate /пластина/. Harry tore /оторвал/ it open at once.
Dear Harry, (it said, in a very untidy /неопрятный/ scrawl /каракули/)

p.emphasis: I know you get Friday /пятница/ afternoons /после обеда/ off, so would you like to
come and have a cup of tea with me around three? I want to hear
all about your first week. Send us an answer back with Hedwig.

section.p: Harry borrowed /заимствованные/ Ron’s quill /полый вал/, scribbled /нацарапанный/ ‘Yes, please, see you later’ on the back of the note and sent Hedwig off again.
It was lucky that Harry had tea with Hagrid to look forward to, because the Potions lesson /урок/ turned out to be the worst /наихудший/ thing that had happened to him so far.

At the start-of-term /старт-оф-термина/ /срок/ banquet /банкет/, Harry had got the idea that Professor Snape disliked /нелюбимое/ him. By the end of the first Potions lesson /урок/, he knew he’d been wrong. Snape didn /А не было/’t dislike /нелюбовь/ Harry – he hated /ненавистный/ him.

Potions lessons took place down in one of the dungeons /подземелья/. It was colder /холоднее/ here than up in the main /главный/ castle and would have been quite creepy /жутко/ enough without the pickled /маринованный/ animals /животные/ floating /плавающий/ in glass jars /банки/ all around the walls.
Snape, like Flitwick, started the class by taking the register /регистр/, and like Flitwick, he paused /приостановлена/ at Harry’s name.
‘Ah, yes,’ he said softly /мягко/, ‘Harry Potter. Our new – celebrity /знаменитость/.’

Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy and his friends Crabbe and Goyle sniggered /хихикнул/ behind their hands. Snape finished calling /призвание/ the names /имена/ and looked up at the class. His eyes were black like Hagrid’s, but they had none of Hagrid’s warmth /тепло/. They were cold and empty and made you think of dark tunnels /туннели/.

‘You are here to learn the subtle /тонкий/ science /наука/ and exact /точный/ art /Изобразительное искусство/ of potion /зелье/-making,’ he began. He spoke in barely /едва/ more than a whisper /шептать/, but they caught every word – like Professor McGonagall, Snape had the gift /подарок/ of keeping /хранение/ a class silent /бесшумный/ without effort /усилие/. ‘As there is little foolish /глупый/ wand-waving /Палочка завивки/ /размахивающий/ here, many of you will hardly believe this is magic. I don’t expect you will really understand the beauty /красота/ of the softly /мягко/ simmering /кипение/ cauldron with its shimmering /мерцающий/ fumes /чад/, the deli /гастроном/­cate /Cate/ power of liquids /жидкости/ that creep /ползать/ through human /человек/ veins /вены/, bewitching /чарующий/ the mind, ensnaring /ensnaring/ the senses /чувств/ ... I can teach /учат/ you how to bottle fame /известность/, brew /заваривать/ glory /слава/, even stopper /пробка/ death /смерть/ – if you aren /Арен/’t as big a bunch /гроздь/ of dunderheads /болванов/ as I usually have to teach /учат/.’

More silence followed this little speech /речь/. Harry and Ron exchanged /обмен/ looks /выглядит/ with raised eyebrows /брови/. Hermione Granger was on the edge of her seat and looked desperate /отчаянный/ to start proving /доказывания/ that she wasn /WASN/’t a dunderhead /тупица/.
‘Potter!’ said Snape suddenly. ‘What would I get if I added powdered /порошкообразный/ root /корень/ of asphodel /златоцветник/ to an infusion /вливание/ of wormwood /горькая полынь/?’

Powdered /порошкообразный/ root /корень/ of what to an infusion /вливание/ of what? Harry glanced /посмотрел/ at Ron, who looked as stumped /озадачены/ as he was; Hermione’s hand had shot into the air.
‘I don’t know, sir,’ said Harry.
Snape’s lips /губы/ curled /курчавый/ into a sneer /насмешка/.
‘Tut /репетит/, tut /репетит/ – fame /известность/ clearly isn’t everything.’
He ignored /игнорируются/ Hermione’s hand.
‘Let’s /Давайте/ try again. Potter, where would you look if I told you to find me a bezoar /безоар/?’

Hermione stretched /растянуты/ her hand as high into the air as it would go without her leaving her seat, but Harry didn /А не было/’t have the faintest /тусклых/ idea what a bezoar /безоар/ was. He tried not to look at Malfoy, Crabbe and Goyle, who were shaking with laughter /смех/.
‘I don’t know, sir.’
‘Thought you wouldn /Wouldn/’t open a book before coming, eh, Potter?’

Harry forced /принудительный/ himself to keep looking straight into those cold eyes. He had looked through his books at the Dursleys’, but did Snape expect him to remember everything in One Thousand Magical Herbs /травы/ and Fungi /грибы/?
Snape was still ignoring /игнорирование/ Hermione’s quivering /дрожащий/ hand.
‘What is the difference /разница/, Potter, between monkshood /аконит/ and wolfs /волки/­bane?’
At this, Hermione stood up, her hand stretching /растягивание/ towards the dungeon /подземелье/ ceiling.
‘I don’t know,’ said Harry quietly. ‘I think Hermione does, though, why don’t you try her?’
A few people laughed /рассмеялся/; Harry caught Seamus’s /Симус-х/ eye and Seamus winked /подмигнула/. Snape, however, was not pleased.

‘Sit /сидеть/ down,’ he snapped at Hermione. ‘For your information /Информация/, Potter, asphodel /златоцветник/ and wormwood /горькая полынь/ make a sleeping /спать/ potion /зелье/ so pow /бух/­erful /вблизи сильных/ it is known as the Draught /проект/ of Living /живой/ Death /смерть/. A bezoar /безоар/ is a stone taken from the stomach /желудок/ of a goat /козел/ and it will save /спасти/ you from most poisons /яды/. As for monkshood /аконит/ and wolfsbane /аконит/, they are the same plant /растение/, which also goes by the name of aconite /аконит/. Well? Why aren /Арен/’t you all copying /копирование/ that down?’
There was a sudden rummaging /рыться/ for quills /перья/ and parchment /пергамент/. Over the noise, Snape said, ‘And a point will be taken from Gryffindor house for your cheek /щека/, Potter.’

Things didn /А не было/’t improve /улучшать/ for the Gryffindors as the Potions lesson /урок/ continued /продолжение/. Snape put them all into pairs /пары/ and set them to mixing /смешивание/ up a simple /просто/ potion /зелье/ to cure /лечение/ boils /фурункулы/. He swept /прокатилась/ around in his long black cloak, watching them weigh /взвешивать/ dried /высушенный/ nettles /крапива/ and crush /раздавить/ snake fangs /клыки/, criticising /критикующий/ almost everyone except Malfoy, whom /кого/ he seemed to like. He was just telling everyone to look at the perfect /идеально/ way Malfoy had stewed /тушеный/ his horned /рогатый/ slugs /слизни/ when clouds /облака/ of acid /кислота/ green smoke /дым/ and a loud hissing /шипение/ filled /заполненный/ the dungeon /подземелье/. Neville had some­how managed to melt /плавиться/ Seamus’s /Симус-х/ cauldron into a twisted /скрученный/ blob /капля/ and their potion /зелье/ was seeping /просачивание/ across the stone floor, burning /сжигание/ holes /отверстия/ in people’s /народный/ shoes /обувь/. Within /в/ seconds, the whole class were standing on their stools /испражнения/ while Neville, who had been drenched /промокший/ in the potion /зелье/ when the cauldron collapsed /развалился/, moaned /простонала/ in pain as angry red boils /фурункулы/ sprang /Sprang/ up all over his arms and legs.

‘Idiot /идиот/ boy!’ snarled /прорычал/ Snape, clearing /клиринг/ the spilled /пролитый/ potion /зелье/ away with one wave /волна/ of his wand. ‘I suppose you added the porcupine /дикобраз/ quills /перья/ before taking the cauldron off the fire?’
Neville whimpered /хныкал/ as boils /фурункулы/ started to pop /поп/ up all over his nose.
‘Take him up to the hospital /больница/ wing /крыло/,’ Snape spat /размолвка/ at Seamus. Then he rounded /закругленный/ on Harry and Ron, who had been working /за работой/ next to Neville.

‘You – Potter – why didn /А не было/’t you tell him not to add /Добавить/ the quills /перья/? Thought he’d make you look good if he got it wrong, did you? That’s another point you’ve lost for Gryffindor.’
This was so unfair /недобросовестный/ that Harry opened his mouth to argue /спорить/, but Ron kicked /ногами/ him behind their cauldron.
‘Don’t push /От себя/ it,’ he muttered. ‘I’ve heard Snape can turn very nasty.’

As they climbed the steps /меры/ out of the dungeon /подземелье/ an hour later, Harry’s mind was racing and his spirits /настроение/ were low. He’d lost two points for Gryffindor in his very first week – why did Snape hate /ненавидеть/ him so much?
‘Cheer up,’ said Ron. ‘Snape’s always taking points off Fred and George. Can I come and meet Hagrid with you?’

At five to three they left the castle and made their way across the grounds. Hagrid lived /жил/ in a small wooden /деревянный/ house on the edge of the Forbidden /запрещено/ Forest. A crossbow /арбалет/ and a pair of galoshes /галоши/ were out­side the front door.
When Harry knocked they heard a frantic /неистовый/ scrabbling /царапали/ from inside and several booming /растущий/ barks /лает/. Then Hagrid’s voice rang /звенел/ out, saying, ‘Back, Fang – back.’
Hagrid’s big hairy /волосатый/ face appeared in the crack /трещина/ as he pulled the door open.
‘Hang /вешать/ on,’ he said. ‘Back, Fang.’
He let them in, struggling /борющийся/ to keep a hold on the collar /воротник/ of an enormous /огромный/ black boarhound /boarhound/.

There was only one room inside. Hams /окороков/ and pheasants /фазаны/ were hanging from the ceiling, a copper /медь/ kettle /чайник/ was boiling /кипение/ on the open fire and in a corner stood a massive /массивный/ bed with a patchwork /пэчворк/ quilt /стегать/ over it.

‘Make yerselves /yerselves/ at home,’ said Hagrid, letting /сдача в аренду/ go of Fang, who bounded /ограниченный/ straight at Ron and started licking /облизывание/ his ears. Like Hagrid, Fang was clearly not as fierce /свирепый/ as he looked.
‘This is Ron,’ Harry told Hagrid, who was pouring /заливка/ boiling /кипение/ water /воды/ into a large teapot /заварочный чайник/ and putting /сдачи/ rock cakes /торты/ on to a plate /пластина/.
‘Another Weasley, eh?’ said Hagrid, glancing /поглядывая/ at Ron’s freckles /веснушки/. ‘I spent half me life chasin /Chasin/’ yer twin /близнец/ brothers away from the Forest.’

The rock cakes /торты/ almost broke their teeth /зубы/, but Harry and Ron pretended /притворился/ to be enjoying /наслаждаясь/ them as they told Hagrid all about their first lessons. Fang rested /отдохнувший/ his head on Harry’s knee /колено/ and drooled /слюни/ all over his robes.
Harry and Ron were delighted /Обрадованный/ to hear Hagrid call Filch ‘that old git /мерзавец/’.

‘An’ as fer that cat, Mrs Norris, I’d like ter introduce /вводить/ her to Fang some time. D’yeh /d'Yeh/ know, every time I go up ter the school, she follows /следует/ me everywhere /везде/? Can’t get rid /избавиться/ of her – Filch puts /путы/ her up to it.’
Harry told Hagrid about Snape’s lesson /урок/. Hagrid, like Ron, told Harry not to worry about it, that Snape liked hardly any of the students.
‘But he seemed to really hate /ненавидеть/ me.’
‘Rubbish /мусор/!’ said Hagrid. ‘Why should he?’
Yet Harry couldn /не мог/’t help thinking that Hagrid didn /А не было/’t quite meet his eyes when he said that.
‘How’s /как это/ yer brother /брат/ Charlie?’ Hagrid asked Ron. ‘I liked him a lot – great with animals /животные/.’

Harry wondered if Hagrid had changed the subject /предмет/ on purpose /цель/. While Ron told Hagrid all about Charlie’s /Чарли/ work with dragons, Harry picked up a piece /кусок/ of paper that was lying on the table under the tea cosy /уютный/. It was a cutting /резка/ from the Daily /ежедневно/ Prophet /пророк/:

p.emphasis: Investigations /исследования/ continue /Продолжать/ into the break-in /взломать/ at Gringotts on 31 July /июль/, widely /широко/ believed /Считается,/ to be the work of dark wizards or witches /ведьмы/ unknown /неизвестный/.
Gringotts’ goblins /гоблины/ today insisted /настояла/ that nothing had been taken. The vault /свод/ that was searched /поиск/ had in fact been emptied /опорожнить/ the same day.
‘But we’re not telling you what was in there, so keep your noses /носы/ out if you know what’s good for you,’ said a Gringotts spokesgoblin /spokesgoblin/ this afternoon.

section.p: Harry remembered /вспомнил/ Ron telling him on the train that someone had tried to rob /грабить/ Gringotts, but Ron hadn’t mentioned /упомянутый/ the date /Дата/.
‘Hagrid!’ said Harry. ‘That Gringotts break-in /взломать/ happened on my birthday! It might’ve /может уже/ been happening /происходит/ while we were there!’

There was no doubt /сомнение/ about it, Hagrid definitely /определенно/ didn /А не было/’t meet Harry’s eyes this time. He grunted /хрюкнул/ and offered /предложенный/ him another rock cake /кекс/. Harry read the story again. The vault /свод/ that was searched /поиск/ had in fact been emptied /опорожнить/ earlier /ранее/ that same day. Hagrid had emptied /опорожнить/ vault /свод/ seven hundred and thirteen /13/, if you could call it emptying /опорожнение/, taking out that grubby /неряшливый/ little package. Had that been what the thieves /воры/ were looking for?

As Harry and Ron walked back to the castle for dinner /ужин/, their pockets /карманы/ weighed /взвешенный/ down with rock cakes /торты/ they’d been too polite /вежливый/ to refuse /отказаться/, Harry thought that none of the lessons he’d had so far had given him as much to think about as tea with Hagrid. Had Hagrid collected /собранный/ that package just in time? Where was it now? And did Hagrid know something about Snape that he didn /А не было/’t want to tell Harry?

Harry had never believed /Считается,/ he would meet a boy he hated /ненавистный/ more than Dudley, but that was before he met Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy. Still, first-year /первый год/ Gryffindors only had Potions with the Slytherins /слизеринцы/, so they didn /А не было/’t have to put up with Malfoy much. Or at least, they didn /А не было/’t until they spotted a notice /уведомление/ pinned /приколол/ up in the Gryffindor common room which made them all groan /стон/. Flying lessons would be starting /начало/ on Thursday /Четверг/ – and Gryffindor and Slytherin would be learning /обучение/ together.
‘Typical /типичный/,’ said Harry darkly /загадочно/. ‘Just what I always wanted. To make a fool /дурачить/ of myself /себя/ on a broomstick in front of Malfoy.’
He had been looking forward to learning /обучение/ to fly /летать/ more than any­thing else.

‘You don’t know you’ll make a fool /дурачить/ of yourself,’ said Ron rea /Субъективная/­sonably /sonably/. ‘Anyway, I know Malfoy’s always going on about how good he is at Quidditch, but I bet that’s all talk.’

Malfoy certainly /безусловно/ did talk about flying a lot. He complained /жаловался/ loudly about first-years never getting in the house Quidditch teams /команды/ and told long, boastful /хвастливый/ stories /истории/ which always seemed to end with him narrowly /узко/ escaping /побег/ Muggles in helicopters /вертолеты/. He wasn /WASN/’t the only one, though: the way Seamus Finnigan /Финниган/ told it, he’d spent most of his childhood /детство/ zooming /масштабирование/ around the countryside /сельская местность/ on his broomstick. Even Ron would tell anyone who’d /кто бы/ listen about the time he’d almost hit a hang /вешать/-glider on Charlie’s /Чарли/ old broom. Everyone from wizarding /волшебников/ families talked /говорили/ about Quidditch con /против/­stantly /янно/. Ron had already had a big argument /аргумент/ with Dean /декан/ Thomas /Томас/, who shared /общий/ their dormitory /общежитие/, about football /футбол/. Ron couldn /не мог/’t see what was exciting /захватывающе/ about a game with only one ball where no one was allowed to fly /летать/. Harry had caught Ron prodding /подталкивания/ Dean /декан/’s poster /плакат/ of West /запад/ Ham /ветчина/ football /футбол/ team, trying to make the players /игроки/ move.

Neville had never been on a broomstick in his life, because his grandmother /бабушка/ had never let him near one. Privately /в частном порядке/, Harry felt she’d had good reason, because Neville managed to have an extra /дополнительный/­ordinary /обычный/ number of accidents /несчастные случаи/ even with both feet on the ground.

Hermione Granger was almost as nervous about flying as Neville was. This was something you couldn /не мог/’t learn by heart out of a book – not that she hadn’t tried. At breakfast on Thursday /Четверг/ she bored /скучающий/ them all stupid with flying tips /чаевые/ she’d got out of a library book called Quidditch through the Ages. Neville was hanging on to her every word, desperate /отчаянный/ for anything that might help him hang /вешать/ on to his broomstick later, but everybody /все/ else was very pleased when Hermione’s lecture /лекция/ was interrupted /прерванный/ by the arrival /прибытие/ of the post.

Harry hadn’t had a single /Один/ letter since Hagrid’s note, something that Malfoy had been quick /быстро/ to notice /уведомление/, of course. Malfoy’s eagle /орел/ owl was always bringing /приведение/ him packages /пакеты/ of sweets /сладости/ from home, which he opened gloatingly /злорадно/ at the Slytherin table.

A barn /сарай/ owl brought Neville a small package from his grand /большой/­mother. He opened it excitedly /азартно/ and showed them a glass ball the size /размер/ of a large marble /мрамор/, which seemed to be full of white smoke /дым/.

‘It’s a Remembrall /remembrall/!’ he explained /объяснил/. ‘Gran /бабуля/ knows I forget things – this tells /говорит/ you if there’s something you’ve forgotten to do. At every turn Harry expected to run into Filch or Mrs Norris, but they were lucky. They sped /ускоренный/ up a staircase to the third floor and tiptoed /цыпочках/ towards the trophy /трофей/ room.

Malfoy and Crabbe weren’t there yet. The crystal /кристалл/ trophy /трофей/ cases /случаи/ glimmered /теплилась/ where the moonlight /лунный свет/ caught them. Cups /чашки/, shields /щиты/, plates /тарелки/ and statues /статуи/ winked /подмигнула/ silver and gold in the darkness /темнота/. They edged /обрезной/ along the walls, keeping /хранение/ their eyes on the doors at either end of the room. Harry took out his wand in case Malfoy leapt in and started at once. The minutes crept by.
‘He’s late, maybe he’s chickened /струсил/ out,’ Ron whispered.
Then a noise in the next room made them jump /Прыгать/. Harry had only just raised his wand when they heard someone speak – and it wasn /WASN/’t Malfoy.
‘Sniff /сопение/ around, my sweet /милая/, they might be lurking /скрываясь/ in a corner.’

It was Filch speaking /Говорящий/ to Mrs Norris. Horror /ужастик/-struck /пораженный/, Harry waved /махал/ madly /безумно/ at the other three to follow him as quickly as possible; they scurried /сновали/ silently /молча/ towards the door away from Filch’s /Филча/ voice. Neville’s robes had barely /едва/ whipped /взбитые/ round the corner when they heard Filch enter /войти/ the trophy /трофей/ room.
‘They’re in here somewhere,’ they heard him mutter /бормотание/, ‘probably hiding /прячется/.’

‘This way!’ Harry mouthed /горлышко/ to the others and, petrified /окаменела/, they began to creep /ползать/ down a long gallery /галерея/ full of suits /костюмы/ of armour /броня/. They could hear Filch getting nearer. Neville suddenly let out a fright /испуг/­ened /ней-/ squeak /писк/ and broke into a run – he tripped /сработал/, grabbed Ron around the waist /Талия/ and the pair of them toppled /свергли/ right into a suit /костюм/ of armour /броня/.
The clanging /лязг/ and crashing /грохот/ were enough to wake /будить/ the whole castle.

‘RUN!’ Harry yelled and the four of them sprinted /помчался/ down the gallery /галерея/, not looking back to see whether /будь то/ Filch was following /следующий/ – they swung around the doorpost /дверной косяк/ and galloped /проскакал/ down one corridor then another, Harry in the lead /вести/ without any idea where they were or where they were going. They ripped /рваные/ through a tapestry /гобелен/ and found themselves in a hidden /скрытый/ passageway /перепускной канал/, hurtled /понесся/ along it and came out near their Charms /Чары/ classroom, which they knew was miles /миль/ from the trophy /трофей/ room.

‘I think we’ve lost him,’ Harry panted /пыхтел/, leaning /склонность/ against the cold wall and wiping /вытирание/ his forehead. Neville was bent double /двойной/, wheezing /хрипящий/ and spluttering /захлебываясь/.
‘I – told – you,’ Hermione gasped, clutching /вцепившись/ at the stitch /стежок/ in her chest /грудь/. ‘I – told – you.’
‘We’ve got to get back to Gryffindor Tower,’ said Ron, ‘quickly as possible.’

‘Malfoy tricked /обманут/ you,’ Hermione said to Harry. ‘You realise /понимать/ that, don’t you? He was never going to meet you – Filch knew someone was going to be in the trophy /трофей/ room, Malfoy must have tipped /наваренный/ him off.’
Harry thought she was probably right, but he wasn /WASN/’t going to tell her that.
‘Let’s /Давайте/ go.’

It wasn /WASN/’t going to be that simple /просто/. They hadn’t gone more than a dozen /дюжина/ paces /шагов/ when a doorknob /дверная ручка/ rattled /гремели/ and something came shoot /стрелять/­ing out of a classroom in front of them.
It was Peeves. He caught sight of them and gave a squeal /визг/ of delight /восторг/.
‘Shut up, Peeves – please – you’ll get us thrown /выброшены/ out.’
Peeves cackled /прокудахтала/.

‘Wandering /блуждающий/ around at midnight, ickle /ickle/ firsties /firsties/? Tut /репетит/, tut /репетит/, tut /репетит/. Naughty /непослушный/, naughty /непослушный/, you’ll get caughty /caughty/.’
‘Not if you don’t give us away, Peeves, please.’
‘Should tell Filch, I should,’ said Peeves in a saintly /безгрешный/ voice, but his eyes glittered /блестели/ wickedly /беззаконно/. ‘It’s for your own good, you know.’
‘Get out of the way.’ snapped Ron, taking a swipe /красть/ at Peeves –this was a big mistake /ошибка/.
‘STUDENTS OUT OF BED!’ Peeves bellowed /проревел/. ‘STUDENTS OUT OF BED DOWN THE CHARMS /Чары/ CORRIDOR!’
Ducking /погружение в воду/ under Peeves they ran for their lives /жизни/, right to the end of the corridor, where they slammed /захлопнула/ into a door – and it was locked.
‘This is it!’ Ron moaned /простонала/, as they pushed helplessly /беспомощно/ at the door. ‘We’re done for! This is the end!’
They could hear footsteps /шаги/, Filch running as fast as he could towards Peeves’s /мозолей-х/ shouts /крики/.
‘Oh, move over,’ Hermione snarled /прорычал/. She grabbed Harry’s wand, tapped /постучал/ the lock /замок/ and whispered, ‘Alohomora /Alohomora/!’
The lock /замок/ clicked /щелкнул/ and the door swung open – they piled /сложено/ through it, shut it quickly and pressed /прессованный/ their ears against it, listening.
‘Which way did they go, Peeves?’ Filch was saying. ‘Quick /быстро/, tell me.’
‘Say “please”.’
‘Don’t mess /беспорядок/ me about, Peeves, now where did they go?’
‘Shan’t /не должен/ say nothing if you don’t say please,’ said Peeves in his annoying /раздражающий/ sing /петь/-song /песня/ voice.
‘All right – please.’

‘NOTHING! Ha /ха/ haaa /HAAA/! Told you I wouldn /Wouldn/’t say nothing if you didn /А не было/’t say please! Ha /ха/ ha /ха/! Haaaaaa /хаааааа/!’ And they heard the sound of Peeves whooshing /свистящий/ away and Filch cursing /чертыхаясь/ in rage /ярость/.

‘He thinks /думает/ this door is locked,’ Harry whispered. ‘I think we’ll be OK /ОК/ – get off, Neville!’ For Neville had been tugging /дергать/ on the sleeve /рукав/ of Harry’s dressing-gown /платье/ /халат/ for the last minute. ‘What?’
Harry turned around – and saw, quite clearly, what. For a moment, he was sure he’d walked into a nightmare /кошмар/ – this was too much, on top of everything that had happened so far.
They weren’t in a room, as he had supposed. They were in a corridor. The forbidden /запрещено/ corridor on the third floor. And now they knew why it was forbidden /запрещено/.

They were looking straight into the eyes of a monstrous /чудовищный/ dog, a dog which filled /заполненный/ the whole space /пространство/ between ceiling and floor. It had three heads. Three pairs /пары/ of rolling /прокатка/, mad eyes; three noses /носы/, twitch /подергивание/­ing and quivering /дрожащий/ in their direction; three drooling /слюнотечение/ mouths /рты/, saliva /слюна/ hanging in slippery /скользкий/ ropes /канаты/ from yellowish /желтоватый/ fangs /клыки/.

It was standing quite still, all six eyes staring at them, and Harry knew that the only reason they weren’t already dead was that their sudden appearance /появление/ had taken it by surprise /сюрприз/, but it was quickly getting over that, there was no mistaking /спутать/ what those thunderous /громовой/ growls /рычание/ meant /имел ввиду/.
Harry groped /ощупью/ for the doorknob /дверная ручка/ – between Filch and death /смерть/, he’d take Filch.

They fell backwards /назад/ – Harry slammed /захлопнула/ the door shut, and they ran, they almost flew, back down the corridor. Filch must have hurried off to look for them somewhere else because they didn /А не было/’t see him anywhere /в любом месте/, but they hardly cared /уход/ – all they wanted to do was put as much space /пространство/ as possible between them and that monster /монстр/. They didn /А не было/’t stop running until they reached the portrait of the Fat Lady /леди/ on the seventh /седьмой/ floor.
‘Where on earth /Земля/ have you all been?’ she asked, looking at their dressing-gowns /халаты/ hanging off their shoulders /плечи/ and their flushed /продували/, sweaty /потный/ faces.

‘Never mind that – pig /свинья/ snout /рыло/, pig /свинья/ snout /рыло/,’ panted /пыхтел/ Harry, and the portrait swung forward. They scrambled /вскарабкался/ into the common room and collapsed /развалился/, trembling /дрожь/ into armchairs /кресла/.
It was a while before any of them said anything. Neville, indeed /в самом деле/, looked as if he’d never speak again.
‘What do they think they’re doing, keeping /хранение/ a thing like that locked up in a school?’ said Ron finally. ‘If any dog needs /потребности/ exercise /упражнение/, that one does.’
Hermione had got both her breath and her bad temper /характер/ back again.
‘You don’t use your eyes, any of you, do you?’ she snapped. ‘Didn /А не было/’t you see what it was standing on?’
‘The floor?’ Harry suggested /предложенный/. ‘I wasn /WASN/’t looking at its feet, I was too busy with its heads.’
‘No, not the floor. It was standing on a trapdoor. It’s obviously guarding something.’
She stood up, glaring /вопиющий/ at them.
‘I hope you’re pleased with yourselves /себя/. We could all have been killed – or worse, expelled. Now, if you don’t mind, I’m going to bed.’
Ron stared after her, his mouth open.
‘No, we don’t mind,’ he said. ‘You’d think we dragged /тащили/ her along, wouldn /Wouldn/’t you?’

But Hermione had given Harry something else to think about as he climbed back into bed. The dog was guarding something ... What had Hagrid said? Gringotts was the safest /безопасный/ place in the world for something you wanted to hide /скрывать/ – except perhaps Hogwarts.
It looked as though Harry had found out where the grubby /неряшливый/ little package from vault /свод/ seven hundred and thirteen /13/ was.

Malfoy couldn /не мог/’t believe his eyes when he saw that Harry and Ron were still at Hogwarts next day, looking tired /устала/ but perfectly /в совершенстве/ cheer­ful /FUL/. Indeed /в самом деле/, by next morning Harry and Ron thought that meeting /встреча/ the three-headed /двуглавый/ /трехголовый/ dog had been an excellent /отлично/ adventure /приключение/ and they were quite keen /острый/ to have another one. In the meantime /то время/, Harry filled /заполненный/ Ron in about the package that seemed to have been moved from Gringotts to Hogwarts, and they spent a lot of time wonder­ing what could possibly /возможно/ need such heavy protection /защита/.
‘It’s either really valuable /ценный/ or really dangerous /опасно/,’ said Ron.
‘Or both,’ said Harry.

But as all they knew for sure about the mysterious /загадочный/ object /объект/ was that it was about two inches long, they didn /А не было/’t have much chance of guessing /угадывание/ what it was without further /в дальнейшем/ clues /ключи/.

Neither /ни/ Neville or Hermione showed the slightest /малейшее/ interest /интерес/ in what lay underneath /под/ the dog and the trapdoor. All Neville cared /уход/ about was never going near the dog again.

Hermione was now refusing /отказывающийся/ to speak to Harry and Ron, but she was such a bossy /властная/ know-it-all /все знают/ that they saw this as an added bonus /бонус/. All they really wanted now was a way of getting back at Malfoy, and to their great delight /восторг/, just such a thing arrived with the post about a week later.

As the owls flooded /затопленный/ into the Great Hall as usual, everyone’s /все это/ attention /внимание/ was caught at once by a long thin package carried /осуществляется/ by six large screech /визг/ owls. Harry was just as interested /заинтересованный/ as everyone else to see what was in this large parcel /пакет/ and was amazed /пораженный/ when the owls soared /париться/ down and dropped it right in front of him, knocking /стук/ his bacon /бекон/ to the floor. They had hardly fluttered /порхали/ out of the way when another owl dropped a letter on top of the parcel /пакет/.
Harry ripped /рваные/ open the letter first, which was lucky, because it said:

p.emphasis: DO NOT OPEN THE PARCEL /пакет/ AT THE TABLE.
It contains /содержит/ your new Nimbus Two Thousand, but I don’t want everybody /все/ knowing /знание/ you’ve got a broomstick or they’ll /они будут/ all want one.
Oliver /Оливер/ Wood will meet you tonight on the Quidditch pitch at seven o’clock /Часы/ for your first training /обучение/ session /сессия/.

section.p: Harry had difficulty /трудность/ hiding /прячется/ his glee /ликование/ as he handed /руками/ the note to Ron to read.
‘A Nimbus Two Thousand!’ Ron moaned /простонала/ enviously /с завистью/. ‘I’ve never even touched /прикоснулся/ one.’

They left the Hall quickly, wanting /желая/ to unwrap /разворачивать/ the broomstick in private /частный/ before their first lesson /урок/, but halfway /наполовину/ across the Entrance /вход/ Hall they found the way upstairs barred /запрещенный/ by Crabbe and Goyle. Malfoy seized the package from Harry and felt it.

‘That’s a broomstick,’ he said, throwing /бросание/ it back to Harry with a mixture /смесь/ of jealousy /ревность/ and spite /озлобленность/ on his face. ‘You’ll be for it this time, Potter, first-years aren /Арен/’t allowed them.’
Ron couldn /не мог/’t resist /оказывать сопротивление/ it.

‘It’s not any old broomstick,’ he said, ‘it’s a Nimbus Two Thousand. What did you say you’ve got at home, Malfoy, a Comet /комета/ Two Sixty /шестьдесят/?’ Ron grinned /ухмыльнулась/ at Harry. ‘Comets /кометы/ look flashy /кричащий/, but they’re not in the same league /лига/ as the Nimbus.’

‘What would you know about it, Weasley you couldn /не мог/’t afford /позволить себе/ half the handle /ручка/,’ Malfoy snapped back. ‘I suppose you and your brothers have to save /спасти/ up, twig /прут/ by twig /прут/.’
Before Ron could answer, Professor Flitwick appeared at Malfoy’s elbow /локоть/.
‘Not arguing /спорить/, I hope, boys?’ he squeaked /пискнула/.
‘Potter’s /гончарное/ been sent a broomstick, Professor,’ said Malfoy quickly.

‘Yes, yes, that’s right,’ said Professor Flitwick, beaming /лучезарный/ at Harry. ‘Professor McGonagall told me all about the special /особый/ circum /циркум/­stances /Stances/, Potter. And what model /модель/ is it?’
‘A Nimbus Two Thousand, sir,’ said Harry, fighting /борьба/ not to laugh /смех/ at the look of horror /ужастик/ on Malfoy’s face. ‘And it’s really thanks to Malfoy here that I’ve got it,’ he added.
Harry and Ron headed /двуглавый/ upstairs, smothering /удушение/ their laughter /смех/ at Malfoy’s obvious /очевидный/ rage /ярость/ and confusion /путаница/.

‘Well, it’s true,’ Harry chortled /хохотнул/ as they reached the top of the marble /мрамор/ staircase. ‘If he hadn’t stolen /похищенный/ Neville’s Remembrall /remembrall/ I wouldn /Wouldn/’t be in the team ...’

‘So I suppose you think that’s a reward /награда/ for breaking /ломка/ rules /правила/?’ came an angry voice from just behind them. Hermione was stomping /топать/ up the stairs /лестница/ looking disapprovingly /неодобрительно/ at the package in Harry’s hand.
‘I thought you weren’t speaking /Говорящий/ to us?’ said Harry.
‘Yes, don’t stop now,’ said Ron, ‘it’s doing us so much good.’
Hermione marched /маршировали/ away with her nose in the air.

Harry had a lot of trouble keeping /хранение/ his mind on his lessons that day. It kept wandering /блуждающий/ up to the dormitory /общежитие/, where his new broom­stick was lying under his bed, or straying /отклоняясь/ off to the Quidditch pitch where he’d be learning /обучение/ to play that night. He bolted /болтовой/ his din /шум/­ner /нер/ that evening without noticing /замечающий/ what he was eating /принимать пищу/ and then rushed /помчался/ upstairs with Ron to unwrap /разворачивать/ the Nimbus Two Thousand at last.
‘Wow /Вау/,’ Ron sighed /вздохнул/, as the broomstick rolled on to Harry’s bed­spread /распространение/.

Even Harry, who knew nothing about the different brooms, thought it looked wonderful /замечательно/. Sleek /гладкий/ and shiny /блестящий/, with a mahogany /красное дерево/ handle /ручка/, it had a long tail of neat /аккуратный/, straight twigs /веточки/ and Nimbus Two Thousand written /написано/ in gold near the top.

As seven o’clock /Часы/ drew /Дрю/ nearer, Harry left the castle and set off towards the Quidditch pitch in the dusk /смеркаться/. He’d never been inside the stadium /стадион/ before. Hundreds of seats /места/ were raised in stands /стенды/ around the pitch so that the spectators /зрителей/ were high enough to see what was going on. At either end of the pitch were three golden /золотой/ poles /столбы/ with hoops /обручи/ on the end. They reminded /напомнил/ Harry of the little plastic /пластик/ sticks /палочки/ Muggle children /дети/ blew /дул/ bubbles /пузырьки/ through, except that they were fifty feet high.

Too eager /нетерпеливый/ to fly /летать/ again to wait for Wood, Harry mounted /смонтированный/ his broomstick and kicked /ногами/ off from the ground. What a feeling – he swooped /налетает/ in and out of the goalposts /Стойки ворот/ and then sped /ускоренный/ up and down the pitch. The Nimbus Two Thousand turned wherever /где бы/ he wanted at his lightest /самый светлый/ touch.
‘Hey /Привет/, Potter, come down!’
Oliver /Оливер/ Wood had arrived. He was carrying /проведение/ a large wooden /деревянный/ crate under his arm. Harry landed next to him.

‘Very nice,’ said Wood, his eyes glinting /сверкают/. ‘I see what McGonagall meant /имел ввиду/ ... you really are a natural /натуральный/. I’m just going to teach /учат/ you the rules /правила/ this evening, then you’ll be joining /присоединение/ team prac /PRAC/­tice /Тайс/ three times a week.’
He opened the crate. Inside were four different-sized /разного размера/ balls /мячи/.
‘Right,’ said Wood. ‘Now, Quidditch is easy enough to under­stand, even if it’s not too easy to play. There are seven players /игроки/ on each side. Three of them are called Chasers /Нарезчики/.’
‘Three Chasers /Нарезчики/,’ Harry repeated /повторный/, as Wood took out a bright red ball about the size /размер/ of a football /футбол/.

‘This ball’s /мячи/ called the Quaffle,’ said Wood. ‘The Chasers /Нарезчики/ throw /бросать/ the Quaffle to each other and try and get it through one of the hoops /обручи/ to score /Гол/ a goal /Цель/. Ten points every time the Quaffle goes through one of the hoops /обручи/. Follow me?’

‘The Chasers /Нарезчики/ throw /бросать/ the Quaffle and put it through the hoops /обручи/ to score /Гол/,’ Harry recited /продекламировал/. ‘So – that’s sort of like basketball /баскетбол/ on broom­sticks /палочки/ with six hoops /обручи/, isn’t it?’
‘What’s basketball /баскетбол/?’ said Wood curiously /странно/.
‘Never mind,’ said Harry quickly.

‘Now, there’s another player /игрок/ on each side who’s /кто/ called the Keeper – I’m Keeper for Gryffindor. I have to fly /летать/ around our hoops /обручи/ and stop the other team from scoring /счет/.’

‘Three Chasers /Нарезчики/, one Keeper,’ said Harry, who was determined /определенный/ to remember it all. ‘And they play with the Quaffle. OK /ОК/, got that. So what are they for?’ He pointed at the three balls /мячи/ left inside the box.
‘I’ll show you now,’ said Wood. ‘Take this.’
He handed /руками/ Harry a small club /клуб/, a bit like a rounders /английская лапта/ bat /летучая мышь/.
‘I’m going to show you what the Bludgers do,’ Wood said. ‘These two are the Bludgers.’

He showed Harry two identical /идентичный/ balls /мячи/, jet /реактивный самолет/ black and slightly /немного/ smaller /меньше/ than the red Quaffle. Harry noticed that they seemed to be straining /деформирование/ to escape /побег/ the straps /ремни/ holding them inside the box.
‘Stand back,’ Wood warned /предупреждала/ Harry. He bent down and freed /освобожденный/ one of the Bludgers.

At once, the black ball rose high in the air and then pelted /забрасывать/ straight at Harry’s face. Harry swung at it with the bat /летучая мышь/ to stop it breaking /ломка/ his nose and sent it zig-zagging /зигзаги/ away into the air – it zoomed /масштаб изображения/ around their heads and then shot at Wood, who dived /нырял/ on top of it and managed to pin /штырь/ it to the ground.

‘See?’ Wood panted /пыхтел/, forcing /форсирование/ the struggling /борющийся/ Bludger /бладжер/ back into the crate and strapping /рослый/ it down safely /безопасно/. ‘The Bludgers rocket /ракета/ around trying to knock /постучать/ players /игроки/ off their brooms. That’s why you have two Beaters /венчики/ on each team. The Weasley twins are ours /наш/ – it’s their job /работа/ to protect /защищать/ their side from the Bludgers and try and knock /постучать/ them towards the other team. So – think you’ve got all that?’

‘Three Chasers /Нарезчики/ try and score /Гол/ with the Quaffle; the Keeper guards /гвардия/ the goalposts /Стойки ворот/; the Beaters /венчики/ keep the Bludgers away from their team,’ Harry reeled /пошатнулся/ off.
‘Very good,’ said Wood.
‘Er – have the Bludgers ever killed anyone?’ Harry asked, hoping he sounded /звучало/ offhand /экспромтом/.

‘Never at Hogwarts. We’ve had a couple /пара/ of broken jaws /пасть/ but nothing worse than that. Now, the last member /член/ of the team is the Seeker. That’s you. And you don’t have to worry about the Quaffle or the Bludgers – ’
‘– unless /если/ they crack /трещина/ my head open.’
‘Don’t worry, the Weasleys are more than a match for the Bludgers – I mean, they’re like a pair of human /человек/ Bludgers them­selves /самости/.’

Wood reached into the crate and took out the fourth /четвертый/ and last ball. Compared /в сравнении/ with the Quaffle and the Bludgers, it was tiny, about the size /размер/ of a large walnut /грецкий орех/. It was bright gold and had little fluttering /вибрация/ silver wings /крылья/.

‘This,’ said Wood, ‘is the Golden /золотой/ Snitch, and it’s the most important ball of the lot. It’s very hard to catch because it’s so fast and difficult to see. It’s the Seeker’s /искателя/ job /работа/ to catch it. You’ve got to weave /ткать/ in and out of the Chasers /Нарезчики/, Beaters /венчики/, Bludgers and Quaffle to get it before the other team’s /команды гостей/ Seeker, because whichever /какой бы ни/ Seeker catches /уловы/ the Snitch wins /победы/ his team an extra /дополнительный/ hundred and fifty points, so they nearly always win /выиграть/. That’s why Seekers /искатели/ get fouled /замутили/ so much. A game of Quidditch only ends /концы/ when the Snitch is caught, so it can go on for ages – I think the record /запись/ is three months /месяцы/, they had to keep bringing /приведение/ on substitutes /заменители/ so the players /игроки/ could get some sleep.
‘Well, that’s it – any questions?’
Harry shook his head. He understood /понимать/ what he had to do all right, it was doing it that was going to be the problem /проблема/.

When they left the dungeons /подземелья/ at the end of Potions, they found a large fir /ель/ tree blocking /блокирование/ the corridor ahead. Two enormous /огромный/ feet sticking /прилипание/ out at the bottom /дно/ and a loud puffing /пыхтящий/ sound told them that Hagrid was behind it.
‘Hi /Здравствуй/, Hagrid, want any help?’ Ron asked, sticking /прилипание/ his head through the branches /ветви/.

‘Would you mind moving /перемещение/ out of the way?’ came Malfoy’s cold drawl /протяжное произношение/ from behind them. ‘Are you trying to earn /зарабатывать/ some extra /дополнительный/ money, Weasley? Hoping to be gamekeeper /егерь/ yourself when you leave Hogwarts, I suppose – that hut of Hagrid’s must seem like a palace /дворец/ compared /в сравнении/ to what your family’s /семьи/ used to.’
Ron dived /нырял/ at Malfoy just as Snape came up the stairs /лестница/.
‘WEASLEY!’
Ron let go of the front of Malfoy’s robes.
‘He was provoked /спровоцированный/, Professor Snape,’ said Hagrid, sticking /прилипание/ his huge hairy /волосатый/ face out from behind the tree. ‘Malfoy was insultin /insultin/’ his family.’

‘Be that as it may, fighting /борьба/ is against Hogwarts rules /правила/, Hagrid,’ said Snape silkily /вкрадчиво/. ‘Five points from Gryffindor, Weasley, and be grateful /благодарный/ it isn’t more. Move along, all of you.’
Malfoy, Crabbe and Goyle pushed roughly /грубо/ past the tree, scatter /разброс/­ing needles /иглы/ everywhere /везде/ and smirking /ухмыляясь/.
‘I’ll get him,’ said Ron, grinding /шлифовка/ his teeth /зубы/ at Malfoy’s back, ‘one of these days, I’ll get him –’
‘I hate /ненавидеть/ them both,’ said Harry, ‘Malfoy and Snape.’
‘Come on, cheer up, it’s nearly Christmas,’ said Hagrid. ‘Tell yeh what, come with me an’ see the Great Hall, looks /выглядит/ a treat /рассматривать/.’
So Harry, Ron and Hermione followed Hagrid and his tree off to the Great Hall, where Professor McGonagall and Professor Flitwick were busy with the Christmas decorations /украшения/.
‘Ah, Hagrid, the last tree – put it in the far corner, would you?’

The Hall looked spectacular /захватывающий/. Festoons /фестоны/ of holly /падуб/ and mistletoe /омела белая/ hung all around the walls and no fewer /меньше/ than twelve towering /возвышающийся/ Christmas trees stood around the room, some sparkling /сверкающий/ with tiny icicles /сосульки/, some glittering /сверкающий/ with hundreds of candles /свечи/.
‘How many days you got left until yer holidays /каникулы/?’ Hagrid asked.
‘Just one,’ said Hermione. ‘And that reminds /напоминает/ me – Harry, Ron, we’ve got half an hour before lunch /обед/, we should be in the library,’

‘You what?’ Hagrid looked shocked /в шоке/. ‘Listen here – I’ve told yeh – drop /падение/ it. It’s nothin /Nothin/’ to you what that dog’s /собаки/ guardin /Guardin/’.’
‘We just want to know who Nicolas Flamel is, that’s all,’ said Hermione.

‘Unless /если/ you’d like to tell us and save /спасти/ us the trouble?’ Harry added. ‘We must’ve /Должно быть/ been through hundreds of books already and we can’t find him anywhere /в любом месте/ – just give us a hint /намек/ – I know I’ve read his name somewhere.’

They had indeed /в самом деле/ been searching /поиск/ books for Flamel’s /Фламель-х/ name ever since Hagrid had let it slip /слип/, because how else were they going to find out what Snape was trying to steal? The trouble was, it was very hard to know where to begin /начать/, not knowing /знание/ what Flamel might have done to get himself into a book. He wasn /WASN/’t in Great Wizards of the Twentieth /двадцатый/ Century /века/, or Notable /примечательный/ Magical Names /имена/ of Our Time; he was missing /отсутствует/, too, from Important Modern /современное/ Magical Discoveries /открытия/, and A Study /изучение/ of Recent /недавний/ Developments /события/ in Wizardry /колдовство/. Hermione took out a list /список/ of subjects /предметы/ and titles /названия/ she had decided to search /поиск/ while Ron strode /зашагал/ off down a row of books and started pulling /тянущий/ them off the shelves /полки/ at random /случайный/. These were the books containing /содержащий/ powerful /мощный/ Dark Magic never taught /учил/ at Hogwarts and only read by older /старшая/ students studying /изучение/ advanced /передовой/ Defence /защита/ Against the Dark Arts /искусства/.
‘What are you looking for, boy?’

Madam Pince /пенсне/ the librarian /библиотекарь/ brandished /размахивали/ a feather /перо/ duster /пыльник/ at him.

Wishing /желающих/ he’d been a bit quicker /быстрее/ at thinking up some story, Harry left the library. They were sure she’d be able to tell them, but they couldn /не мог/’t risk /риск/ Snape hearing /слух/ what they were up to.

Harry waited /подождал/ outside in the corridor to see if the other two had found anything, but he wasn /WASN/’t very hopeful /многообещающий/. They had been look­ing for a fortnight /две недели/, after all, but as they only had odd moments /моменты/ between lessons it wasn /WASN/’t surprising /удивительный/ they’d found nothing. What they really needed /необходимый/ was a nice long search /поиск/ without Madam Pince /пенсне/ breathing /дыхание/ down their necks /шеек/.
Five minutes later, Ron and Hermione joined /присоединился/ him, shaking their heads. They went off to lunch /обед/.
‘You will keep looking while I’m away, won’t you?’ said Hermione. ‘And send me an owl if you find anything.’
‘And you could ask your parents if they know who Flamel is,’ said Ron. ‘It’d /это было/ be safe to ask them.’
‘Very safe, as they’re both dentists /стоматологи/,’ said Hermione.

Once the holidays /каникулы/ had started, Ron and Harry were having too good a time to think much about Flamel. They had the dormitory /общежитие/ to themselves and the common room was far emptier /пустее/ than usual, so they were able to get the good armchairs /кресла/ by the fire. They sat by the hour eating /принимать пищу/ anything they could spear /копье/ on a toasting /тостов/ fork /вилка/ – bread /хлеб/, crumpets /пышки/, marshmallows /зефир/ – and plotting /черчения/ ways /пути/ of getting Malfoy expelled, which were fun /весело/ to talk about even if they wouldn /Wouldn/’t work.

Ron also started teaching /обучение/ Harry wizard chess. This was exactly like Muggle chess except that the figures /цифры/ were alive /в живых/, which made it a lot like directing /руководство/ troops /войска/ in battle /боевой/. Ron’s set was very old and battered /разбитый/. Like everything else he owned /находящийся в собственности/, it had once belonged /принадлежал/ to someone else in his family – in this case, his grandfather /Дед/. However, old chessmen /шахматисты/ weren’t a drawback /недостаток/ at all. Ron knew them so well he never had trouble getting them to do what he wanted.

Harry played /играл/ with chessmen /шахматисты/ Seamus Finnigan /Финниган/ had lent /одолжил/ him and they didn /А не было/’t trust /доверять/ him at all. He wasn /WASN/’t a very good player /игрок/ yet and they kept shouting /крики/ different bits /биты/ of advice /совет/ at him, which was confusing /запутанным/: ‘Don’t send me there, can’t you see his knight /рыцарь/? Send him, we can afford /позволить себе/ to lose him.’

On Christmas Eve /канун/, Harry went to bed looking forward to the next day for the food /питание/ and the fun /весело/, but not expecting /ожидая/ any presents /подарки/ at all. When he woke /просыпался/ early /рано/ next morning, however, the first thing he saw was a small pile of packages /пакеты/ at the foot of his bed.
‘Happy Christmas,’ said Ron sleepily /сонно/ as Harry scrambled /вскарабкался/ out of bed and pulled on his dressing-gown /платье/ /халат/.
‘You too,’ said Harry. ‘Will you look at this? I’ve got some presents /подарки/!’

Harry picked up the top parcel /пакет/. It was wrapped /завернутый/ in thick brown /коричневый/ paper and scrawled /нацарапал/ across it was To Harry, from Hagrid. A second, very small parcel /пакет/ contained /содержащиеся/ a note.

We received /получено/ your message /сообщение/ and enclose /окружать/ your Christmas present /настоящее время/. From Uncle Vernon and Aunt Petunia. Sellotaped /sellotaped/ to the note was a fifty-pence /пенни/ /пятьдесят пенсов/ piece /кусок/.
‘That’s friendly /дружелюбный/,’ said Harry.
Ron was fascinated /очарованный/ by the fifty pence /пенни/.
‘Weird /странный/!’ he said. ‘What a shape /форма/! This is money?’

‘I think I know who that one’s /один это/ from,’ said Ron, going a bit pink and pointing to a very lumpy /комковатый/ parcel /пакет/. ‘My mum. I told her you didn /А не было/’t expect any presents /подарки/ and – oh, no,’ he groaned /простонал/, ‘she’s /она/ made you a Weasley jumper /джемпер/.’
Harry had torn /порванный/ open the parcel /пакет/ to find a thick, hand-knitted /ручная вязка/ sweater /свитер/ in emerald /изумруд/ green and a large box of home-made /самодельный/ fudge /помадка/.
‘Every year she makes /марки/ us a jumper /джемпер/,’ said Ron, unwrapping /разворачивание/ his own, ‘and mine /мой/’s always maroon /темно-бордовый/.’
‘That’s really nice of her,’ said Harry, trying the fudge /помадка/, which was very tasty /вкусно/.
His next present /настоящее время/ also contained /содержащиеся/ sweets /сладости/ – a large box of Chocolate Frogs /лягушки/ from Hermione.
This left only one parcel /пакет/. Harry picked it up and felt it. It was very light. He unwrapped /развернутый/ it.
Something fluid /жидкость/ and silvery /серебристый/ grey went slithering /скользя/ to the floor, where it lay in gleaming /сверкающих/ folds /складки/. Ron gasped.

‘I’ve heard of those,’ he said in a hushed /приглушенный/ voice, dropping /сбрасывание/ the box of Every-Flavour /аромат/ /каждый аромат/ Beans /фасоль/ he’d got from Hermione. ‘If that’s what I think it is – they’re really rare /редкий/, and really valuable /ценный/.’

p.emphasis: Your father left this in my possession /владение/ before he died.
It is time it was returned /возвращенный/ to you.

section.p: There was no signature /подпись/. Harry stared at the note. Ron was admiring /восхищенный/ the Cloak.
‘I’d give anything for one of these,’ he said. ‘Anything. What’s the matter?’
‘Nothing,’ said Harry. He felt very strange. Who had sent the Cloak? Had it really once belonged /принадлежал/ to his father?

Before he could say or think anything else, the dormitory /общежитие/ door was flung /разветвленная/ open and Fred and George Weasley bounded /ограниченный/ in. Harry stuffed /фаршированный/ the Cloak quickly out of sight. He didn /А не было/’t feel like sharing /разделение/ it with anyone else yet.
‘Merry /веселый/ Christmas!’
‘Hey /Привет/, look – Harry’s got a Weasley jumper /джемпер/, too!’
Fred and George were wearing blue jumpers /перемычки/, one with a large yellow /желтый/ F on it, the other with a large yellow /желтый/ G.
‘Harry’s is better than ours /наш/, though,’ said Fred, holding up Harry’s jumper /джемпер/. ‘She obviously makes /марки/ more of an effort /усилие/ if you’re not family.’
‘Why aren /Арен/’t you wearing yours /ваш/, Ron?’ George demanded /потребовал/. ‘Come on, get it on, they’re lovely /прекрасный/ and warm /тепло/.’
‘I hate /ненавидеть/ maroon /темно-бордовый/,’ Ron moaned /простонала/ half-heartedly /нерешительно/ as he pulled it over his head.

‘You haven’t got a letter on yours /ваш/,’ George observed /наблюдаемый/. ‘I suppose she thinks /думает/ you don’t forget your name. But we’re not stupid – we know we’re called Gred /GRED/ and Forge /ковать/.’

Percy Weasley stuck /застрял/ his head through the door, looking disap /disap/­proving /доказывания/. He had clearly come halfway /наполовину/ through unwrapping /разворачивание/ his presents /подарки/ as he, too, carried /осуществляется/ a lumpy /комковатый/ jumper /джемпер/ over his arm, which Fred seized.
