‘I – don’t – want –’ said Percy thickly /хрипло/, as the twins forced /принудительный/ the jumper /джемпер/ over his head, knocking /стук/ his glasses askew /косо/.
‘And you’re not sitting with the Prefects /префектов/ today, either,’ said George. ‘Christmas is a time for family.’
They frog /лягушка/-marched /маршировали/ Percy from the room, his arms pinned /приколол/ to his sides /стороны/ by his jumper /джемпер/.

Harry had never in all his life had such a Christmas dinner /ужин/. A hundred fat, roast /обжиг/ turkeys /индеек/, mountains /горы/ of roast /обжиг/ and boiled /вареный/ pota /Пота/­toes /пальцы/, platters /Жесткие диски/ of fat chipolatas /сардельки/, tureens /супницы/ of buttered /сливочное масло/ peas /горох/, silver boats /лодки/ of thick, rich /богатые/ gravy /подливка/ and cranberry /клюква/ sauce /соус/ – and stacks /стеки/ of wiz /волшебник/­ard /Ард/ crackers /крекеры/ every few feet along the table. These fantastic /фантастика/ crack /трещина/­ers /ERS/ were nothing like the feeble /слабый/ Muggle ones the Dursleys usually bought /купил/, with their little plastic /пластик/ toys /игрушки/ and their flimsy /непрочный/ paper hats /головные уборы/. Harry pulled a wizard cracker /крекер/ with Fred and it didn /А не было/’t just bang /бах/, it went off with a blast /взрыв/ like a cannon /пушка/ and engulfed /поглощенный/ them all in a cloud /облако/ of blue smoke /дым/, while from the inside exploded /взорванный/ a rear /задний/-admiral’s hat and several live, white mice /мышей/. Up on the High Table, Dumbledore had swapped /поменять местами/ his pointed wizard’s /мастера/ hat for a flowered /цветочек/ bonnet /капот/ and was chuckling /посмеиваясь/ merrily /весело/ at a joke /шутка/ Professor Flitwick had just read him.

Flaming /пламенный/ Christmas puddings /пудинги/ followed the turkey /Турция/. Percy nearly broke his teeth /зубы/ on a silver Sickle /серп/ embedded /встроенный/ in his slice /кусочек/. Harry watched Hagrid getting redder /краснее/ and redder /краснее/ in the face as he called for more wine /вино/, finally kissing /целование/ Professor McGonagall on the cheek /щека/, who, to Harry’s amazement /изумление/, giggled /хихикнула/ and blushed /покраснел/, her top hat lop-sided /покосившийся/.

When Harry finally left the table, he was laden /нагруженный/ down with a stack /стек/ of things out of the crackers /крекеры/, including /в том числе/ a pack /пак/ of non-explodable /без взрываемый/, luminous /светящийся/ balloons /надувные шарики/, a grow /расти/-your-own-warts kit /Комплект/ and his own new wizard chess set. The white mice /мышей/ had disappeared and Harry had a nasty feeling they were going to end up as Mrs Norris’ Christmas dinner /ужин/.

Harry and the Weasleys spent a happy afternoon having a furi /фури/­ous /ОЕ/ snowball /снежный шар/ fight /борьба/ in the grounds. Then, cold, wet /влажный/ and gasping /затрудненное дыхание/ for breath, they returned /возвращенный/ to the fire in the Gryffindor common room, where Harry broke in his new chess set by losing /проигрыш/ spectacu /spectacu/­larly /бенно/ to Ron. He suspected /подозреваемый/ he wouldn /Wouldn/’t have lost so badly /плохо/ if Percy hadn’t tried to help him so much.

After a tea of turkey /Турция/ sandwiches /бутерброды/, crumpets /пышки/, trifle /мелочь/, and Christmas cake /кекс/, everyone felt too full and sleepy /сонный/ to do much before bed except sit /сидеть/ and watch Percy chase /гнаться/ Fred and George all over Gryffindor Tower because they’d stolen /похищенный/ his prefect /префект/ badge /значок/.

It had been Harry’s best Christmas day ever. Yet something had been nagging /нытье/ at the back of his mind all day. Not until he climbed into bed was he free to think about it: the Invisibility Cloak and whoever /кто бы ни/ had sent it.

Ron, full of turkey /Турция/ and cake /кекс/ and with nothing mysterious /загадочный/ to bother /беспокоить/ him, fell asleep almost as soon as he’d drawn /вничью/ the curtains /шторы/ of his four-poster /полог/ /плакат/. Harry leant over the side of his own bed and pulled the Cloak out from under it.

His father’s /отец/ ... this had been his father’s /отец/. He let the material /материал/ flow /течь/ over his hands, smoother /гладкой/ than silk /шелк/, light as air. Use it well, the note had said.

He had to try it, now. He slipped /проскользнул/ out of bed and wrapped /завернутый/ the Cloak around himself. Looking down at his legs, he saw only moonlight /лунный свет/ and shadows /тени/. It was a very funny feeling.

Suddenly, Harry felt wide awake /бодрствующий/. The whole of Hogwarts was open to him in this Cloak. Excitement /волнение/ flooded /затопленный/ through him as he stood there in the dark and silence. He could go anywhere /в любом месте/ in this, anywhere /в любом месте/, and Filch would never know.
Ron grunted /хрюкнул/ in his sleep. Should Harry wake /будить/ him? Something held him back – his father’s /отец/ Cloak – he felt that this time – the first time – he wanted to use it alone.
He crept out of the dormitory /общежитие/, down the stairs /лестница/, across the common room and climbed through the portrait hole.
‘Who’s /кто/ there?’ squawked /пронзительно/ the Fat Lady /леди/. Harry said nothing. He walked quickly down the corridor.

Where should he go? He stopped, his heart racing, and thought. And then it came to him. The Restricted /ограниченный/ Section /раздел/ in the library. He’d be able to read as long as he liked, as long as it took to find out who Flamel was. He set off, drawing /Рисование/ the Invisibility Cloak tight /в обтяжку/ around him as he walked.

The library was pitch black and very eerie /сверхъестественный/. Harry lit /освещенный/ a lamp to see his way along the rows /строки/ of books. The lamp looked as if it was floating /плавающий/ along in mid-air /в воздухе/, and even though Harry could feel his arm supporting /поддержки/ it, the sight gave him the creeps /ползает/.

The Restricted /ограниченный/ Section /раздел/ was right at the back of the library. Stepping /шаговый/ carefully over the rope /веревка/ which separated /отделенный/ these books from the rest of the library, he held up his lamp to read the titles /названия/.

They didn /А не было/’t tell him much. Their peeling /шелушение/, faded /утрачен/ gold letters spelled /полба/ words in languages /языки/ Harry couldn /не мог/’t understand. Some had no title /заглавие/ at all. One book had a dark stain /пятно/ on it that looked horribly /ужасно/ like blood. The hairs /волосы/ on the back of Harry’s neck prickled /защипало/. Maybe he was imagining /воображающий/ it, maybe not, but he thought a faint /слабый/ whispering /шепот/ was coming from the books, as though they knew someone was there who shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ be.

He had to start somewhere. Setting /установка/ the lamp down carefully on the floor, he looked along the bottom /дно/ shelf /полка/ for an interesting /интересно/-looking book. A large black and silver volume /объем/ caught his eye. He pulled it out with difficulty /трудность/, because it was very heavy, and, bal /БАЛ/­ancing /ancing/ it on his knee /колено/, let it fall open.

A piercing /пронзительный/, blood-curdling /стынет кровь/ shriek /визг/ split /Трещина/ the silence – the book was screaming /кричащий/! Harry snapped it shut, but the shriek /визг/ went on and on, one high, unbroken /непрерывный/, ear /ухо/-splitting note. Mr Flamel, who celebrated /знаменитый/ his six hundred and sixty /шестьдесят/-fifth birthday last year, enjoys /пользуется/ a quiet life in Devon /девон/ with his wife /жена/, Perenelle /Перенель/ (six hundred and fifty-eight /пятьдесят восемь/ /8/).

section.p: ‘See?’ said Hermione, when Harry and Ron had finished. ‘The dog must be guarding Flamel’s /Фламель-х/ Philosopher’s Stone! I bet he asked Dumbledore to keep it safe for him, because they’re friends and he knew someone was after it. That’s why he wanted the Stone moved out of Gringotts!’
‘A stone that makes /марки/ gold and stops /упоры/ you ever dying /умирающий/!’ said Harry. ‘No wonder Snape’s after it! Anyone would want it.’

‘And no wonder we couldn /не мог/’t find Flamel in that Study /изучение/ of Recent /недавний/ Developments /события/ in Wizardry /колдовство/,’ said Ron. ‘He’s not exactly recent /недавний/ if he’s six hundred and sixty /шестьдесят/-five, is he?’

Next morning in Defence /защита/ Against the Dark Arts /искусства/, while copying /копирование/ down different ways /пути/ of treating /лечения/ werewolf /оборотень/ bites /укусы/, Harry and Ron were still discussing /обсуждение/ what they’d do with a Philosopher’s Stone if they had one. It wasn /WASN/’t until Ron said he’d buy his own Quidditch team that Harry remembered /вспомнил/ about Snape and the coming match.

I’m going to play,’ he told Ron and Hermione. ‘If I don’t, all the Slytherins /слизеринцы/ will think I’m just too scared to face Snape. I’ll show them ... it’ll /это будет/ really wipe /протирать/ the smiles /улыбки/ off their faces if we win /выиграть/.’
‘Just as long as we’re not wiping /вытирание/ you off the pitch,’ said Hermione.

As the match drew /Дрю/ nearer, however, Harry became more and more nervous, whatever /без разницы/ he told Ron and Hermione. The rest of the team weren’t too calm /спокойный/, either. The idea of overtaking /обгон/ Slytherin in the House Championship /чемпионат/ was wonderful /замечательно/, no one had done it for nearly seven years, but would they be allowed to, with such a biased /пристрастный/ referee /судья/?

Harry didn /А не было/’t know whether /будь то/ he was imagining /воображающий/ it or not, but he seemed to keep running into Snape wherever /где бы/ he went. At times, he even wondered whether /будь то/ Snape was following /следующий/ him, trying to catch him on his own. Potions lessons were turning into a sort of weekly /еженедельно/ torture /пытки/, Snape was so horrible to Harry. Could Snape pos /позиция/­sibly /Сибли/ know they’d found out about the Philosopher’s Stone? Harry didn /А не было/’t see how he could – yet he sometimes /иногда/ had the horrible feel­ing that Snape could read minds /умов/.

Harry knew, when they wished /пожелал/ him good luck /везение/ outside the chang /чан/­ing rooms /номера/ next afternoon, that Ron and Hermione were wonder­ing whether /будь то/ they’d ever see him alive /в живых/ again. This wasn /WASN/’t what you’d call comforting /утешительный/. Harry hardly heard a word of Wood’s /Вуда/ pep /бодрость духа/ talk as he pulled on his Quidditch robes and picked up his Nimbus Two Thousand.

Ron and Hermione, meanwhile /между тем/, had found a place in the stands /стенды/ next to Neville, who couldn /не мог/’t understand why they looked so grim /мрачный/ and worried, or why they had both brought their wands to the match. Little did Harry know that Ron and Hermione had been secretly /тайно/ practising /практикующий/ the Leg-Locker /ножка-шкафчик/ Curse /проклятие/. They’d got the idea from Malfoy using /с помощью/ it on Neville, and were ready to use it on Snape if he showed any sign of wanting /желая/ to hurt Harry.
‘Now, don’t forget, it’s Locomotor /двигательный/ Mortis /окоченение/,’ Hermione muttered as Ron slipped /проскользнул/ his wand up his sleeve /рукав/.
‘I know,’ Ron snapped. ‘Don’t nag /пилить/.’
Back in the changing /изменения/ room, Wood had taken Harry aside /в стороне/.

‘Don’t want to pressure /давление/ you, Potter, but if we ever need an early /рано/ capture /захватить/ of the Snitch it’s now. Finish /Конец/ the game before Snape can favour /благоприятствовать/ Hufflepuff too much.’
‘The whole school’s /школы/ out there!’ said Fred Weasley, peering /всматриваясь/ out of the door. ‘Even – blimey /вот это да/ – Dumbledore’s come to watch!’
Harry’s heart did a somersault /кувыркаться/.
‘Dumbledore?’ he said, dashing /лихой/ to the door to make sure. Fred was right. There was no mistaking /спутать/ that silver beard.
Harry could have laughed /рассмеялся/ out loud with relief /облегчение/. He was safe. There was simply /просто/ no way that Snape would dare to try and hurt him if Dumbledore was watching.
Perhaps that was why Snape was looking so angry as the teams /команды/ marched /маршировали/ on to the pitch, something that Ron noticed, too.
‘I’ve never seen Snape look so mean,’ he told Hermione. ‘Look – they’re off. Ouch /ой/!’
Someone had poked /тыкали/ Ron in the back of the head. It was Malfoy.
‘Oh, sorry, Weasley, didn /А не было/’t see you there.’
Malfoy grinned /ухмыльнулась/ broadly /широко/ at Crabbe and Goyle.
‘Wonder how long Potter’s /гончарное/ going to stay on his broom this time? Anyone want a bet? What about you, Weasley?’

Ron didn /А не было/’t answer; Snape had just awarded /награжден/ Hufflepuff a penalty /штраф/ because George Weasley had hit a Bludger /бладжер/ at him. Hermione, who had all her fingers crossed /пересекла/ in her lap /круг/, was squinting /косящий/ fixedly /неподвижно/ at Harry, who was circling /кружить/ the game like a hawk /ястреб/, looking for the Snitch.

‘You know how I think they choose /выберите/ people for the Gryffindor team?’ said Malfoy loudly a few minutes later, as Snape awarded /награжден/ Hufflepuff another penalty /штраф/ for no reason at all. ‘It’s people they feel sorry for. See, there’s Potter, who’s /кто/ got no parents, then there’s the Weasleys, who’ve /которые уже/ got no money – you should be on the team, Longbottom /Лонгботт/, you’ve got no brains /мозги/.’
Neville went bright red but turned in his seat to face Malfoy.
‘I’m worth /стоимость/ twelve of you, Malfoy,’ he stammered /запинаясь/.
Malfoy, Crabbe and Goyle howled /выл/ with laughter /смех/, but Ron, still not daring /отважный/ to take his eyes from the game, said, ‘You tell him, Neville.’
‘Longbottom /Лонгботт/, if brains /мозги/ were gold you’d be poorer /беднее/ than Weasley, and that’s saying something.’
Ron’s nerves /нервы/ were already stretched /растянуты/ to breaking /ломка/ point with anxiety /тревожность/ about Harry.
‘I’m warning /предупреждение/ you, Malfoy – one more word –’
‘Ron!’ said Hermione suddenly. ‘Harry –!’
‘What? Where?’

Harry had suddenly gone into a spectacular /захватывающий/ dive /погружение/, which drew /Дрю/ gasps /вздохи/ and cheers /ура/ from the crowd. Hermione stood up, her crossed /пересекла/ fingers in her mouth, as Harry streaked /с прожилками/ towards the ground like a bullet /пуля/.
‘You’re in luck /везение/, Weasley, Potter’s /гончарное/ obviously spotted some money on the ground!’ said Malfoy.

Ron snapped. Before Malfoy knew what was happening /происходит/, Ron was on top of him, wrestling /борьба/ him to the ground. Neville hesitated /колебался/, then clambered /карабкались/ over the back of his seat to help.

‘Come on, Harry!’ Hermione screamed, leaping /прыгающий/ on to her seat to watch as Harry sped /ускоренный/ straight at Snape – she didn /А не было/’t even notice /уведомление/ Malfoy and Ron rolling /прокатка/ around under her seat, or the scuffles /дерется/ and yelps /визги/ coming from the whirl /завихрение/ of fists /кулаки/ that was Neville, Crabbe and Goyle.

Up in the air, Snape turned on his broomstick just in time to see something scarlet /алый/ shoot /стрелять/ past him, missing /отсутствует/ him by inches – next second, Harry had pulled out of the dive /погружение/, his arm raised in triumph /триумф/, the Snitch clasped /всплеснула/ in his hand.
The stands /стенды/ erupted /извергался/; it had to be a record /запись/, no one could ever remember the Snitch being caught so quickly.

‘Ron! Ron! Where are you? The game’s /об игре/ over! Harry’s won! We’ve won! Gryffindor are in the lead /вести/!’ shrieked /взвизгнул/ Hermione, danc /danc/­ing up and down on her seat and hugging /в обнимку/ Parvati /Парвати/ Patil /Патил/ in the row in front.

Harry jumped off his broom, a foot from the ground. He couldn /не мог/’t believe it. He’d done it – the game was over; it had barely /едва/ lasted /продолжалась/ five minutes. As Gryffindors came spilling /проливая/ on to the pitch, he saw Snape land /земельные участки/ nearby /рядом, поблизости/, white-faced /белолицый/ and tight /в обтяжку/-lipped – then Harry felt a hand on his shoulder and looked up into Dumbledore’s smiling face.

‘Well done,’ said Dumbledore quietly, so that only Harry could hear. ‘Nice to see you haven’t been brooding /задумчивый/ about that mirror ... been keeping /хранение/ busy ... excellent /отлично/ ...’
Snape spat /размолвка/ bitterly /горько/ on the ground.

Harry left the changing /изменения/ room alone some time later, to take his Nimbus Two Thousand back to the broomshed /broomshed/. He couldn /не мог/’t ever remember feeling happier /счастливее/. He’d really done something to be proud /гордый/ of now – no one could say he was just a famous name any more. The evening air had never smelled /пахло/ so sweet /милая/. He walked over the damp /сырость/ grass /трава/, reliving /переживая/ the last hour in his head, which was a happy blur /пятно/: Gryffindors running to lift /лифт/ him on to their shoulders /плечи/; Ron and Hermione in the distance /расстояние/, jumping /прыжки/ up and down, Ron cheer­ing through a heavy nosebleed /носовое кровотечение/.

Harry had reached the shed /сарай/. He leant against the wooden /деревянный/ door and looked up at Hogwarts, with its windows /окна/ glowing /пылающий/ red in the setting /установка/ sun /солнце/. Gryffindor in the lead /вести/. He’d done it, he’d shown /показанный/ Snape ...
And speaking /Говорящий/ of Snape ...

A hooded /закрытый/ figure /фигура/ came swiftly /быстро/ down the front steps /меры/ of the castle. Clearly not wanting /желая/ to be seen, it walked as fast as possible towards the Forbidden /запрещено/ Forest. Harry’s victory /победа/ faded /утрачен/ from his mind as he watched. He recognised /признанное/ the figure /фигура/’s prowling /праздношатание/ walk. Snape, sneaking /подлый/ into the Forest while everyone else was at dinner /ужин/ – what was going on?
Harry jumped back on his Nimbus Two Thousand and took off. Gliding /скольжение/ silently /молча/ over the castle he saw Snape enter /войти/ the Forest at a run. He followed.

The trees were so thick he couldn /не мог/’t see where Snape had gone. He flew in circles /круги/, lower /ниже/ and lower /ниже/, brushing /щетками/ the top branches /ветви/ of trees until he heard voices /голоса/. He glided /скользили/ towards them and landed noiselessly /потихоньку/ in a towering /возвышающийся/ beech /бук/ tree.
He climbed carefully along one of the branches /ветви/, holding tight /в обтяжку/ to his broomstick, trying to see through the leaves.

Below /ниже/, in a shadowy /смутный/ clearing /клиринг/, stood Snape, but he wasn /WASN/’t alone. Quirrell was there, too. Harry couldn /не мог/’t make out the look on his face, but he was stuttering /заикание/ worse than ever. Harry strained /натянутый/ to catch what they were saying.
‘... d-don’t /D-не/ know why you wanted t-t-to /т-т-к/ meet here of all p-places /р-места/ /мест/, Severus /Severus/ ...’
‘Oh, I thought we’d keep this private /частный/,’ said Snape, his voice icy /ледяной/. ‘Students aren /Арен/’t supposed to know about the Philosopher’s Stone, after all.’
Harry leant forward. Quirrell was mumbling /бормотание/ something. Snape interrupted /прерванный/ him.
‘Have you found out how to get past that beast /зверь/ of Hagrid’s yet?’
‘B-b-but /б-но/ /б-б-а/ Severus /Severus/, I –’
‘You don’t want me as your enemy /враг/, Quirrell,’ said Snape, taking a step /шаг/ towards him.
‘I-I /я-я/ don-t /дон-т/ know what you –’
‘You know perfectly /в совершенстве/ well what I mean.’

An owl hooted /загудели/ loudly and Harry nearly fell out of the tree. He steadied /стабилизировался/ himself in time to hear Snape say, ‘– your little bit of hocus /опаивать/ pocus /покус/. I’m waiting.’
‘B-but /б-но/ I d-d-don’t /д-д-не/ /D-не/ –’
‘Very well,’ Snape cut /порез/ in. ‘We’ll have another little chat /чат/ soon, when you’ve had time to think things over and decided where your loyalties /привязанностей/ lie /ложь/.’
He threw his cloak over his head and strode /зашагал/ out of the clearing /клиринг/. It was almost dark now, but Harry could see Quirrell, standing quite still as though he was petrified /окаменела/.
‘Harry where have you been?’ Hermione squeaked /пискнула/.

‘We won! You won! We won!’ shouted Ron, thumping /громадный/ Harry on the back. ‘And I gave Malfoy a black eye and Neville tried to take on Crabbe and Goyle single /Один/-handed /руками/! He’s still out cold but Madam Pomfrey says he’ll be all right – talk about showing /показ/ Slytherin! Everyone’s /все это/ waiting for you in the common room, we’re having a party /вечеринка/, Fred and George stole /украл/ some cakes /торты/ and stuff from the kitchens /кухни/.’
‘Never mind that now,’ said Harry breathlessly /запыхавшись/. ‘Let’s /Давайте/ find an empty room, you wait ’til /сезам/ you hear this ...’
He made sure Peeves wasn /WASN/’t inside before shutting /закрытие/ the door behind them, then he told them what he’d seen and heard.

‘So we were right, it is the Philosopher’s Stone, and Snape’s try­ing to force /сила/ Quirrell to help him get it. He asked if he knew how to get past Fluffy – and he said something about Quirrell’s “hocus /опаивать/-pocus /покус/” – I reckon /рассчитывать/ there are other things guarding the stone apart from Fluffy, loads /грузы/ of enchantments /чары/, probably, and Quirrell would have done some anti-Dark /анти-темно/ Arts /искусства/ spell which Snape needs /потребности/ to break through –’
‘So you mean the Stone’s /Стоуна/ only safe as long as Quirrell stands /стенды/ up to Snape?’ said Hermione in alarm /аварийная сигнализация/.
‘It’ll /это будет/ be gone by next Tuesday /вторник/,’ said Ron.

Quirrell, however, must have been braver /смелее/ than they’d thought. In the weeks /недель/ that followed he did seem to be getting paler /бледнее/ and thin­ner /нер/, but it didn /А не было/’t look as though he’d cracked /треснувший/ yet.

Every time they passed the third-floor /третий этаж/ corridor, Harry, Ron and Hermione would press /Нажмите/ their ears to the door to check /проверить/ that Fluffy was still growling /рычать/ inside. Snape was sweeping /подметание/ about in his usual bad temper /характер/, which surely /конечно/ meant /имел ввиду/ that the Stone was still safe. Whenever /всякий раз, когда/ Harry passed Quirrell these days he gave him an encouraging /обнадеживающий/ sort of smile, and Ron had started telling people off for laughing /смеющийся/ at Quirrell’s stutter /заикание/.

Hermione, however, had more on her mind than the Philosopher’s Stone. She had started drawing /Рисование/ up revision /пересмотр/ time­tables /таблицы/ and colour /цвет/-coding all her notes /заметки/. Harry and Ron wouldn /Wouldn/’t have minded /мыслящих/, but she kept nagging /нытье/ them to do the same.
‘Hermione, the exams /Экзамены/ are ages away.’
‘Ten weeks /недель/,’ Hermione snapped. ‘That’s not ages, that’s like a second to Nicolas Flamel.’
‘But we’re not six hundred years old,’ Ron reminded /напомнил/ her. ‘Anyway, what are you revising /пересмотр/ for, you already know it all.’

‘What am I revising /пересмотр/ for? Are you mad? You realise /понимать/ we need to pass /проходить/ these exams /Экзамены/ to get into the second year? They’re very impor /важ/­tant /Tant/, I should have started studying /изучение/ a month /месяц/ ago, I don’t know what’s got into me ...’

Unfortunately /К сожалению/, the teachers seemed to be thinking along the same lines /линии/ as Hermione. They piled /сложено/ so much homework /домашнее задание/ on them that the Easter /Пасха/ holidays /каникулы/ weren’t nearly as much fun /весело/ as the Christmas ones. It was hard to relax /расслабиться/ with Hermione next to you reciting /читка/ the twelve uses /использования/ of dragon’s /дракона/ blood or practising /практикующий/ wand movements /движения/. Moaning /стонать/ and yawning /зевающий/, Harry and Ron spent most of their free time in the library with her, trying to get through all their extra /дополнительный/ work.

‘I’ll never remember this,’ Ron burst out one afternoon, throw /бросать/­ing down his quill /полый вал/ and looking longingly /нетерпеливо/ out of the library window. It was the first really fine /отлично/ day they’d had in months /месяцы/. The sky was a clear /Чисто/, forget-me-not /незабудка/ blue and there was a feeling in the air of summer /лето/ coming.

Harry, who was looking up ‘Dittany /ясенец белый/’ in One Thousand Magical Herbs /травы/ and Fungi /грибы/, didn /А не было/’t look up until he heard Ron say, ‘Hagrid! What are you doing in the library?’
Hagrid shuffled /перемешиваются/ into view /Посмотреть/, hiding /прячется/ something behind his back. He looked very out of place in his moleskin /молескин/ overcoat /пальто/.

‘Jus /закон/’ lookin /заглянуть/’,’ he said, in a shifty /нечестный/ voice that got their interest /интерес/ at once. ‘An’ what’re /О чем/ you lot up ter?’ He looked suddenly suspicious /подозрительный/. ‘Yer not still lookin /заглянуть/’ fer Nicolas Flamel, are yeh?’
‘Oh, we found out who he is ages ago,’ said Ron impressively /выразительно/. ‘And we know what that dog’s /собаки/ guarding, it’s a Philosopher’s St /улица/—’
‘Shhhh /Shhhh/!’ Hagrid looked around quickly to see if anyone was listening. ‘Don’ go shoutin /shoutin/’ about it, what’s the matter with yeh?’
‘There are a few things we wanted to ask you, as a matter of fact,’ said Harry, ‘about what’s guarding the Stone apart from Fluffy –’

‘SHHHH /Shhhh/!’ said Hagrid again. ‘Listen – come an’ see me later, I’m not promisin /promisin/’ I’ll tell yeh anythin’, mind, but don’ go rabbitin /rabbitin/’ about it in here, students aren /Арен/’ s’posed /s'posed/ ter know. They’ll /они будут/ think I’ve told yeh –’
‘See you later, then,’ said Harry.
Hagrid shuffled /перемешиваются/ off.
‘What was he hiding /прячется/ behind his back?’ said Hermione thought­fully /в полной мере/.
‘Do you think it had anything to do with the Stone?’

‘I’m going to see what section /раздел/ he was in,’ said Ron, who’d /кто бы/ had enough of working /за работой/. He came back a minute later with a pile of books in his arms and slammed /захлопнула/ them down on the table.

‘Dragons!’ he whispered. ‘Hagrid was looking up stuff about dragons! Look at these: Dragon Species /вид/ of Great Britain /Британия/ and Ireland /Ирландия/; From Egg /яйцо/ to Inferno /ад/, A Dragon Keeper’s /хранителя/ Guide /руководство/.’
‘Hagrid’s always wanted a dragon, he told me so the first time I ever met him,’ said Harry.

‘But it’s against our laws /законы/,’ said Ron. ‘Dragon-breeding /дракона разведение/ was out­lawed /lawed/ by the Warlocks /колдуны/’ Convention /условность/ of 1709, everyone knows that. It’s hard to stop Muggles noticing /замечающий/ us if we’re keeping /хранение/ dragons in the back garden /сад/ – anyway, you can’t tame /приручать/ dragons, it’s danger /Опасность/­ous /ОЕ/. You should see the burns /ожоги/ Charlie’s /Чарли/ got off wild ones in Romania /Румыния/.’
‘But there aren /Арен/’t wild dragons in Britain /Британия/?’ said Harry.

‘Of course there are,’ said Ron. ‘Common Welsh /валлийский/ Green and Hebridean /Hebridean/ Blacks /негры/. The Ministry /министерство/ of Magic has a job /работа/ hushing /замалчивание/ them up, I can tell you. Our lot have to keep putting /сдачи/ spells /заклинания/ on Muggles who’ve /которые уже/ spotted them, to make them forget.’
‘So what on earth /Земля/’s Hagrid up to?’ said Hermione.

When they knocked on the door of the gamekeeper /егерь/’s hut an hour later, they were surprised /удивленный/ to see that all the curtains /шторы/ were closed /закрыто/. Hagrid called, ‘Who is it?’ before he let them in and then shut the door quickly behind them.

It was stiflingly /душно/ hot /горячий/ inside. Even though it was such a warm /тепло/ day, there was a blazing /полыхающий/ fire in the grate /решетка/. Hagrid made them tea and offered /предложенный/ them stoat /горностай/ sandwiches /бутерброды/, which they refused /отказалась/.
‘So – yeh wanted to ask me somethin /Somethin/’?’
‘Yes,’ said Harry. There was no point beating /битье/ about the bush /куст/. ‘We were wondering /интересно/ if you could tell us what’s guarding the Philosopher’s Stone apart from Fluffy.’
Hagrid frowned /нахмурился/ at him.

‘O’ course I can’t,’ he said. ‘Number one, I don’ know meself /meself/. Number two, yeh know too much already, so I wouldn /Wouldn/’ tell yeh if I could. That Stone’s /Стоуна/ here fer a good reason. It was almost stolen /похищенный/ outta /убираться/ Gringotts – I s’pose /поза/ /s'pose /поза// yeh’ve /yeh've/ worked /работал/ that out an’ all? Beats /биения/ me how yeh even know abou /Abou/’ Fluffy.’

‘Oh, come on, Hagrid, you might not want to tell us, but you do know, you know everything that goes on round here,’ said Hermione in a warm /тепло/, flattering /лестный/ voice. Hagrid’s beard twitched /дернулись/ and they could tell he was smiling. ‘We only wondered who had done the guarding, really.’ Hermione went on. ‘We wondered who Dumbledore had trusted /доверенный/ enough to help him, apart from you.’
Hagrid’s chest /грудь/ swelled /набухать/ at these last words. Harry and Ron beamed /балочные/ at Hermione.

‘Well, I don’ s’pose /поза/ /s'pose /поза// it could hurt ter tell yeh that ... let’s /Давайте/ see ... he borrowed /заимствованные/ Fluffy from me ... then some o’ the teachers did enchantments /чары/ ... Professor Sprout /росток/ – Professor Flitwick – Professor McGonagall –’ he ticked /тикали/ them off on his fingers, ‘Professor Quirrell – an’ Dumbledore himself did somethin /Somethin/’, o’ course. Hang /вешать/ on, I’ve forgotten someone. Oh yeah, Professor Snape.’
‘Yeah – yer not still on abou /Abou/’ that, are yeh? Look, Snape helped /помог/ protect /защищать/ the Stone, he’s not about ter steal it.’

Harry knew Ron and Hermione were thinking the same as he was. If Snape had been in on protecting /защищающий/ the Stone, it must have been easy to find out how the other teachers had guarded /охраняемый/ it. He probably knew everything – except, it seemed, Quirrell’s spell and how to get past Fluffy.
‘You’re the only one who knows how to get past Fluffy, aren /Арен/’t you, Hagrid?’ said Harry anxiously /с тревогой/. ‘And you wouldn /Wouldn/’t tell anyone, would you? Not even one of the teachers?’
‘Not a soul /душа/ knows except me an’ Dumbledore,’ said Hagrid proudly /гордо/.
‘Well, that’s something,’ Harry muttered to the others. ‘Hagrid, can we have a window open? I’m boiling /кипение/.’
‘Can’t, Harry, sorry,’ said Hagrid. Harry noticed him glance /взгляд/ at the fire. Harry looked at it, too.
‘Hagrid – what’s that?’
But he already knew what it was. In the very heart of the fire, underneath /под/ the kettle /чайник/, was a huge, black egg /яйцо/.
‘Ah,’ said Hagrid, fiddling /пустячный/ nervously with his beard. ‘That’s – er ...’
‘Where did you get it, Hagrid?’ said Ron, crouching /Крадущийся/ over the fire to get a closer look at the egg /яйцо/. ‘It must’ve /Должно быть/ cost /Стоимость/ you a fortune /состояние/.’

‘Won it,’ said Hagrid. ‘Las /лас/’ night. I was down in the village /деревня/ havin /Хавин/’ a few drinks /напитки/ an’ got into a game o’ cards /карты/ with a stranger /незнакомец/. Think he was quite glad ter get rid /избавиться/ of it, ter be honest /честный/.’
‘But what are you going to do with it when it’s hatched /вылупились/?’ said Hermione.

‘Well, I’ve bin doin /делаешь/’ some readin /читаешь/’,’ said Hagrid, pulling /тянущий/ a large book from under his pillow /подушка/. ‘Got this outta /убираться/ the library – Dragon-Breeding /дракона разведение/ for Pleasure /удовольствие/ and Profit /прибыль/ – it’s a bit outta /убираться/ date /Дата/, o’ course, but it’s all in here. Keep the egg /яйцо/ in the fire, ’cause /причина/ their mothers /матери/ breathe /дышать/ on ’em, see, an’ when it hatches /люки/, feed /корм/ it on a bucket /ведро/ o’ brandy /бренди/ mixed /смешанный/ with chicken /курица/ blood every half hour. An’ see here – how ter recognise /признать/ diff’rent /diff'rent/ eggs /яйца/ – what I got there’s a Norwegian /Норвежский/ Ridgeback /риджбек/. They’re rare /редкий/, them.’
He looked very pleased with himself, but Hermione didn /А не было/’t.
‘Hagrid, you live in a wooden /деревянный/ house,’ she said.
But Hagrid wasn /WASN/’t listening. He was humming /гудящий/ merrily /весело/ as he stoked /топил/ the fire.
So now they had something else to worry about: what might hap /случаться/­pen /ручка/ to Hagrid if anyone found out he was hiding /прячется/ an illegal /нелегальный/ dragon in his hut.

‘Wonder what it’s like to have a peaceful /мирное/ life,’ Ron sighed /вздохнул/, as evening after evening they struggled /изо всех сил/ through all the extra /дополнительный/ home­work they were getting. Hermione had now started making revi /Реви/­sion /Sion/ timetables /расписания/ for Harry and Ron, too. It was driving /вождение/ them mad.
Then, one breakfast time, Hedwig brought Harry another note from Hagrid. He had written /написано/ only two words: It’s hatching /штриховка/.
Ron wanted to skip /пропускать/ Herbology /гербологии/ and go straight down to the hut. Hermione wouldn /Wouldn/’t hear of it.
‘Hermione, how many times in our lives /жизни/ are we going to see a dragon hatching /штриховка/?’
‘We’ve got lessons, we’ll get into trouble, and that’s nothing to what Hagrid’s going to be in when someone finds /находки/ out what he’s doing –’
‘Shut up!’ Harry whispered.
Malfoy was only a few feet away and he had stopped dead to listen. How much had he heard? Harry didn /А не было/’t like the look on Malfoy’s face at all.

Ron and Hermione argued /утверждал/ all the way to Herbology /гербологии/, and in the end, Hermione agreed /согласовано/ to run down to Hagrid’s with the other two during /в течение/ morning break. When the bell /колокол/ sounded /звучало/ from the castle at the end of their lesson /урок/, the three of them dropped their trowels /мастерки/ at once and hurried through the grounds to the edge of the Forest. Hagrid greeted /встречено/ them looking flushed /продували/ and excited /в восторге/.
‘It’s nearly out.’ He ushered /возвестило/ them inside.
The egg /яйцо/ was lying on the table. There were deep cracks /трещины/ in it. Something was moving /перемещение/ inside; a funny clicking /щелкающий/ noise was coming from it.
They all drew /Дрю/ their chairs /стулья/ up to the table and watched with bated /затаив/ breath.

All at once there was a scraping /выскабливание/ noise and the egg /яйцо/ split /Трещина/ open. The baby /детка/ dragon flopped /шлепнулся/ on to the table. It wasn /WASN/’t exactly pretty /Симпатичная/; Harry thought it looked like a crumpled /мятый/, black umbrella /зонтик/. Its spiny /колючий/ wings /крылья/ were huge compared /в сравнении/ to its skinny /тощий/ jet /реактивный самолет/ body and it had a long snout /рыло/ with wide nostrils /ноздри/, stubs /заглушки/ of horns /рога/ and bulging /выпячивание/, orange /оранжевый/ eyes.
It sneezed /чихнул/. A couple /пара/ of sparks /искры/ flew out of its snout /рыло/.
‘Isn’t he beautiful /красивая/?’ Hagrid murmured /бормотал/. He reached out a hand to stroke /Инсульт/ the dragon’s /дракона/ head. It snapped at his fingers, showing /показ/ pointed fangs /клыки/.
‘Bless /благословить/ him, look, he knows his mummy /Мама/!’ said Hagrid.
‘Hagrid,’ said Hermione, ‘how fast do Norwegian /Норвежский/ Ridgebacks /Ridgebacks/ grow /расти/, exactly?’
Hagrid was about to answer when the colour /цвет/ suddenly drained /осушенных/ from his face – he leapt to his feet and ran to the window.
‘What’s the matter?’
‘Someone was lookin /заглянуть/’ through the gap /разрыв/ in the curtains /шторы/ – it’s a kid /дитя/ – he’s runnin /убегающий/’ back up ter the school.’
Harry bolted /болтовой/ to the door and looked out. Even at a distance /расстояние/ there was no mistaking /спутать/ him.
Malfoy had seen the dragon.

Something about the smile lurking /скрываясь/ on Malfoy’s face during /в течение/ the next week made Harry, Ron and Hermione very nervous. They spent most of their free time in Hagrid’s darkened /затемненный/ hut, trying to reason with him.
‘Just let him go,’ Harry urged /настоятельно/. ‘Set him free.’
‘I can’t,’ said Hagrid. ‘He’s too little. He’d die.’

They looked at the dragon. It had grown /взрослый/ three times in length /длина/ in just a week. Smoke /дым/ kept furling /закрутки/ out of its nostrils /ноздри/. Hagrid hadn’t been doing his gamekeeping /охотничьего промысла/ duties /обязанности/ because the dragon was keep­ing him so busy. There were empty brandy /бренди/ bottles /бутылки/ and chicken /курица/ feathers /перья/ all over the floor.
‘I’ve decided to call him Norbert,’ said Hagrid, looking at the dragon with misty /туманный/ eyes. ‘He really knows me now, watch. Norbert! Norbert! Where’s /где/ Mummy /Мама/?’
‘He’s lost his marbles /мраморы/,’ Ron muttered in Harry’s ear /ухо/.
‘Hagrid,’ said Harry loudly, ‘give it a fortnight /две недели/ and Norbert’s /Норберт/ going to be as long as your house. Malfoy could go to Dumbledore at any moment.’
Hagrid bit his lip /губа/.
‘I – I know I can’t keep him for ever, but I can’t jus /закон/’ dump /свалка/ him, I can’t.’
Harry suddenly turned to Ron.
‘Charlie,’ he said.
‘You’re losing /проигрыш/ it, too,’ said Ron. ‘I’m Ron, remember?’
‘No – Charlie – your brother /брат/ Charlie. In Romania /Румыния/. Studying /изучение/ dragons. We could send Norbert to him. Charlie can take care /забота/ of him and then put him back in the wild!’
‘Brilliant /блестящий/!’ said Ron. ‘How about it, Hagrid?’
And in the end, Hagrid agreed /согласовано/ that they could send an owl to Charlie to ask him.

The following /следующий/ week dragged /тащили/ by. Wednesday /среда/ night found Hermione and Harry sitting alone in the common room, long after everyone else had gone to bed. The clock /Часы/ on the wall had just chimed /Чимед/ midnight when the portrait hole burst open. Ron appeared out of nowhere /нигде/ as he pulled off Harry’s Invisibility Cloak. He had been down at Hagrid’s hut, helping /помощь/ him feed /корм/ Norbert, who was now eating /принимать пищу/ dead rats /крысы/ by the crate.

‘It bit me!’ he said, showing /показ/ them his hand, which was wrapped /завернутый/ in a bloody /кровавый/ handkerchief /носовой платок/. ‘I’m not going to be able to hold a quill /полый вал/ for a week. I tell you, that dragon’s /дракона/ the most horrible animal /животное/ I’ve ever met, but the way Hagrid goes on about it, you’d think it was a fluffy little bunny /кролик/ rabbit /кролик/. When it bit me he told me off for frightening /пугающий/ it. And when I left, he was singing /пение/ it a lullaby /Колыбельная/.’
There was a tap /нажмите/ on the dark window.
‘It’s Hedwig!’ said Harry, hurrying /торопясь/ to let her in. ‘She’ll /оболочка/ have Charlie’s /Чарли/ answer!’
The three of them put their heads together to read the note.

p.emphasis: How are you? Thanks for the letter – I’d he glad to take the Norwegian /Норвежский/ Ridgeback /риджбек/, but it won’t be easy getting him here. I think the best thing will be to send him over with some friends of mine /мой/ who are coming to visit /посещение/ me next week. Trouble is, they mustn’t /нельзя/ be seen carrying /проведение/ an illegal /нелегальный/ dragon.
Could you get the Ridgeback /риджбек/ up the tallest /Самый высокий/ tower at midnight on Saturday /суббота/? They can meet you there and take him away while it’s still dark.
Send me an answer as soon as possible.

section.p: They looked at each other.
‘We’ve got the Invisibility Cloak,’ said Harry. ‘It shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ be too difficult – I think the Cloak’s /плаща/ big enough to cover /обложка/ two of us and Norbert.’
It was a mark /отметка/ of how bad the last week had been that the other two agreed /согласовано/ with him. Anything to get rid /избавиться/ of Norbert – and Malfoy.

There was a hitch /заминка/. By next morning, Ron’s bitten /укушенный/ hand had swollen /вздутый/ to twice its usual size /размер/. He didn /А не было/’t know whether /будь то/ it was safe to go to Madam Pomfrey – would she recognise /признать/ a dragon bite /укусить/? By the afternoon, though, he had no choice /выбор/. The cut /порез/ had turned a nasty shade /тень/ of green. It looked as if Norbert’s /Норберт/ fangs /клыки/ were poiso /poiso/­nous /сметка/.
Harry and Hermione rushed /помчался/ up to the hospital /больница/ wing /крыло/ at the end of the day to find Ron in a terrible state /государство/ in bed.

‘It’s not just my hand,’ he whispered, ‘although that feels /чувствует/ like it’s about to fall off. Malfoy told Madam Pomfrey he wanted to bor /бора/­row one of my books so he could come and have a good laugh /смех/ at me. He kept threatening /угрожающий/ to tell her what really bit me – I’ve told her it was a dog but I don’t think she believes /считает/ me – I shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ have hit him at the Quidditch match, that’s why he’s doing this.’
Harry and Hermione tried to calm /спокойный/ Ron down.

‘It’ll /это будет/ all be over at midnight on Saturday /суббота/,’ said Hermione, but this didn /А не было/’t soothe /успокаивать/ Ron at all. On the contrary /вопреки/, he sat bolt /болт/ upright /вертикально/ and broke into a sweat /пот/.

‘Midnight on Saturday /суббота/!’ he said in a hoarse /хриплый/ voice. ‘Oh no – oh no – I’ve just remembered /вспомнил/ – Charlie’s /Чарли/ letter was in that book Malfoy took, he’s going to know we’re getting rid /избавиться/ of Norbert.’
Harry and Hermione didn /А не было/’t get a chance to answer. Madam Pomfrey came over at that moment and made them leave, saying Ron needed /необходимый/ sleep.

‘It’s too late to change /изменение/ the plan /план/ now,’ Harry told Hermione. ‘We haven’t got time to send Charlie another owl and this could be our only chance to get rid /избавиться/ of Norbert. We’ll have to risk /риск/ it. And we have got the Invisibility Cloak, Malfoy doesn’t /не/ know about that.’
They found Fang the boarhound /boarhound/ sitting outside with a ban /запрет/­daged /daged/ tail when they went to tell Hagrid, who opened a window to talk to them.
‘I won’t let you in,’ he puffed /запыхавшийся/. ‘Norbert’s /Норберт/ at a tricky /запутанный/ stage /сцена/ – noth /Noth/­in’ I can’t handle /ручка/.’
When they told him about Charlie’s /Чарли/ letter, his eyes filled /заполненный/ with tears /слезы/, although that might have been because Norbert had just bitten /укушенный/ him on the leg.
‘Aargh /Aargh/! It’s all right, he only got my boot /ботинок/ – jus /закон/’ playin /Playin/’ – he’s only a baby /детка/, after all.’

The baby /детка/ banged /ударилась/ its tail on the wall, making the windows /окна/ rattle /погремушка/. Harry and Hermione walked back to the castle, feeling Saturday /суббота/ couldn /не мог/’t come quickly enough.

They would have felt sorry for Hagrid when the time came for him to say goodbye /Прощай/ to Norbert if they hadn’t been so worried about what they had to do. It was a very dark, cloudy /облачный/ night and they were a bit late arriving /прибывающий/ at Hagrid’s hut because they’d had to wait for Peeves to get out of their way in the Entrance /вход/ Hall, where he’d been playing tennis /большой теннис/ against the wall.
Hagrid had Norbert packed /уплотненный/ and ready in a large crate.

‘He’s got lots /много/ o’ rats /крысы/ an’ some brandy /бренди/ fer the journey /поездка/,’ said Hagrid in a muffled /заглушенный/ voice. ‘An’ I’ve packed /уплотненный/ his teddy /Тедди/ bear /медведь/ in case he gets /получает/ lonely /Одинокий/.’
From inside the crate came ripping /потрясающий/ noises /шумы/ that sounded /звучало/ to Harry as though teddy /Тедди/ was having his head torn /порванный/ off.

‘Bye /пока/-bye /пока/, Norbert!’ Hagrid sobbed /всхлипывала/, as Harry and Hermione cov /сОУ/­ered /Ered/ the crate with the Invisibility Cloak and stepped underneath /под/ it themselves. ‘Mummy /Мама/ will never forget you!’

How they managed to get the crate back up to the castle, they never knew. Midnight ticked /тикали/ nearer as they heaved /вздымалась/ Norbert up the marble /мрамор/ staircase in the Entrance /вход/ Hall and along the dark corri /Corri/­dors /DORS/. Up another staircase, then another – even one of Harry’s short /короткая/ cuts /порезы/ didn /А не было/’t make the work much easier /Полегче/.
‘Nearly there!’ Harry panted /пыхтел/ as they reached the corridor beneath /под/ the tallest /Самый высокий/ tower.

Then a sudden movement /движение/ ahead of them made them almost drop /падение/ the crate. Forgetting /забывая/ that they were already invisible /невидимый/, they shrank /сжался/ into the shadows /тени/, staring at the dark outlines /контуры/ of two people grappling /борется/ with each other ten feet away. A lamp flared /расклешенные/.
Professor McGonagall, in a tartan /шотландка/ dressing-gown /платье/ /халат/ and a hairnet /сетка для волос/, had Malfoy by the ear /ухо/.
‘Detention /задержание/!’ she shouted. ‘And twenty /20/ points from Slytherin! Wandering /блуждающий/ around in the middle of the night, how dare you –’
‘You don’t understand, Professor, Harry Potter’s /гончарное/ coming – he’s got a dragon!’
‘What utter /выговорить/ rubbish /мусор/! How dare you tell such lies /вранье/! Come on – I shall /должен/ see Professor Snape about you, Malfoy!’

The steep /крутой/ spiral /спираль/ staircase up to the top of the tower seemed the easiest /простой/ thing in the world after that. Not until they’d stepped out into the cold night air did they throw /бросать/ off the Cloak, glad to be able to breathe /дышать/ properly /должным образом/ again. Hermione did a sort of jig /кондуктор/.
‘Malfoy’s got detention /задержание/! I could sing /петь/!’
‘Don’t,’ Harry advised /рекомендуется/ her.

Chuckling /посмеиваясь/ about Malfoy, they waited /подождал/, Norbert thrashing /порка/ about in his crate. About ten minutes later, four broomsticks /метлы/ came swooping /парящий/ down out of the darkness /темнота/.

Charlie’s /Чарли/ friends were a cheery /бодрый/ lot. They showed Harry and Hermione the harness /упряжь/ they’d rigged /подстроенный/ up, so they could suspend /приостановить/ Norbert between them. They all helped /помог/ buckle /пряжка/ Norbert safely /безопасно/ into it and then Harry and Hermione shook hands with the others and thanked /поблагодарил/ them very much.
At last, Norbert was going ... going ... gone.

They slipped /проскользнул/ back down the spiral /спираль/ staircase, their hearts /сердца/ as light as their hands, now that Norbert was off them. No more dragon – Malfoy in detention /задержание/ – what could spoil /портить/ their happiness /счастье/?
The answer to that was waiting at the foot of the stairs /лестница/. As they stepped into the corridor, Filch’s /Филча/ face loomed /маячили/ suddenly out of the darkness /темнота/.
‘Well, well, well,’ he whispered, ‘we are in trouble.’
They’d left the Invisibility Cloak on top of the tower.
Things couldn /не мог/’t have been worse.

Filch took them down to Professor McGonagall’s /МакГонагалл/ study /изучение/ on the first floor, where they sat and waited /подождал/ without saying a word to each other. Hermione was trembling /дрожь/. Excuses /предлоги/, alibis /алиби/ and wild cover /обложка/-up stories /истории/ chased /преследовали/ each other around Harry’s brain /головной мозг/, each more feeble /слабый/ than the last. He couldn /не мог/’t see how they were going to get out of trouble this time. They were cornered /с углами/. How could they have been so stupid as to forget the Cloak? There was no reason on earth /Земля/ that Professor McGonagall would accept /принимать/ for their being out of bed and creeping /ползучий/ around the school in the dead of night, let alone being up the tallest /Самый высокий/ astronomy /астрономия/ tower, which was out-of-bounds /оценки/ /за границами/ except for classes /классы/. Add /Добавить/ Norbert and the Invisibility Cloak and they might as well be packing /упаковка/ their bags /мешки/ already.
Had Harry thought that things couldn /не мог/’t have been worse? He was wrong. When Professor McGonagall appeared, she was lead /вести/­ing Neville.
‘Harry!’ Neville burst out, the moment he saw the other two. ‘I was trying to find you to warn /предупреждать/ you, I heard Malfoy saying he was going to catch you, he said you had a drag /бремя/—’

Harry shook his head violently /сильно/ to shut Neville up, but Professor McGonagall had seen. She looked more likely /вероятно/ to breathe /дышать/ fire than Norbert as she towered /возвышались/ over the three of them.
‘I would never have believed /Считается,/ it of any of you. Mr Filch says you were up the astronomy /астрономия/ tower. It’s one o’clock /Часы/ in the morning. Explain yourselves /себя/.’
It was the first time Hermione had ever failed /не смогли/ to answer a teach /учат/­er’s /эр-х/ question /вопрос/. She was staring at her slippers /домашние тапочки/, as still as a statue /статуя/.

‘I think I’ve got a good idea of what’s been going on,’ said Professor McGonagall. ‘It doesn’t /не/ take a genius /гениальность/ to work it out. You fed /кормили/ Draco /Дракон/ Malfoy some cock-and-bull /петушиные и-бык/ story about a dragon, trying to get him out of bed and into trouble. I’ve already caught him. I suppose you think it’s funny that Longbottom /Лонгботт/ here heard the story and believed /Считается,/ it, too?’

Harry caught Neville’s eye and tried to tell him without words that this wasn /WASN/’t true, because Neville was looking stunned /ошеломлен/ and hurt. Poor /бедные/, blundering /неумелый/ Neville – Harry knew what it must have cost /Стоимость/ him to try and find them in the dark, to warn /предупреждать/ them.

‘I’m disgusted /чувствующий отвращение/,’ said Professor McGonagall. ‘Four students out of bed in one night! I’ve never heard of such a thing before! You, Miss Granger, I thought you had more sense /смысл/. As for you, Mr Potter, I thought Gryffindor meant /имел ввиду/ more to you than this. All three of you will receive /Получать/ detentions /задержания/ – yes, you too, Mr Longbottom /Лонгботт/, nothing gives /дает/ you the right to walk around school at night, especially /особенно/ these days, it’s very dangerous /опасно/ – and fifty points will be taken from Gryffindor.’
‘Fifty?’ Harry gasped – they would lose the lead /вести/, the lead /вести/ he’d won in the last Quidditch match.
‘Fifty points each,’ said Professor McGonagall, breathing /дыхание/ heavily /сильно/ through her long pointed nose.
‘Professor – please –’
‘You can’t –’
‘Don’t tell me what I can and can’t do, Potter. Now get back to bed, all of you. I’ve never been more ashamed /совестно/ of Gryffindor students.’

A hundred and fifty points lost. That put Gryffindor in last place. In one night, they’d ruined /разрушенный/ any chance Gryffindor had had for the House Cup. Harry felt as though the bottom /дно/ had dropped out of his stomach /желудок/. How could they ever make up for this?

Harry didn /А не было/’t sleep all night. He could hear Neville sobbing /рыдание/ into his pillow /подушка/ for what seemed like hours /часов/. Harry couldn /не мог/’t think of anything to say to comfort /комфорт/ him. He knew Neville, like himself, was dreading /ужасает/ the dawn /рассвет/. What would happen /случаться/ when the rest of Gryffindor found out what they’d done?

At first, Gryffindors passing /прохождение/ the giant hour-glasses /часовые стекла/ that record /запись/­ed /издание/ the house points next day thought there’d /красный/ been a mistake /ошибка/. How could they suddenly have a hundred and fifty points fewer /меньше/ than yesterday /вчера/? And then the story started to spread /распространение/: Harry Potter, the famous Harry Potter, their hero /герой/ of two Quidditch matches /Матчи/, had lost them all those points, him and a couple /пара/ of other stupid first-years.

From being one of the most popular /популярный/ and admired /почитаемый/ people at the school, Harry was suddenly the most hated /ненавистный/. Even Ravenclaws /рейвенкловцы/ and Hufflepuffs /Хаффлпаффцы/ turned on him, because everyone had been longing /желание/ to see Slytherin lose the House Cup. Everywhere /везде/ Harry went, people pointed and didn /А не было/’t trouble to lower /ниже/ their voices /голоса/ as they insulted /оскорбленный/ him. Slytherins /слизеринцы/, on the other hand, clapped as he walked past them, whistling /свистящий/ and cheering /ободряющий/, ‘Thanks Potter, we owe /задолжать/ you one!’
Only Ron stood by him.
‘They’ll /они будут/ all forget this in a few weeks /недель/. Fred and George have lost loads /грузы/ of points in all the time they’ve /они имеют/ been here, and people still like them.’
‘They’ve /они имеют/ never lost a hundred and fifty points in one go, though, have they?’ said Harry miserably /несчастно/.
‘Well – no,’ Ron admitted /признал/.

It was a bit late to repair /ремонт/ the damage /наносить ущерб/, but Harry swore /клялись/ to him­self /сам/ not to meddle /вмешиваться/ in things that weren’t his business /бизнес/ from now on. He’d had it with sneaking /подлый/ around and spying /шпионаж/. He felt so ashamed /совестно/ of himself that he went to Wood and offered /предложенный/ to resign /в отставку/ from the Quidditch team.
‘Resign /в отставку/?’ Wood thundered /прогремело/. ‘What good’ll /good'll/ that do? How are we going to get any points back if we can’t win /выиграть/ at Quidditch?’

But even Quidditch had lost its fun /весело/. The rest of the team wouldn /Wouldn/’t speak to Harry during /в течение/ practice /практика/, and if they had to speak about him, they called him ‘the Seeker’.

Hermione and Neville were suffering /страдающий/, too. They didn /А не было/’t have as bad a time as Harry, because they weren’t as well known, but nobody would speak to them either. Hermione had stopped draw /привлечь/­ing attention /внимание/ to herself /сама/ in class, keeping /хранение/ her head down and work­ing in silence.

Harry was almost glad that the exams /Экзамены/ weren’t far away. All the revision /пересмотр/ he had to do kept his mind off his misery /нищета/. He, Ron and Hermione kept to themselves, working /за работой/ late into the night, trying to remember the ingredients /ингредиенты/ in complicated /сложно/ potions, learn charms /Чары/ and spells /заклинания/ off by heart, memorise /выучить наизусть/ the dates /даты/ of magical discoveries /открытия/ and goblin /гоблин/ rebellions /бунты/ ...

Then, about a week before the exams /Экзамены/ were due /в связи/ to start, Harry’s new resolution /разрешающая способность/ not to interfere /вмешиваться/ in anything that didn /А не было/’t concern /беспокойство/ him was put to an unexpected /неожиданный/ test /контрольная работа/. Walking back from the library on his own one afternoon, he heard somebody /кто-то/ whimpering /нытье/ from a classroom up ahead. As he drew /Дрю/ closer, he heard Quirrell’s voice.
‘No – no – not again, please –’
It sounded /звучало/ as though someone was threatening /угрожающий/ him. Harry moved closer.
‘All right – all right –’ he heard Quirrell sob /рыдать/.

Next second, Quirrell came hurrying /торопясь/ out of the classroom, straightening /выпрямление/ his turban. He was pale and looked as though he was about to cry /плакать/. He strode /зашагал/ out of sight; Harry didn /А не было/’t think Quirrell had even noticed him. He waited /подождал/ until Quirrell’s footsteps /шаги/ had disappeared, then peered /всматривался/ into the classroom. It was empty, but a door stood ajar /приоткрытый/ at the other end. Harry was halfway /наполовину/ towards it before he remembered /вспомнил/ what he’d promised /обещанный/ himself about not meddling /надоедливый/.

All the same, he’d have gambled /азартные игры/ twelve Philosopher’s Stones /камни/ that Snape had just left the room, and from what Harry had just heard, Snape would be walking with a new spring /весна/ in his step /шаг/ – Quirrell seemed to have given in at last.
Harry went back to the library, where Hermione was testing /тестирование/ Ron on Astronomy /астрономия/. Harry told them what he’d heard.
‘Snape’s done it, then!’ said Ron. ‘If Quirrell’s told him how to break his Anti-Dark /анти-темно/ Force /сила/ spell –’
‘There’s still Fluffy, though,’ said Hermione.

‘Maybe Snape’s found out how to get past him without asking /просить/ Hagrid,’ said Ron, looking up at the thousands /тысячи/ of books surround /окружать/­ing them. ‘I bet there’s a book somewhere in here, telling you how to get past a giant three-headed /двуглавый/ /трехголовый/ dog. So what do we do, Harry?’
The light of adventure /приключение/ was kindling /растопка/ again in Ron’s eyes, but Hermione answered /ответил/ before Harry could.
‘Go to Dumbledore. That’s what we should have done ages ago. If we try anything ourselves /сами/ we’ll be thrown /выброшены/ out for sure.’

‘But we’ve got no proof /доказательство/!’ said Harry. ‘Quirrell’s too scared to back us up. Snape’s only got to say he doesn’t /не/ know how the troll got in at Hallowe’en and that he was nowhere /нигде/ near the third floor – who do you think they’ll /они будут/ believe, him or us? It’s not exactly a secret we hate /ненавидеть/ him, Dumbledore’ll /dumbledore'll/ think we made it up to get him sacked /уволен/. Filch wouldn /Wouldn/’t help us if his life depended /зависит/ on it, he’s too friendly /дружелюбный/ with Snape, and the more students get thrown /выброшены/ out, the better, he’ll think. And don’t forget, we’re not supposed to know about the Stone or Fluffy. That’ll /что будет/ take a lot of explaining /объясняя/.’
Hermione looked convinced /убежденный/, but Ron didn /А не было/’t.
‘If we just do a bit of poking /тыкать/ around –’
‘No,’ said Harry flatly /плоско/, ‘we’ve done enough poking /тыкать/ around.’
He pulled a map /карта/ of Jupiter /Юпитер/ towards him and started to learn the names /имена/ of its moons /спутники/.
The following /следующий/ morning, notes /заметки/ were delivered /доставлен/ to Harry, Hermione and Neville at the breakfast table. They were all the same:

p.emphasis: Your detention /задержание/ will take place at eleven o’clock /Часы/ tonight. Meet Mr Filch in the Entrance /вход/ Hall.

section.p: Harry had forgotten they still had detentions /задержания/ to do in the furore /фурор/ over the points they’d lost. He half expected Hermione to com /ком/­plain /гладкий/ that this was a whole night of revision /пересмотр/ lost, but she didn /А не было/’t say a word. Like Harry, she felt they deserved /заслуженный/ what they’d got.

At eleven o’clock /Часы/ that night they said goodbye /Прощай/ to Ron in the common room and went down to the entrance /вход/ hall with Neville. Filch was already there – and so was Malfoy. Harry had also for­gotten /полученный/ that Malfoy had got a detention /задержание/, too.

‘Follow me,’ said Filch, lighting /осветительные приборы/ a lamp and leading /ведущий/ them out­side. ‘I bet you’ll think twice about breaking /ломка/ a school rule /правило/ again, won’t you, eh?’ he continued /продолжение/, leering /плотоядно/ at them. ‘Oh yes ... hard work and pain are the best teachers if you ask me ... It’s just a pity /жалость/ they let the old punishments /наказания/ die out ... hang /вешать/ you by your wrists /запястьях/ from the ceiling for a few days, I’ve got the chains /цепи/ still in my office /офис/, keep ’em well oiled /смазанный маслом/ in case they’re ever needed /необходимый/ ... Right, off we go, and don’t think of running off, now, it’ll /это будет/ be worse for you if you do.’

They marched /маршировали/ off across the dark grounds. Neville kept sniff /сопение/­ing. Harry wondered what their punishment /наказание/ was going to be. It must be something really horrible, or Filch wouldn /Wouldn/’t be sounding /звучащий/ so delighted /Обрадованный/.

The moon /Луна/ was bright, but clouds /облака/ scudding /scudding/ across it kept throwing /бросание/ them into darkness /темнота/. Ahead, Harry could see the lighted /освещенная/ windows /окна/ of Hagrid’s hut. Then they heard a distant /отдаленный/ shout /окрик/.
‘Is that you, Filch? Hurry up, I want ter get started.’

Harry’s heart rose; if they were going to be working /за работой/ with Hagrid it wouldn /Wouldn/’t be so bad. His relief /облегчение/ must have showed in his face, because Filch said, ‘I suppose you think you’ll be enjoying /наслаждаясь/ your­self /сам/ with that oaf /уродливый/? Well, think again, boy – it’s into the Forest you’re going and I’m much mistaken /ошибочный/ if you’ll all come out in one piece /кусок/.’
At this, Neville let out a little moan /стон/ and Malfoy stopped dead in his tracks /треков/.

‘The Forest?’ he repeated /повторный/, and he didn /А не было/’t sound quite as cool /круто/ as usual. ‘We can’t go in there at night – there’s all sorts /виды/ of things in there – werewolves /оборотни/, I heard.’
Neville clutched /схватилась/ the sleeve /рукав/ of Harry’s robe /халат/ and made a choking /задыхаясь/ noise.

‘That’s your lookout /быть осторожным/, isn’t it?’ said Filch, his voice cracking /растрескивание/ with glee /ликование/. ‘Should’ve /надо было/ thought of them werewolves /оборотни/ before you got in trouble, shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ you?’

Hagrid came striding /шагающий/ towards them out of the dark, Fang at his heel /пятка/. He was carrying /проведение/ his large crossbow /арбалет/, and a quiver /колчан/ of arrows /стрелки/ hung over his shoulder.
‘Abou /Abou/’ time,’ he said. ‘I bin waitin /жду/’ fer half an hour already. All right, Harry, Hermione?’
‘I shouldn /не должен/’t /не должен/ be too friendly /дружелюбный/ to them, Hagrid,’ said Filch coldly /холодно/, ‘they’re here to be punished /наказали/, after all.’

‘That’s why yer late, is it?’ said Hagrid, frowning /угрожающий/ at Filch. ‘Bin lecturin /lecturin/’ them, eh? ’Snot /сопли/ your place ter do that. Yeh’ve /yeh've/ done yer bit, I’ll take over from here.’

‘I’ll be back at dawn /рассвет/,’ said Filch, ‘for what’s left of them,’ he added nastily /мерзко/, and he turned and started back towards the castle, his lamp bobbing /флюктуация интенсивности светового пятна на экране радиолокатора/ away in the darkness /темнота/.
Malfoy now turned to Hagrid.
‘I’m not going in that Forest,’ he said, and Harry was pleased to hear the note of panic /паника/ in his voice.
‘Yeh are if yeh want ter stay at Hogwarts,’ said Hagrid fiercely /свирепо/. ‘Yeh’ve /yeh've/ done wrong an’ now yeh’ve /yeh've/ got ter pay /платить/ fer it.’
‘But this is servant /служащий/ stuff, it’s not for students to do. I thought we’d be writing /письмо/ lines /линии/ or something. If my father knew I was doing this, he’d –’

‘– tell yer that’s how it is at Hogwarts,’ Hagrid growled /прорычал/. ‘Writin /пишешь/’ lines /линии/! What good’s /товар/ that ter anyone? Yeh’ll /yeh'll/ do summat /summat/ useful /полезным/ or yeh’ll /yeh'll/ get out. If yeh think yer father’d /father'd/ rather you were expelled, then get back off ter the castle an’ pack /пак/. Go on!’
Malfoy didn /А не было/’t move. He looked at Hagrid furiously /бешено/ but then dropped his gaze /посмотреть/.

‘Right then,’ said Hagrid, ‘now, listen carefully, ’cause /причина/ it’s dan /Дан/­gerous /gerous/ what we’re gonna /собирается/ do tonight an’ I don’ want no one takin /такин/’ risks /риски/. Follow me over here a moment.’

He led /светодиод/ them to the very edge of the Forest. Holding his lamp up high he pointed down a narrow /узкий/, winding /обмотка/ earth /Земля/ track /трек/ that dis /дис/­appeared into the thick black trees. A light breeze /ветер/ lifted /поднятый/ their hair as they looked into the Forest.

‘Look there,’ said Hagrid, ‘see that stuff shinin /Shinin/’ on the ground? Silvery /серебристый/ stuff? That’s unicorn blood. There’s a unicorn in there bin hurt badly /плохо/ by summat /summat/. This is the second time in a week. I found one dead last Wednesday /среда/. We’re gonna /собирается/ try an’ find the poor /бедные/ thing. We might have ter put it out of its misery /нищета/.’
‘And what if whatever /без разницы/ hurt the unicorn finds /находки/ us first?’ said Malfoy, unable /не в состоянии/ to keep the fear /страх/ out of his voice.

‘There’s nothin /Nothin/’ that lives /жизни/ in the Forest that’ll /что будет/ hurt yeh if yer with me or Fang,’ said Hagrid. ‘An’ keep ter the path. Right, now, we’re gonna /собирается/ split /Трещина/ inter /между/ two parties /стороны/ an’ follow the trail /след/ in diff’rent /diff'rent/ directions /направления/. There’s blood all over the place, it must’ve /Должно быть/ bin stag /олень/­gerin /Gerin/’ around since last night at least.’
‘I want Fang,’ said Malfoy quickly, looking at Fang’s /клыка/ long teeth /зубы/.

‘All right, but I warn /предупреждать/ yeh, he’s a coward /трус/,’ said Hagrid. ‘So me, Harry an’ Hermione’ll /hermione'll/ go one way an’ Draco /Дракон/, Neville an’ Fang’ll /fang'll/ go the other. Now, if any of us finds /находки/ the unicorn, we’ll send up green sparks /искры/, right? Get yer wands out an’ practise /практика/ now – that’s it – an’ if anyone gets /получает/ in trouble, send up red sparks /искры/, an’ we’ll all come an’ find yeh – so, be careful /осторожный/ – let’s /Давайте/ go.’

The Forest was black and silent /бесшумный/. A little way into it they reached a fork /вилка/ in the earth /Земля/ path and Harry, Hermione and Hagrid took the left path while Malfoy, Neville and Fang took the right.

They walked in silence, their eyes on the ground. Every now and then a ray /луч/ of moonlight /лунный свет/ through the branches /ветви/ above lit /освещенный/ a spot /место/ of silver blue blood on the fallen /падший/ leaves.
Harry saw that Hagrid looked very worried.
‘Could a werewolf /оборотень/ be killing /убийство/ the unicorns /единороги/?’ Harry asked.
‘Not fast enough,’ said Hagrid. ‘It’s not easy ter catch a unicorn, they’re powerful /мощный/ magic creatures /существа/. I never knew one ter be hurt before.’

They walked past a mossy /мшистый/ tree-stump /пень/. Harry could hear run­ning /нин/ water /воды/; there must be a stream /поток/ somewhere close by. There were still spots /пятна/ of unicorn blood here and there along the winding /обмотка/ path.
‘You all right, Hermione?’ Hagrid whispered. ‘Don’ worry, it can’t’ve /can't've/ gone far if it’s this badly /плохо/ hurt an’ then we’ll be able ter – GET BEHIND THAT TREE!’

Hagrid seized Harry and Hermione and hoisted /водрузили/ them off the path behind a towering /возвышающийся/ oak /дуб/. He pulled out an arrow /стрела/ and fitted /установлены/ it into his crossbow /арбалет/, raising /привлечение/ it, ready to fire. The three of them lis /лис/­tened /tened/. Something was slithering /скользя/ over dead leaves nearby /рядом, поблизости/: it sounded /звучало/ like a cloak trailing /задний/ along the ground. Hagrid was squint /косоглазие/­ing up the dark path, but after a few seconds, the sound faded /утрачен/ away.
‘I knew it,’ he murmured /бормотал/. ‘There’s summat /summat/ in here that shouldn /не должен/’ be.’
‘A werewolf /оборотень/?’ Harry suggested /предложенный/.
‘That wasn /WASN/’ no werewolf /оборотень/ an’ it wasn /WASN/’ no unicorn, neither /ни/,’ said Hagrid grimly /угрюмо/. ‘Right, follow me, but careful /осторожный/, now.’
They walked more slowly, ears straining /деформирование/ for the faintest /тусклых/ sound. Suddenly, in a clearing /клиринг/ ahead, something definitely /определенно/ moved.
‘Who’s /кто/ there?’ Hagrid called. ‘Show yerself /yerself/ – I’m armed /вооруженный/!’

And into the clearing /клиринг/ came – was it a man, or a horse /лошадь/? To the waist /Талия/, a man, with red hair and beard, but below /ниже/ that was a horse /лошадь/’s gleaming /сверкающих/ chestnut /каштан/ body with a long, reddish /красновато/ tail. Harry and Hermione’s jaws /пасть/ dropped.
‘Oh, it’s you, Ronan,’ said Hagrid in relief /облегчение/. ‘How are yeh?’
He walked forward and shook the centaur /кентавр/’s hand.
‘Good evening to you, Hagrid,’ said Ronan. He had a deep, sorrowful /скорбный/ voice. ‘Were you going to shoot /стрелять/ me?’

‘Can’t be too careful /осторожный/, Ronan,’ said Hagrid, patting /похлопывание/ his crossbow /арбалет/. ‘There’s summat /summat/ bad loose /свободный/ in this Forest. This is Harry Potter an’ Hermione Granger, by the way. Students up at the school. An’ this is Ronan, you two. He’s a centaur /кентавр/.’
‘We’d noticed,’ said Hermione faintly /слабо/.
‘Good evening,’ said Ronan. ‘Students, are you? And do you learn much, up at the school?’
‘Erm /эм/ –’
‘A bit,’ said Hermione timidly /застенчиво/.
‘A bit. Well, that’s something.’ Ronan sighed /вздохнул/. He flung /разветвленная/ back his head and stared at the sky. ‘Mars /Марс/ is bright tonight.’
‘Yeah,’ said Hagrid, glancing /поглядывая/ up too. ‘Listen, I’m glad we’ve run inter /между/ yeh, Ronan, ’cause /причина/ there’s a unicorn bin hurt – you seen any­thin’?’
Ronan didn /А не было/’t answer immediately /немедленно/. He stared unblinkingly /мигая/ upwards /вверх/, then sighed /вздохнул/ again.
‘Always the innocent /невинный/ are the first victims /жертвы/,’ he said. ‘So it has been for ages past, so it is now.’
‘Yeah,’ said Hagrid, ‘but have yeh seen anythin’, Ronan? Anythin’ unusual /необычный/?’
‘Mars /Марс/ is bright tonight,’ Ronan repeated /повторный/ while Hagrid watched him impatiently /с нетерпением/. ‘Unusually /необычно/ bright.’
‘Yeah, but I was meanin /meanin/’ anythin’ unusual /необычный/ a bit nearer home,’ said Hagrid. ‘So yeh haven’t noticed anythin’ strange?’
Yet again, Ronan took a while to answer. At last, he said, ‘The Forest hides /шкуры/ many secrets /секреты/.’

A movement /движение/ in the trees behind Ronan made Hagrid raise /повышение/ his bow /лук/ again, but it was only a second centaur /кентавр/, black-haired /черноволосый/ and -bodied /работоспособных/ and wilder /дикое/-looking than Ronan.
‘Hullo /алло/, Bane,’ said Hagrid. ‘All right?’
‘Good evening, Hagrid, I hope you are well?’

‘Well enough. Look, I’ve jus /закон/’ bin askin /спрашиваешь/’ Ronan, you seen any­thin’ odd in here lately /в последнее время/? Only there’s a unicorn bin injured /пострадавший/ – would yeh know anythin’ about it?’
Bane walked over to stand next to Ronan. He looked skywards /к небу/.
‘Mars /Марс/ is bright tonight,’ he said simply /просто/.
‘We’ve heard,’ said Hagrid grumpily /сварливо/. ‘Well, if either of you do see anythin’, let me know, won’t yeh? We’ll be off, then.’
Harry and Hermione followed him out of the clearing /клиринг/, staring over their shoulders /плечи/ at Ronan and Bane until the trees blocked /блокированный/ their view /Посмотреть/.

‘Never,’ said Hagrid irritably /раздражение/, ‘try an’ get a straight answer out of a centaur /кентавр/. Ruddy /румяный/ star-gazers /Звездность gazers/. Not interested /заинтересованный/ in anythin’ closer’n /closer'n/ the moon /Луна/.’
‘Are there many of them in here?’ asked Hermione.

‘Oh, a fair /Справедливая/ few ... Keep themselves to themselves mostly /в основном/, but they’re good enough about turnin /turnin/’ up if ever I want a word. They’re deep, mind, centaurs /кентавры/ ... they know things ... jus /закон/’ don’ let on much.’
‘D’you /d'вас/ think that was a centaur /кентавр/ we heard earlier /ранее/?’ said Harry.
‘Did that sound like hooves /копыта/ to you? Nah /Неа/, if yeh ask me, that was what’s bin killin /убиваешь/’ the unicorns /единороги/ – never heard anythin’ like it before.’

They walked on through the dense /плотный/, dark trees. Harry kept looking nervously over his shoulder. He had the nasty feeling they were being watched. He was very glad they had Hagrid and his crossbow /арбалет/ with them. They had just passed a bend /изгиб/ in the path when Hermione grabbed Hagrid’s arm.
‘Hagrid! Look! Red sparks /искры/, the others are in trouble!’
‘You two wait here!’ Hagrid shouted. ‘Stay on the path, I’ll come back for yeh!’

They heard him crashing /грохот/ away through the undergrowth /подлесок/ and stood looking at each other, very scared, until they couldn /не мог/’t hear anything but the rustling /шуршащий/ of leaves around them.
‘You don’t think they’ve /они имеют/ been hurt, do you?’ whispered Hermione.
‘I don’t care /забота/ if Malfoy has, but if something’s /что-то/ got Neville ... It’s our fault /придираться/ he’s here in the first place.’

The minutes dragged /тащили/ by. Their ears seemed sharper /шулер/ than usual. Harry’s seemed to be picking /собирание/ up every sigh /вздох/ of the wind /ветер/, every cracking /растрескивание/ twig /прут/. What was going on? Where were the others?

At last, a great crunching /хруст/ noise announced /объявленный/ Hagrid’s return /вернуть/. Malfoy, Neville and Fang were with him. Hagrid was fuming /дымящей/. Malfoy, it seemed, had sneaked /проносят/ up behind Neville and grabbed him for a joke /шутка/. Neville had panicked /панический/ and sent up the sparks /искры/.

‘We’ll be lucky ter catch anythin’ now, with the racket /ракетка/ you two were makin /Макин/’. Right, we’re changin /Changin/’ groups /группы/ – Neville, you stay with me an’ Hermione, Harry, you go with Fang an’ this idiot /идиот/. I’m sorry,’ Hagrid added in a whisper /шептать/ to Harry, ‘but he’ll have a harder /Сильнее/ time frightenin /frightenin/’ you, an’ we’ve gotta /должен/ get this done.’

So Harry set off into the heart of the Forest with Malfoy and Fang. They walked for nearly half an hour, deeper /Глубже/ and deeper /Глубже/ into the Forest, until the path became almost impossible /невозможно/ to follow because the trees were so thick. Harry thought the blood seemed to be getting thicker /толще/. There were splashes /брызги/ on the roots /корнеплоды/ of a tree, as though the poor /бедные/ creature /существо/ had been thrashing /порка/ around in pain close by. Harry could see a clearing /клиринг/ ahead, through the tangled /запутанный/ branches /ветви/ of an ancient /древний/ oak /дуб/.
‘Look –’ he murmured /бормотал/, holding out his arm to stop Malfoy.
Something bright white was gleaming /сверкающих/ on the ground. They inched /медленно двигался/ closer.

It was the unicorn all right, and it was dead. Harry had never seen anything so beautiful /красивая/ and sad /грустный/. Its long slender /стройный/ legs were stuck /застрял/ out at odd angles /углы/ where it had fallen /падший/ and its mane /грива/ was spread /распространение/ pearly /жемчужный/ white on the dark leaves.

Harry had taken one step /шаг/ towards it when a slithering /скользя/ sound made him freeze /замерзать/ where he stood. A bush /куст/ on the edge of the clear /Чисто/­ing quivered /задрожала/ ... Then, out of the shadows /тени/, a hooded /закрытый/ figure /фигура/ came crawling /ползком/ across the ground like some stalking /облава/ beast /зверь/. Harry, Malfoy and Fang stood transfixed /замирает/. The cloaked /облачена/ figure /фигура/ reached the uni /уни/­corn /кукуруза/, it lowered /понижена/ its head over the wound /рана/ in the animal /животное/’s side, and began to drink /напиток/ its blood.
‘AAAAAAAAAAARGH /aaaaaaaaaaargh/!’

Malfoy let out a terrible scream /орать/ and bolted /болтовой/ – so did Fang. The hooded /закрытый/ figure /фигура/ raised its head and looked right at Harry – unicorn blood was dribbling /подтекание/ down its front. It got to its feet and came swiftly /быстро/ towards him – he couldn /не мог/’t move for fear /страх/.

Then a pain pierced /пронзили/ his head like he’d never felt before, it was as though his scar was on fire – half-blinded /наполовину ослепленный/, he staggered /в шахматном порядке/ back­wards /подопечные/.
